questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 3

 

The site marked as '3' in the x-ray given above is the neck of the fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop) due to injury to the common fibular nerve.

 

Neck of Fibula is the narrowed region just distal to the head of the fibula. The common fibular (peroneal) nerve winds around the neck of the fibula. This makes the nerve vulnerable at this site, and any injury or compression can affect nerve function.

 

Site 1 – Lateral epicondyle

 

Site 2 – Head of Fibula

 

Site 3 – Neck of Fibula

 

Site 4 – Tibia

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Site 1. Lateral Epicondyle: It is a prominent bony protrusion on the lateral side of the distal end of the humerus, which is the bone of the upper arm. "Tennis elbow" or lateral epicondylitis is a common condition associated with the lateral epicondyle. It's caused by overuse and inflammation of the tendons that attach to the lateral epicondyle, leading to pain and tenderness at the site.

 

Site 2 - Head of Fibula: It is the proximal, rounded end of the fibula, the smaller of the two leg bones. It's located just below the lateral aspect of the knee joint.

 

This is the location of the common fibular (peroneal) nerve, which wraps around the neck of the fibula. Injuries or fractures to the head of the fibula may damage this nerve, potentially leading to foot drop.

 

Site 4 - Tibia: It is also known as the shinbone, is the larger, medial, and anterior bone of the leg, located between the knee and the ankle. It is anteromedially placed in the leg and is palpable along its length. The tibia is a common site for fractures, especially the distal part, due to its subcutaneous position. The anterior surface of the tibia, known as the shin, is easily palpable and is often the site of contusions or "shin splints" in athletes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common fibular nerve's course around the neck of the fibula makes this area a hotspot for injuries leading to dorsiflexion failure, underlining the importance of protecting this area from trauma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the ER with a history of trauma two weeks back with confusion and ataxia. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural haemorrhage

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).
  • Subdural hematomas typically occur due to the rupture of bridging veins, which can be associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, or chronic alcohol overuse.
  •  The presentation of symptoms like confusion and ataxia two weeks after trauma is characteristic of a chronic subdural hematoma.

 

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of bridging veins.
  • Etiology: Can be acute (traumatic) or chronic (associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, chronic alcohol overuse). Also seen in shaken babies.
  • Clinical Features: Typically presents without a lucid interval; altered consciousness from the onset. Features of raised intracranial tension and neurological deficits may be present.
  • CT Findings: Crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (branch of the maxillary artery), often secondary to a skull fracture involving the pterion.
  • Clinical Features: Often includes a lucid interval (period of normalcy between two periods of unconsciousness).
  • CT Findings: Biconvex (lentiform), hyperdense blood collection that does not cross suture lines.

 

Option C. Intra-parenchymal Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Most commonly caused by systemic hypertension.
  • Location: Most often occurs in the putamen/globus pallidus of the basal ganglia (lenticulostriate vessels).
  • CT Findings: Intra-parenchymal bleed.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Bleeding due to trauma or rupture of an aneurysm (such as a saccular aneurysm).
  • Clinical Features: Patients complain of the “worst headache of my life.” Bloody or yellow lumbar puncture. Vasospasm can occur, nimodipine is used to prevent/reduce it.
  • CT Findings: Intraventricular and subarachnoid space hyperdensities represent acute hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval.
  •  CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

The given scenario and image is most likely to be of Fournier gangrene which is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

 

FOURNIER’S GANGRENE

 

  • Synergistic gangrene of scrotum and perineum
  • Limited to skin and fascial planes - type of necrotising fasciitis
  • Never breaches the tunica, testis always spared
  • Risk factors - Low immunity, uncontrolled diabetes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases: Anti-gas gangrene serum is obsolete now.

 

Option B. Urinary diversion is the next step: Urinary diversion is not the next best step.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy must be done: Testes are preserved during debridement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier gangrene is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jerovecii

 

The given scenario is pointing out to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis (aka South American blastomycosis • Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease), presents with oral mucosa lesions, cervical lymphadenopathy, and pulmonary lesions.

 

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, systemic granulomatous disease. On GMS staining, shows tiny oval yeast cells (2–4 µm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

 

Option C. Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, around 60% patients are asymptomatic. Manifests as pneumonia, cavities, pleural effusion or nodule formation, Skin lesions, Arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a critical opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients, characterized by non-specific respiratory symptoms and distinctive cystic structures on Gomori methenamine silver staining. Regular prophylaxis and monitoring are essential for at-risk populations.

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer was brought to the emergency after he suddenly became unconscious while working in the field. On examination, his temperature was 105 degrees Fahrenheit and his skin turgor was decreased. Which of the following would not be seen in the patient?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweating

 

Explanation

 

In the scenario described, the patient likely suffers from heatstroke, characterized by a high body temperature (105°F), altered consciousness, and dehydration (indicated by decreased skin turgor).

 

Heatstroke is a severe form of heat illness that occurs when the body's heat-dissipating mechanisms fail. One of the classic signs, especially in exertional heatstroke, is the cessation of sweating, despite the elevated body temperature. This lack of sweating is due to dehydration and the body's inability to maintain adequate heat loss through evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Tachypnea - Rapid, deep breathing (Kussmaul breathing) can be seen in heatstroke

 

Option B: Hypotension - Dehydration and vasodilation in an attempt to dissipate heat can result in hypotension in heatstroke.

 

Option D: Red hot skin - Heatstroke patients can present with hot, flushed skin due to increased blood flow to the skin surface and the body's inability to dissipate heat effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Difference between Fever and Heatstroke is as follows:

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, hysteroscopy can be done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asherman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

 

Asherman Syndrome

 

  • These are intra-uterine adhesions
  • They usually follow a history of sharp curettage
  • Symptoms are hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea and secondary infertility

 

Diagnosis –

 

TVS: broken/ irregular endometrium

 

HSG: space filling defect is seen (moth eaten appearance)

 

Ix of choice: Hysteroscopy

 

Treatment - Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubal ligation: Tubal ligation is done via laparoscopy.

 

Option C. Endocervical polyp: In Endocervical polyps’ cases surgical ligation and excision can be done if severe bleeding is expected. Hysteroscopy can help visualisation and assessment but it is not the primary method for managing endocervical polyps.

 

Option D. Subserosal fibroid: In cases of Subserosal fibroids an MRI helps in detailed mapping of the fibroids if a myomectomy is planned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presented with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you suspect in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3 deficiency

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia is suggestive of niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Vitamin B3 (also called niacin, nicotinic acid)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1/Thiamine deficiency: can manifest as wet beriberi (CVS features like heart failure and edema), dry beriberi (peripheral neuritis), or as Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis (in alcoholics). Dietary deficiency of thiamine inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6/Pyridoxine deficiency: causes Convulsions, hyperirritability, peripheral neuropathy (deficiency inducible by isoniazid and oral contraceptives), sideroblastic anemia (due to impaired hemoglobin synthesis and iron excess)

 

Option D. Vitamin B12/Cobalamin deficiency: causes Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia, paraesthesia and subacute combined degeneration due to abnormal myelin. Associated with

↑ serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels, along with 2° folate deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Following image shows Casal’s Necklace & hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed limbs:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in OPD with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid tumor

 

  • The given clinical scenario and image points to a diagnosis of parotid tumor.
  • MC benign parotid tumor is Pleomorphic Adenoma.
  • MC site: superficial lobe of parotid

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst: Seen in children at lines of mesodermal fusion like outer canthus of eye.

 

 

Option C. Sebaceous cyst: Will show soft consistency and punctum.

 

 

Option D. Swollen cervical lymph node – will show firm consistency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A parotid tumor, particularly pleomorphic adenoma, is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.
  • It is characterized by slow growth, a variable consistency, and mobility, commonly found in the superficial lobe of the parotid gland.
  • Proper diagnosis involves imaging and FNAC, with treatment typically involving surgical removal while preserving the facial nerve if possible.

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from tongue to prostate is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Letulle technique

 

Letulle’s method (En masse)

 

  • Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • Best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other                         
  • Disadvantage: difficult to handle large mass.

 

Below image shows Letulle’s Method

 

 

Other Options:

 

Other Autopsy Techniques for Evisceration:

 

Option A. Virchow’s method

 

  • Each and every organ is removed one by one (e.g., each lung, each kidney, heart separately)
  • Relations of organs are not preserved
  • Most commonly used technique (easier to perform)

 

Below image shows Virchow’s Method

 

 

Option B. Rokitansky Method-

 

  • In situ
  • Organs dissected inside the body
  • for highly infectious disease, e.g., HIV to prevent the spread of infection

 

Below image shows Rokitansky Method

 

 

Option C. Ghon’s method (en block):

 

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks

 

Below image shows Ghon’s Method

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Letulle technique involves removing thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs en masse, preserving their relationships, and is preferred for infants to observe congenital abnormalities.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, PC dikshit, page 147

choices.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure
The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure
The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure
Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation

questions.text: The true statement among the following is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

 

Losartan is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker. It binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. It is also a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor and attenuates platelet aggregation. All ARBs are avoided in moderate to severe renal impairment due to risk of development of hyperkalemia. Most ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic impairment also except LEO (Safe in Liver disease are Eprosartan and Olmesartan)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure: Like all the ARBs, telmisartan is avoided in severe renal disease. Further, telmisartan is excreted by biliary secretion. So, dose of telmisartan should be reduced in mild to moderate hepatic failure. 

 

Option B. The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure: Irbesartan is avoided in both severe renal and hepatic disease.

 

Option C. The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure: Olmesartan require dose adjustment in severe renal failure. However, olmesartan and eprosartan do not require dose adjustment even in severe liver failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All ARBs should be avoided in moderate to severe renal disease due to risk of hyperkalemia. Except Olmesartan and Eprosartan, all other ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic disease also. Losartan has additional antiplatelet action by acting as TXA2 receptor antagonist.

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the groin region. A diagnosis of direct inguinal hernia is made. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conjoint tendon

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia occurs when abdominal contents herniate through a weak point in the fascia of the abdominal wall.
  • This type of hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach's triangle, which is defined by the rectus abdominis muscle medially, the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, and the inguinal ligament inferiorly.
  • The conjoint tendon, which is formed by the merging of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles, makes up the main part of the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • Weakness in the conjoint tendon is most likely to cause a direct inguinal hernia.

 

Direct Inguinal Hernia

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arises from Hesselbach’s triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Mechanism: Due to weakness in the conjoint tendon.
  • Key Feature: Protrudes directly through the abdominal wall without passing through the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal ligament: The pectineal ligament (Cooper's ligament) is a thickened band of periosteum along the pectineal line of the pubis. It is not typically involved in the development of direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option C. Reflected part of inguinal ligament: The reflected part of the inguinal ligament is a part of the external oblique aponeurosis and is not the primary structure associated with the weakness leading to direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Lacunar ligament: The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal and is associated more with femoral hernias rather than inguinal hernias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Direct inguinal hernias result from a weakness in the conjoint tendon, which forms a crucial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  •  This anatomical weakness allows abdominal contents to protrude directly through the abdominal wall within Hesselbach’s triangle.

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl's eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

Owl's eye appearance on urinary examination is typically seen in Cytomegalovirus.

 

CMV, Human Herpes Virus 5, Largest virus in Herpesviridae family

 

 

 

Other options are not associated with Owl’s eye appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl's eye" appearance of cells in the urine is a diagnostic clue for Cytomegalovirus infection, especially relevant for diagnosing congenital CMV infections in neonates or severe infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaint of a jaw swelling. His tissue was found to have the presence of t (8;14). The histopathological appearance of the bone marrow aspirate tissue is given in the image. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkitt lymphoma 

 

The presence of a translocation t(8;14) is characteristic of Burkitt’s lymphoma. The same is confirmed by the tumor cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli.

 

Direct lines from Robbins.. - ”When the bone marrow is involved, aspirates reveal tumor cells with slightly clumped nuclear chromatin, two to five distinct nucleoli, and royal blue cytoplasm containing clear cytoplasmic vacuoles”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular lymphoma: Characterized by t(14;18) translocation and involves BCL2 gene, not typically presenting with jaw swelling.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Does not involve t(8;14) translocation and has different histopathological features.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Plasma cell neoplasm, typically presents with bone pain, anemia, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia, not with t(8;14) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt lymphoma is identified by the presence of the t(8;14) translocation and histopathological features including cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli. It commonly presents with jaw or abdominal tumors and requires prompt recognition and treatment due to its aggressive nature.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enhance fibrin degradation

 

Tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) converts plasminogen to plasmin that breaks the thrombus, which results in fibrinolysis of formed thrombus (thrombolysis).

 

Drugs in this class include:

 

S – Streptokinase

 

U – Urokinase

 

R – Reteplase

 

A – Alteplase

 

T – Tenecteplase

 

Indication → Pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability

         Acute ischemic stroke

         Acute MI

 

Overdose of thrombolytics

 

→ Leads to bleeding

 

→ Antidotes: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid [EACA]

                      Tranexamic Acid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibit extrinsic pathway: This is not the mechanism of tPA. The extrinsic pathway involves the activation of clotting factors by tissue factor and is more related to clot formation rather than breakdown.

 

Option B. Inhibits platelet aggregation: This is not the mechanism of tPA. Platelet aggregation is inhibited by drugs like aspirin and clopidogrel, not by tPA.

 

Option D. Inhibit clot formation: This is not the mechanism of tPA. Inhibition of clot formation is achieved by anticoagulants like heparin and warfarin, whereas tPA is involved in clot breakdown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) enhances fibrin degradation by converting plasminogen to plasmin, leading to the dissolution of blood clots.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby is brought to OPD with jaundice and clay-colored stools. Lab work up reveals that the baby has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. A liver biopsy was done and shows periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biliary atresia

 

An infant with jaundice, clay-coloured stools, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is highly suggestive of biliary atresia.

 

An infant with Biliary atresia presents with progressive jaundice, persistent yellow stools, and palpable liver with abnormal consistency.

 

Laboratory investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Ultrasonography reveals a triangular-cord sign (cone-shaped fibrotic mass cranial to the bifurcation of the portal vein).

 

HIDA test is more relevant for its negative predictive value (100%). Liver biopsy is diagnostic for biliary atresia. In biliary atresia, portal tract expansion, ductular proliferation and fibrosis is seen.

 

Laparotomy and perioperative cholangiography may be required in an infant with equivocal biopsy, findings and no excretion on HIDA scan, to evaluate for biliary atresia.

 

Biliary atresia is managed by Kasai procedure (hepato-portoenterostomy).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crigler-Najjar syndrome: This is characterized by absent or deficient UGT enzyme leading to increased unconjugated bilirubin. It does not present with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or clay-colored stools.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: A mild form of Dubin-Johnson syndrome that causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but without the dark liver appearance seen in Dubin-Johnson syndrome. It does not present with periductal proliferation on liver biopsy.

 

Option C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Characterized by increased conjugated bilirubin and a dark liver appearance. It is an autosomal recessive disorder but does not present with the same liver biopsy findings as biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An infant presenting with jaundice, clay-colored stools, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is highly suggestive of biliary atresia.

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

 

Rotavirus is among the most common identifiable viral causes of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years. Most cases are asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance.

 

Diagnosis – ELISA – Detects rotavirus antigen in Stool

 

  • Molecular methods – PCR, BioFilm Array

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antigen detection in blood: Not used for rotavirus as the virus does not typically present in blood.

 

Option C. Antibody detection in serum: This method is not typically used for acute diagnosis as it indicates past exposure rather than current infection.

 

Option D. Light microscopy of stool specimen: This is ineffective for viruses like rotavirus due to their small size and lack of distinctive morphology in light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antigen detection in stool samples is the standard diagnostic approach for confirming rotavirus infection, crucial for implementing appropriate management strategies, especially in managing dehydration risks in young children.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below as A? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fascia transversalis

 

Marked structure is the deep inguinal ring, formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.

 

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.

 

An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal Oblique:  The internal oblique muscle is one of the three major muscles of the lateral abdominal wall. It lies just deep to the external oblique and superficial to the transversus abdominis.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the lumbar fascia, anterior two-thirds of the iliac crest, and lateral half of the inguinal ligament. It inserts into the lower ribs, linea alba, and the pubic bone.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option B. External Oblique: The external oblique is the most superficial of the three flat muscles of the lateral abdominal wall.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the outer surfaces of the 5th to 12th ribs and inserts into the linea alba, pubic tubercle, and anterior half of the iliac crest.
  • Innervation: Like the internal oblique, it's innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option C. Parietal Peritoneum: The parietal peritoneum is the outer layer of the peritoneum that lines the internal surface of the abdominal wall.

 

  • Composition: It consists of a single layer of squamous epithelial cells (mesothelium) and its underlying connective tissue.
  • Innervation: The parietal peritoneum overlying the anterior abdominal wall is primarily innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fascia Transversalis: The fascia transversalis is a thin aponeurotic membrane which lies between the inner surface of the transversus abdominis muscle and the parietal peritoneum. It covers the entire inner surface of the abdominal wall and is continuous with the iliac and pelvic fasciae.

 

Hernias that penetrate the fascia transversalis in the groin region are called direct inguinal hernias.

choices.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury and his serum K+ level was found to be 5.5 mEq/L. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Becomes more positive

 

Explanation

 

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause a shift in the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value, increased cell excitability, and impairments in membrane potential changes.

 

Hyperkalemia can affect the resting membrane potential of cells, including neurons and muscle cells, in the following ways:

 

  1. Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value.
  2. Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli.
  3. Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials.
  4.  Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No change: Incorrect. Changes in extracellular potassium concentrations directly impact the resting membrane potential.

 

Option B. Becomes more negative: Incorrect. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration results in depolarization (more positive resting membrane potential), not hyperpolarization.

 

Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative: Incorrect. While complex fluctuations can occur under dynamic conditions, primarily, hyperkalemia causes a persistent depolarization (more positive shift) without an initial opposite change.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hyperkalemia, as seen in patients with severe muscle injury, the resting membrane potential becomes more positive due to decreased potassium efflux, leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells. This can affect the normal function of these cells, potentially leading to complications such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. What is the reason behind this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rebound hypertension

 

Clonidine is an alpha-2 agonist and a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. Used in HTN. Stimulates presynaptic α-receptor in the vasomotor centre in the brainstem, suppressing the release of norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.

 

Clonidine sudden stoppage causes Rebound HTN and sympathetic overactivity.

 

Treatment of clonidine withdrawal is Phentolamine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postural Hypotension

 

  • Description: A condition where blood pressure drops significantly upon standing up.
  • Relevance: Clonidine can cause postural hypotension, but sudden discontinuation leads to rebound hypertension, not postural hypotension.

 

Option B. Receptor Upregulation

 

  • Description: An increase in the number of receptors on the cell surface.
  • Relevance: This concept is more related to long-term exposure to antagonists, not the sudden withdrawal of an agonist like clonidine.

 

Option D. Receptor Hypersensitivity

 

  • Description: Increased sensitivity of receptors to a stimulus.
  • Relevance: While receptor hypersensitivity can occur, it is not the primary mechanism behind the headache and rebound hypertension seen with sudden clonidine withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rebound hypertension is a critical condition that can occur when clonidine, an alpha-2 agonist, is suddenly discontinued. This results in a rapid increase in sympathetic activity, leading to symptoms such as headache due to a sudden spike in blood pressure.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Patient with given clinical symptoms and the HRP-2 positivity points to diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria.

 

This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2), produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum, present on the surface of RBCs. It can detect only Plasmodium falciparum HRP-2 antigen but not the other three species of Plasmodium. Test remains positive until 2 weeks after the cure.

 

 

Another Kit test is Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (p LDH) which can detect all four Plasmodium species that infect humans.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Not detected by the HRP-2 test.

 

Option C. Plasmodium vivax and Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Also not detected by the HRP-2 test. They would be identified by other rapid tests targeting different antigens like pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who is being treated for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin presented with complaints of sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness. The finding of the ultrasound is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG  2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

The given clinical situation and USG showing enlarged ovaries having large cysts points to diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

 

OVARIAN HYPERSTIMULATION SYNDROME

 

  • OHSS is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation.
  • The clinical features appear about 3–6 days after the ovulating dose of hCG is administered.
  • Pathophysiology - Increased capillary permeability leads to leakage of fluid from the peritoneal and ovarian surfaces. Variety of chemical mediators like cytokines, Variety of chemical mediators like cytokines.

 

 

 

Management - The management of OHSS is mainly supportive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polycystic ovarian syndrome: PCOS is characterized by chronic anovulation, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries, but it does not typically present with sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness associated with enlarged ovaries having large cysts as seen in OHSS.

 

Option C. Theca lutein cysts: These cysts are associated with molar pregnancies and multiple gestations, often presenting with high levels of hCG but not typically with the acute symptoms and clinical scenario described here.

 

Option D. Granulosa cell tumor: This is a type of ovarian tumor that does not present with the acute symptoms and ultrasound findings characteristic of OHSS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation, with symptoms including abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness, often visible on ultrasound as enlarged ovaries with large cysts.

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He also complains of a sweaty palm. His appearance is as shown in the picture. What is the next step in evaluation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ultrasensitive thyrotropin

 

The patient's symptoms and the clinical image strongly suggest Graves' Orbitopathy (also known as Graves' Ophthalmopathy), characterized by proptosis, eyelid edema, and eye congestion. The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral exophthalmos is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism.

 

The next step in evaluating a patient suspected of having hyperthyroidism is to perform a thyroid function test (TFT), with the most important initial test being the measurement of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH). The ultrasensitive thyrotropin test, which measures TSH levels, is crucial because it helps in determining the presence of hyperthyroidism.

 

In Graves' disease, TSH levels are typically very low or undetectable, while free T4 and Total T3 levels are elevated (primary hyperthyroidism).

 

IOC – MRI of the orbit

 

TOC – mild – moderate disease – conservative management

 

Mod.-severe disease – first line TOC – CS (Dexamethasone); Teprotumumab (IGF1 receptor inhibitor Mab)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid receptor antibody: This test is specific for confirming Graves' disease, but it is not the first step. It is used after initial thyroid function tests suggest hyperthyroidism to confirm the diagnosis. The antibodies known as TRAb (TSH receptor antibody/ Thyroid receptor Ab).

 

2 forms of TRAb – TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin) and

                -  TBII (Thyroid binding Inhibitory Immunoglobulin)

 

Option B. Radioactive Iodine Uptake: This test helps to differentiate between various causes of hyperthyroidism, such as Graves' disease and toxic multinodular goiter. It is not the first step but follows initial thyroid function tests if hyperthyroidism is confirmed.

 

Option D. Anti thyroid peroxidase antibody: This antibody is not specific for Graves' disease. It is more commonly associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and other autoimmune thyroid disorders, making it less relevant for initial evaluation in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first and most crucial test in the evaluation of suspected hyperthyroidism, such as in a case suggestive of Graves' disease, is the measurement of ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels.

 

Confirmatory Diagnosis – by TRAbs (Thyroid receptor antibodies)

questions.text: The temperature of a body of a deceased person is found to be 39 degrees Celsius. Which of the following is the most probable reason? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Septicaemia

 

Septicaemia, a severe infection where bacteria enter the bloodstream, causes the body to produce a high fever due to excessive bacterial activity. This can result in postmortem caloricity, where the body temperature remains elevated after death.

 

Postmortem Caloricity: Usually cooling of the body occurs after death, however in certain exceptional conditions the body temperatures remain increased after death for 2-3 hours. This is called Postmortem Caloricity.

 

It can Occur due to two reasons:

 

1) Body temperature was too high before death

 

  1. When Heat regulation is disturbed before death: Heat Stroke, pontine hemorrhage    
  2. Increased heat production due to convulsions: Strychnine poisoning and tetanus
  3. Increased heat production due to excessive bacterial activity: Infectious diseases (Septicaemia, typhoid etc.)

 

2) Very high environmental temperature

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyanide poisoning: Cyanide poisoning leads to rapid death by inhibiting cellular respiration, but it does not typically cause elevated postmortem body temperature.

 

Option C. Corrosive poisoning: Corrosive poisons cause tissue damage and may lead to symptoms such as pain and vomiting, but they do not typically result in postmortem caloricity.

 

Option D. Intra-abdominal hemorrhage: Intra-abdominal hemorrhage involves bleeding within the abdominal cavity, which does not cause elevated postmortem body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem caloricity, where the body temperature remains elevated after death, can occur due to high body temperature before death, such as in cases of septicaemia, heat stroke, and certain poisonings, or due to very high environmental temperature.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 81

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

 

Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve. Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms  described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS): This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. While MPS can affect the eyes, leading to problems like corneal clouding and glaucoma, the key symptoms often include developmental delay, skeletal and joint abnormalities, and coarse facial features. Eye-related symptoms are typically not the first presenting symptoms in MPS.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This refers to a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth. Congenital cataracts can cause a variety of symptoms including a noticeable white, grey, or yellow spot in the pupil, nystagmus (uncontrolled eye movements), and yes, potentially photophobia. However, lacrimation (excessive tearing) is not a typical symptom of cataracts.

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: This condition is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborns. Typically, it's caused by bacteria acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother. The primary symptoms include redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, and discharge, which may be watery or pus-like. Photophobia can be a symptom, but it's not as common as in some other conditions like congenital glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with features of respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. There is a history of upper respiratory infection. The radiograph is shown below. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

 

A child with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor and given radiograph points to a diagnosis of acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

 

LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS (CROUP)

 

  • Viral infection of glottis & subglottic region
  • Caused by Parainfluenza virus
  • Symptoms: hoarse voice, coryza, mild Tachypnea

 

Treatment –

 

  • Nebulized racemic adrenaline (1:1 mixture of d & I isomers)
  • A single dose of dexamethasone (0.3--0.6 mg/kg, intramuscular) reduces seventy, if given within the first 24 hours.
  • Antibiotics not indicated

 

NOTE -

 

Croup decreases in lying down position and Laryngomalacia increases on lying down

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis patients, usually 3-6 years of age, present with acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia and drooling. The patient looks toxic and sits in tripod position, sitting upright, leaning forward with chin up. Treatment is IV Ceftriaxone. Lateral neck X-ray reveals thickening of the epiglottis (thumb print sign).

 

 

Option C. Foreign body in glottis: Aspiration of foreign body may result in localized area of wheeze, hyperresonance and reduced air entry. Foreign bodies are removed through a rigid bronchoscope.

 

Option D. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is M/C cause of congenital laryngeal anomaly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral infection of the glottis and subglottic region, often caused by the Parainfluenza virus, and presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor.

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount.

 

Lab Diagnosis for Trichomonas:

 

  1. Direct Microscopy: Wet (saline) mount of fresh samples jerky motile trophozoites and pus cells. Cystic stage not seen.
  2. Culture: Gold standard method for diagnosis.
  3. Serology: Antigen Detection in Vaginal Secretion:
    • More sensitive than microscopy
    • Indicates recent infection
    • ELISA uses monoclonal antibodies.
    • Antibody Detection by ELISA - whole cell antigen preparation
  4. Molecular Methods: Highly sensitive targeting T. vaginalis specific genes - beta-tubulin gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be cultured: Incorrect, as Trichomonas vaginalis can indeed be cultured and this is considered the gold standard for its diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions: Incorrect, Trichomonas vaginalis does not produce cysts; it exists only in trophozoite form.

 

Option D. It is not a sexually transmitted infection: Incorrect, as it is a well-known sexually transmitted infection.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sign indicating adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 3 kg? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year

 

Correct sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant is an increase in length of 25 cm in the first year.

 

Normal length of a newborn - 48-50cm (increase by 50% at 1st year = 75cm)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year: An infant gain weight at a rate of approximately 20-40 g per day for the first 3 months of life. Thereafter, they gain about 400 g weight every month for the remaining part of the first year.

 

Option C. Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age:

 

 

Option D. Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile: According to WHO growth charts, weight and height under 50th percentile do not indicate adequate growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in length by 25 cm in the first year is a key indicator of adequate growth in infants.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vagina mixed with mucous discharge. On examination, a necrotizing growth is seen in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. What will be the management for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chemoradiation

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with a foul-smelling bloody discharge mixed with mucous discharge, and a necrotizing growth in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. These clinical features are suggestive of advanced cervical cancer. The involvement of the lateral parametrium indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the cervix to the surrounding tissues but not to the pelvic wall or the lower third of the vagina, which classifies it as Stage 2B cervical cancer. The standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer is chemoradiation, which combines chemotherapy with radiation therapy. This approach aims to enhance the effectiveness of the treatment, reduce tumor size, and prevent further spread of the cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer. It may be used in conjunction with radiation, but not as a sole therapy in this stage.

 

Option B. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation therapy, is typically used for early-stage cervical cancer or in combination with external beam radiation therapy for more advanced stages. However, it is not sufficient as a standalone treatment for Stage 2B.

 

Option D. Surgery: Surgery is generally not recommended for Stage 2B cervical cancer due to the extent of the disease spread to the parametrium. The preferred approach is chemoradiation to address both local and regional disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 2B cervical cancer, characterized by lateral parametrium involvement, is best managed with chemoradiation.

 

Staging of CA Cervix

 

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1
  • Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4

 

 

Chemoradiation can be offered at all stages

choices.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, direct Coombs test

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought with pallor and jaundice. On examination he had a hemoglobin of 9g/dl and mild splenomegaly. He has a history of similar episodes from birth.  The peripheral smear had red cells without central pallor. Which of the following is useful for making the diagnosis of the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility test 

 

Presence of mild jaundice, splenomegaly and anemia is suggestive of hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis. Since the history of similar episodes since child birth is present it is more likely a familiar case and so, the most appropriate answer is hereditary spherocytosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, direct Coombs test: While autoimmune hemolytic anemia also presents with hemolysis, the history of episodes from birth and the specific peripheral smear findings are more suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Typically presents with acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, not with a chronic history from birth.

 

Option D. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): Characterized by intravascular hemolysis, hemoglobinuria, and a different set of laboratory findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis should be suspected in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and spherocytes on a peripheral smear. The osmotic fragility test is a key diagnostic tool for this condition.

 

  • Spherocytes are more fragile in hypotonic solutions due to reduced surface area-to-volume ratio.
  • Newer and more sensitive tests include EMA (Eosin-5-maleimide) binding test by flow cytometry.

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required

questions.text: A patient came to the medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels are found to be 155 mEq/L, urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

 

The patient's presentation of polyuria and low urine osmolality (200 mOsm/L) with hypernatremia (Na+ 155 mEq/L) is indicative of diabetes insipidus (DI). Given the history of total hypophysectomy, this is most likely central diabetes insipidus (CDI), where the pituitary gland no longer produces antidiuretic hormone (ADH, also known as vasopressin).

 

In CDI, the definitive treatment is desmopressin (DDAVP), a synthetic analog of ADH. Desmopressin helps to reduce urine output and correct hypernatremia by promoting water reabsorption in the kidneys. Since the condition is permanent due to the hypophysectomy, lifelong supplementation with desmopressin is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue: Discontinuing DDAVP after 2 weeks is not appropriate as the patient will continue to suffer from polyuria and hypernatremia due to the lack of ADH.

 

Option C. Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required: This option is incorrect as the patient's symptoms and lab findings clearly indicate the need for treatment.

 

Option D. Thiazides for 2 weeks: Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) to reduce urine output by increasing ADH sensitivity. However, in central diabetes insipidus, thiazides are not effective because the issue is the absence of ADH, not a problem with the kidneys' response to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy, lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation is required to manage symptoms and prevent complications from persistent polyuria and hypernatremia.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following aortic arches causes the defect shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 6th left

 

The image depicts a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th pharyngeal arch.

 

Normally, the ductus arteriosus closes within 72 hours of birth. However, in cases of PDA, the ductus arteriosus fails to close, leading to abnormal blood flow between the two major arteries.

 

Presentation - Hyperdynamic precordium, bounding peripheral pulses, wide pulse pressure, a machine-like continuous or systolic murmur, cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings, hepatomegaly, increasing oxygen dependence, carbon dioxide retention, and renal failure.

 

Treatment options for PDA include medication, minimally invasive catheter-based procedures, and surgical closure. Medications like indomethacin or ibuprofen can be given to encourage closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

The aortic arch arteries, also referred to as the branchial or pharyngeal arch arteries, are a series of six paired arterial structures that arise from the aortic sac during embryonic development. They play a crucial role in the formation of the major arteries of the head, neck, and thorax. Abnormal development or persistence of these arteries can lead to a range of congenital anomalies.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 4th left and Option B. 4th right: These arches are primarily involved in forming parts of the aorta and its major branches, not directly related to the defect depicted in the image.

 

Option D. 6th right: While the right 6th arch also contributes to the development of the pulmonary artery system, its defects are usually not associated with PDA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Here's a list of defects related to the aortic arch arteries:

 

  1. Double Aortic Arch: This involves the persistence of both the right and left fourth aortic arches. It can form a vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus, which can cause respiratory and feeding difficulties.
  2. Right Aortic Arch: This results from the regression of the left fourth aortic arch. Depending on the persistence of the ductus arteriosus, different types can form, some of which can lead to a vascular ring.
  3. Interrupted Aortic Arch: Here, there's a complete loss of continuity between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta. It's often associated with other congenital heart defects.
  4. Persistent Truncus Arteriosus: This is a failure of the truncus arteriosus to divide into the pulmonary trunk and aorta, leading to a single arterial trunk emerging from the heart supplying both systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations.
  5. Coarctation of the Aorta: It's a narrowing of the aorta, often occurring near the site of the ductus arteriosus. It can lead to high blood pressure in the upper body and arms and lower blood pressure in the lower body and legs.
  6. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA): After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes, but in this condition, it remains open, leading to abnormal blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery.
  7. Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery: This is a variant in the branching pattern where the right subclavian artery arises as the last branch of the aortic arch and can course posterior to the esophagus.
  8. Cervical Aortic Arch: Here, the aortic arch is positioned higher than normal in the neck. It is usually of no clinical significance but can be identified radiologically.
  9. Aortopulmonary Septal Defects: These defects involve abnormal connections between the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.
  10. Vascular Rings: These are congenital anomalies of the aortic arch and its branches that encircle and compress the trachea and esophagus.

questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recommended dietary allowance

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population. RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population. RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate intake: A value based on observed or experimentally determined approximations of nutrient intake by a group (or groups) of healthy people.

 

Option B. Dietary goals: are quantitative national targets for selected macronutrients and micronutrients aimed at preventing long-term chronic disease. They focus on population-level nutritional health.

 

Option C. The estimated average requirement (EAR): Average daily level of intake estimated to meet the requirements of 50% of healthy individual’s RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)

 

  • Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable.
  • For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

  • An abdominoperineal resection involves the removal of the left colon, pelvic floor, rectum, and anal canal.
  •  It is typically indicated for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas located within 5 cm of the anal verge.
  • The sympathetic innervation of the rectum originates from L1 – L3 spinal nerves, which form the superior hypogastric plexus.  
  • At the level of the sacral promontory, these nerves divide into the left and right hypogastric nerves, traveling on both sides of the pelvis.
  • These nerves supply the rectum and send branches to supply the genitourinary system anteriorly.
  • During pelvic surgeries, it is crucial to be aware of these nerves to avoid injuring them.
  • High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) near the sacral promontory may injure the superior hypogastric nerves, leading to sympathetic dysfunction.
  • This dysfunction is characterized by retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation: Parasympathetic nerves are less likely to be affected by the ligation of the IMA as their pathways are different. Parasympathetic innervation primarily involves the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4), which are not typically disrupted in this procedure.

 

Option B. Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and impotence: While bladder dysfunction is a possible consequence of sympathetic nerve damage, impotence is not the most common result of injury to the sympathetic nerves. The more typical outcome includes retrograde ejaculation.

 

Option D. Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region: Loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region would more likely result from damage to the pudendal nerve, not the sympathetic nerves. Impotence can occur but is less specific compared to retrograde ejaculation in the context of IMA ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus.
  • This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

 

Explanation

 

The above clinical scenario depicts transection of the spinal cord in the lateral aspect of the dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm.

 

 

The fibers in the dorsal column are arranged in such a manner that the sacral segments are positioned most medially and those from the cervical segments are positioned most laterally.

 

These are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus gracilis - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb
  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus cuneatus - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral upper limb.

 

Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus functions:

 

  1. Fine touch
  2. Tactile localization
  3. Tactile discrimination
  4. Vibration

 

This patient with an injury to the lateral part of the cervical cord's dorsal column tract will have damaged fasciculus cuneatus. This would result in loss of touch, vibration, and proprioception in the arm of the same side of the lesion.

 

function below the level of injury. The clue to solving this question is that the question mentions that the damage is to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception: This would be seen if the fasciculus gracilis was affected, which is responsible for carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb.

 

Option B. Absence of fine motor movement of fingers: This would be a result of damage to the corticospinal tract, which carries motor information.

 

Option D. Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception: Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column pathway, and it is affected ipsilaterally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract in the cervical spine region results in the loss of ipsilateral arm proprioception due to the involvement of the fasciculus cuneatus. This emphasizes the importance of the dorsal column in carrying proprioceptive and fine tactile information from the upper limbs.

 

Additional Information

 

Brown Sequard Syndrome (Hemi-sectioning of spinal cord)

 

  • I/L loss of Fine touch
  • C/L loss of Pain & Temperature
  • I/L loss of Proprioception
  • I/L motor paralysis

choices.text: Abortion leading to death of mother
Preventing the child from being born alive

questions.text: IPC Section 314 deals with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abortion leading to death of mother

 

ABORTION IPC’S = 312-316 IPC’S, 317 & 318

 

312 – 316 → Criminal Abortion

 

312 – Criminal abortion with consent of mother (BNS section 88)

 

313 – Criminal abortion without the consent of mother (BNS section 89)

 

314 – Death of mother during criminal abortion (BNS section 90)

 

315 - Preventing a live birth or causing a live born to die after birth (BNS section 91)

 

316 – Causing death of quick born, by a heinous act which could have led to death of mother (ex: - hit on abdomen of mother) (BNS section 92)

 

317 - Abandoning of a child by parents when child age is <12 years (BNS section 93)

 

318 - Concealing the birth of a newborn by secret disposal of dead body (BNS section 94)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC Section 314 deals specifically with the death of the mother during a criminal abortion.

questions.text: Which of the following would most likely lead to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Squatting

 

In hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the intensity of the murmur is influenced by the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. Various maneuvers and medications can affect this obstruction by altering preload (the volume of blood in the ventricles before contraction) or afterload (the resistance the heart must pump against).

 

Squatting increases preload by squeezing the peripheral veins and increasing venous return to the heart. This increase in preload reduces LVOT obstruction, thereby decreasing the murmur's intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Digoxin increases contractility. In HCM, increased contractility can worsen LVOT obstruction, thereby increasing the intensity of the murmur and worsening the murmur.

 

Option C. Valsalva: The Valsalva maneuver reduces preload by decreasing venous return to the heart. This reduction in preload can increase LVOT obstruction, leading to a louder murmur.

 

Option D. Furosemide: By reducing preload, furosemide increases LVOT obstruction and murmur intensity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing preload (e.g., through squatting) reduces LVOT obstruction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, leading to a decrease in the murmur's intensity.

questions.text: An infant is brought to OPD with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT reveals periventricular calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital cytomegalovirus infection

 

Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital rubella syndrome: Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections. Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles). Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

Option B. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option C. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periventricular calcifications on neuroimaging, along with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia, are characteristic of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

questions.text: A patient complains that he often gets troubled at night during sleep by tingling and numbness that involves his lateral three digits. He further explains that symptoms are relieved as he lays his arms hanging from the bed. Correct regarding the condition is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CTS: Durkan test

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is the entrapment of median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum
  • Clinical features:
    • 8 times more common in females
    • Usual age group is 50 years
    • Burning pain, paresthesia, tingling and numbness in median nerve distribution



       
    • Pain increased by activities, more troublesome at night; relieved by handing the arm over the side of bed or by shaking the arm
    • Clumsiness and weakness in tasks requiring fine manipulation
       
  • Special tests:
    • Sensory symptoms can be reproduced by percussion over the median nerve – Tinel’s sign
    • Sensory symptoms can also be reproduced by holding the wrist in full flexion for a minute – Phalen’s test/Reverse Phalen’s test

 

 

1. Phalen’s test; 2. Reverse Phalen’s test

 

  • The most specific test for carpal tunnel syndrome is Durkans test – Direct compression over the median nerve – best clinical test – done by holding wrist in slight flexion and directly compressing the nerve by applying pressure to proximal wrist crease for 30 seconds – development of pain, paresthesia or numbness indicates a positive test.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CTS: Froment sign. Froment’s sign is seen in cases of ulnar nerve palsy where the adductor pollicis is paralysed. The patient is made to hold a book between the thumb and the palm. In case of ulnar nerve palsy, the patient will hold the book using the flexor pollicis longus muscle, which will produce flexion at the IP joint.

 

 

This sign is specific of ulnar nerve palsy and will be negative in carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option C. Guyon canal syndrome: Froment sign. Guyon Canal syndrome, also known as Ulnar Tunnel Syndrome/ulnar tunnel syndrome/handlebar palsy, is a relatively rare peripheral ulnar neuropathy. It is defined as a compression of the distal ulnar nerve at the level of the wrist as it enters the hand through a space called ulnar tunnel or Guyon canal. The clinical presentation can be purely sensory, purely motor or both depending on the location of the nerve compression. Froment’s sign will be positive in this case.

 

Option D. Guyon canal syndrome: Durkan test. Durkan test is the most specific and sensitive for carpal tunnel syndrome only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given clinical symptoms of the patient suggest presence of carpal tunnel syndrome. The most specific test to check median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel is the Durkan’s Test.

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased

 

Explanation

 

This preterm baby who developed respiratory distress syndrome has surfactant deficiency. Due to which surface tension increases and compliance decreases.

 

Surfactant (Lecithin/Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl Choline) is produced by specialized cells called type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Surfactant molecules have a hydrophilic (water-attracting) head and a hydrophobic (water-repellent) tail. This unique structure allows surfactant to lower the surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveoli. It reduces the attractive forces between water molecules, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.

 

Compliance refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and recoil efficiently during breathing. Without surfactant, the surface tension within the alveoli would be high, making it difficult for the lungs to inflate during inspiration and causing them to collapse more readily during expiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm infants, especially those born before the lungs have matured at around 28 weeks, the lack of adequate surfactant leads to increased surface tension and decreased compliance, contributing to the development of respiratory distress syndrome.

choices.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is refractory period

questions.text: True statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Point B to D is refractory period

 

Explanation:

 

The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.

 

 

AT POINT 1 - Resting membrane potential: membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.

 

AT POINT 2 - Membrane depolarization: Na+ activation gate opens à Na+ flows inward.

 

AT POINT 3 - Membrane repolarization: Na+ inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K+ activation gate opens → K+ flows outward.

 

AT POINT 4 - Membrane hyperpolarization: K+ activation gates are slow to close → excess K+ efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na+ channels switch back to resting state. Na+/K+ pump restores ions concentration.

 

Point 2 to 4 is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.

 

The refractory period is divided into two, an absolute refractory period and a relative refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Threshold potential is reached just before point B where a rapid depolarization phase begins.

 

Option B: Incorrect. At point E, the nerve is not more excitable; rather, it is in a hyperpolarized state where more than the normal stimulus would be needed to generate another action potential.

 

Option C: Incorrect. The transition from C to D is characterized by the closing of Na+ channels and the opening of K+ channels, not the other way around.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phases of an action potential -

 

  • Point A: Represents the resting membrane potential.
  • Point B: Marks the threshold potential.

 

Point C: Represents the peak of the action potential.

 

  • Point D: Repolarization phase
  • Point E: Hyperpolarization phase
  • Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C
  • Relative refractory period from around point C to D

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient died, and his body was brought for post-mortem. The method of autopsy to be done is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rokitansky technique

 

Rokitansky Method-

 

  • In situ
  • Organs dissected inside the body
  • for highly infectious disease, e.g., HIV to prevent the spread of infection

 

 

 

Rokitansky Method

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ghon’s method (en block):

 

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks

 

 

Ghon’s Method

 

Option B. Letulle’s method (En masse)

 

  • Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • Best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other                         
  • Disadvantage: difficult to handle large mass.

 

       

Letulle’s Method

 

Option C. Virchow’s method

 

  • Each and every organ is removed one by one (e.g., each lung, each kidney, heart separately)
  • Relations of organs are not preserved
  • Most commonly used technique (easier to perform)

 

 

Virchow’s Method

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rokitansky technique involves dissecting organs in situ and is the preferred method for highly infectious diseases like HIV to prevent the spread of infection.

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

 

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

 

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

 

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

 

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.
