A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.

 

Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: Which of the following are vitamin K dependent factors requiring gamma carboxylation? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 7, 9, 10

 

Vitamin K is essential for the post-translational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. This modification is gamma carboxylation, which allows these proteins to bind calcium ions and participate effectively in the coagulation cascade.

 

Vitamin K Dependent Factors:

 

  • Procoagulants: Factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X.
  • Anticoagulants: Protein C and Protein S.

 

These factors are synthesized in the liver and require gamma carboxylation of specific glutamic acid residues for their activity. Without this modification, they cannot bind calcium effectively, which is necessary for their role in coagulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K dependent factors are procoagulants (factors 2,7,9,10) and anticoagulants (protein C and S). They require gamma carboxylation for their activity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with complaints of confusion and ataxia. Upon examination, nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wernicke's Encephalopathy

 

The presentation of a 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use, who is experiencing confusion, ataxia, nystagmus, and sixth nerve palsy, is highly suggestive of Wernicke's Encephalopathy. This is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the classic triad of confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (such as nystagmus and cranial nerve palsies), and ataxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Korsakoff Syndrome: This is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome that often follows Wernicke's Encephalopathy. It is characterized by severe memory impairment, confabulation, and behavioral changes but lacks the acute neurological symptoms such as nystagmus and ataxia seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Delirium Tremens: This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by delirium, tremors, agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic instability. While confusion is common, the specific neurological findings of nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy are more indicative of Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. De Clerambault Syndrome: Also known as erotomania, this is a delusional disorder characterized by the belief that another person is in love with the individual. It is unrelated to the symptoms presented in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcohol use due to poor nutritional intake and absorption. Treatment include high dose of parenteral thiamine. Ophthalmoplegia responds first to the treatment, ataxia doesnt improve completely in almost 50% of cases.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: A patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide, having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding jejunostomy

 

  • Since the patient is in complete dysphagia, a feeding jejunostomy is the next best step.

 

CAUSTIC INJURY

 

Most common in children or people with psychiatric illness

 

Alkali poison – liquefactive necrosis

 

Management – Emergency → stabilise the patient

 

  • Endoscopy to assess the injury
  • No perforation – conservative management + feeding by NG feed / NJ feed / gastrostomy or jejunostomy
  • Serial endoscopic assessment – usually after 3-6 months → elective reconstruction → esophagectomy + conduit (gastric / colonic)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophago-jejunostomy : Esophago-jejunostomy is avoided in acute setting.

 

Option B. Stent placement: Esophageal stenting may not be useful if injury extends to stomach.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy: Procedures on stomach are avoided until extent of injury is assessed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with complete dysphagia following the ingestion of a strong alkali like sodium hydroxide, the best immediate management step is the insertion of a feeding jejunostomy to provide nutritional support while assessing and stabilizing the patient.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. Blood investigations reveal total leucocyte count to be >50,000 cells/L. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

 

Neonate with complaints of paroxysm of cough followed by apnea and leucocytosis (>50,000 cells/ L) points to diagnosis of pertussis, for which DOC is Macrolides, i.e., Azithromycin.

 

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

 

A well appearing young child begins to choke, gasp and flail the extremities with face reddened. Apnea and cyanosis may follow the coughing.

 

 

Infants < 3 months do not display the classic stages of whooping cough. Catarrhal phase is usually unnoticed.

 

Treatment – Macrolides

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is not effective against Bordetella pertussis and is not used for the treatment of pertussis.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is an alternative treatment for pertussis in patients who cannot tolerate macrolides but is not the first-line therapy.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: This antibiotic is not typically used for the treatment of pertussis and is not considered the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants presenting with pertussis (whooping cough), characterized by paroxysmal cough and elevated leukocyte count, the drug of choice is azithromycin.

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

 

The patient with given complaints points to meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae and it exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus colonies. When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus.

 

H. influenzae can grow on blood agar if the source of V factor is provided

 

When S. aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, then factor V is released from S. aureus.

 

It forms larger colonies adjacent to S. aureus streak line and size of the colonies decreases gradually away from the S. aureus streak line, this is known as Satellitism. Therefore, used for the isolation of H. influenzae.

 

 

 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

 

  1. Factor X = hemin→ present freely in blood
  2. Factor V = Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) →present inside RBCs (also produced by some bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus)

 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and less commonly suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis.

 

DOC - Cefotaxime or ceftazidime

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bacitracin sensitive: Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes, a Gram positive coccus.

 

Option B. Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar: Associated with organisms such as Shigella, Salmonella, and Proteus species.

 

Option D. It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar: Alpha-hemolysis on blood agar is a characteristic of Streptococcus pneumonia, a gram-positive coccus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Haemophilus influenzae infection, particularly meningitis, look for satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar, indicating the organism's dependence on externally sourced V factor for growth.

questions.text: A 4-year-old patient presented with a rectal mass 2.5 cm by 3 cm. On biopsy it had the presence of colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells.  Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hamartoma

 

The clinical history of a rectal mass on biopsy having the colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is suggestive of a juvenile polyp. This polyp is an example of a hamartomatous polyp.     

 

Hamartoma:

 

  • Definition: A hamartoma is a benign, focal malformation that resembles a neoplasm but grows at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. It is composed of an abnormal mixture of tissue elements that are normally found at that site.
  • Juvenile Polyp: A type of hamartomatous polyp commonly found in children. It is characterized by the presence of dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells, as described in the biopsy findings.
  • Clinical Presentation: Typically presents as a solitary rectal polyp in young children, often causing painless rectal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choristoma: A benign growth of normal tissue in an abnormal location, not consistent with the described biopsy findings.

 

Option C. Adenoma: A benign neoplasm of glandular tissue, typically presenting with dysplastic changes, not the dilated glands with mucin and inflammatory cells.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: A malignant tumor of glandular origin, which would show invasive growth and cellular atypia, not consistent with the benign nature of the findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A rectal mass in a young child with biopsy findings of colonic mucosa and multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is indicative of a juvenile polyp, which is a type of hamartomatous polyp.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presented to OBG department at 36 weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasound shows that the fetus is in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no gross anomaly. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

 

In this situation, external cephalic version should be attempted.

 

Management of Transverse lie –

 

 

Absolute Contraindications of ECV:

 

  • Placenta Previa
  • Contracted Pelvis
  • Multiple Pregnancy
  • Hyperextended head
  • Uterine Anomaly
  • Dead fetus
  • Distressed fetus
  • Denied consent

 

Complications of ECV:

 

  • Abruption
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Preterm labour.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Cord presentation or prolapse
  • Entangling of the cord around the fetus.
  • Isoimmunization in Rh-negative mothers due to feto-maternal transfusion.
  • Induction of labor is contraindicated in Transverse lie.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: While a cesarean section is the best and safest method of delivery in cases of persistent transverse or oblique lie, it is not the first-line management in this situation where ECV can be attempted.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Waiting for spontaneous correction is not recommended at 36 weeks with a transverse lie, as it may not occur, and could lead to complications.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Inducing labor in a transverse lie position is contraindicated as it can lead to complications such as cord prolapse and obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External cephalic version should be attempted between 36 and 37 weeks of gestation for a fetus in a transverse lie if there are no contraindications.

questions.text: A student got his jaw locked while yawning. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral pterygoid

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid.

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads: superior (or upper) and inferior (or lower). The superior head attaches to the articular disc and the capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This muscle plays a crucial role in the opening of the mouth, protrusion of the mandible, and moving the jaw from side to side. Dysfunction or spasms of this muscle could contribute to jaw locking during yawning. The lateral pterygoid is, therefore, closely associated with the movements and function of the TMJ.

 

All Innervated by CN V3

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temporalis: The temporalis muscle originates from the temporal fossa and inserts onto the coronoid process of the mandible. It's primarily responsible for closing the mouth and is involved in elevating and retracting the mandible. It does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ, but it plays a role in jaw movement.

 

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is similar in function to the masseter muscle and helps in elevating the mandible, thus assisting in closing the mouth. It also plays a role in moving the jaw from side to side. However, like the temporalis, it doesn't directly attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Option D. Masseter: The masseter muscle is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing). It originates from the zygomatic arch and inserts onto the lateral aspect of the mandibular angle and ramus. Its primary function is to elevate the mandible, assisting in closing the mouth. It does not have an attachment to the articular disc of the TMJ but is important for jaw function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle, particularly its superior head, is uniquely attached to the TMJ's articular disc and plays a pivotal role in jaw movements including mouth opening and lateral movements, making it relevant in cases of jaw locking.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grey

 

The patient presents with erosions on the cervix, which is indicative of cervicitis. According to the syndromic management guidelines for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), cervicitis is treated with the Grey Kit (Kit 1).

 

Educational Objective:  

 

STI color coded kits:

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

 

The triad of Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL) points to a diagnosis of Congenital rubella syndrome

 

Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections.

 

Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles)

 

Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option B. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Option C. Congenital cytomegalovirus infection: Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), cataract, and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. He has a retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise.  There is no mucosal bleeding in the patient. Which of the following coagulation factor can be responsible for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor 8/9 deficiency

 

The presence of recurrent deep tissue bleeding (retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise) in a male is suggestive of a clotting factor deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand factor deficiency: Typically presents with mucosal bleeding and prolonged bleeding time, not deep tissue bleeding as described.

 

Option C. Lupus anticoagulant: Usually associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to a paradoxical increase in thrombosis rather than bleeding.

 

Option D. Factor 9/12 deficiency: Factor XII deficiency does not cause significant bleeding and is usually discovered incidentally with prolonged aPTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia, caused by deficiencies in factors VIII or IX, presents with recurrent deep tissue bleeding and hemarthrosis, without significant mucosal bleeding. This differentiates it from other bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked 1 in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fossa of Rosenmuller

 

 

The image represented is the endoscopic view of lateral wall of the nasopharynx. Structure marked 1 is Fossa of Rosenmüller.

1 - FOSSA OF ROSENMULLER

2 - TORUS TUBARIUS

3 - POSTERIOR PHARYNGEAL WALL

4 - EUSTACHIAN TUBE OPENING

Lateral wall of nasopharynx contains Eustachian tube opening in the form of a bulge called torus tubarius and fossa of Rosenmüller lies behind this elevation (most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma)

 

The tubal tonsil is a small lymphoid tissue located at the tubal elevation near the opening of the eustachian tube.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubal Tonsil: Lymphoid tissue near the opening of the Eustachian tube but not visible as marked in this image.

 

Option C. Opening of Eustachian Tube: Located anterior to the Fossa of Rosenmuller, usually at the torus tubarius, not visible in the marked area.

 

Option D. Adenoid: Lymphoid tissue located on the posterior wall of the nasopharynx, not in the lateral wall and thus not visible in this specific view.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fossa of Rosenmuller's familiarity is essential in nasopharyngeal examinations, especially in the context of identifying potential sites for nasopharyngeal carcinoma or other pathologies. Its recognition during endoscopy guides thorough inspection and appropriate clinical interventions.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Target cell: can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the post splenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme.

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells:  are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells are seen in hairy cell leukemia, characterized by B lymphocytes with hair-like projections, and are identified using electron microscopy and specific markers like CD11c, CD25, CD103, and Annexin-A.

questions.text: Name the drug that acts on both the marked points: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omapatrilat

 

Omapatrilat is a inhibits both neprilysin and Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). As a result, there is a decrease in Angiotensin II and increase in natriuretic peptide levels, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sacubitril: Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin reducing breakdown of vasoactive peptides such as natriuretic peptides and bradykinin, therefore increasing their levels leading to vasodilation, diuresis, and counteracting the effects of RAAS. Sacubitril is combined with an ARB, valsartan is indicated for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Option C. Losartan: Losartan is classified under angiotensin receptor blocker, used in the treatment of hypertension. A/E are Hyperkalemia, Dysgeusia, Postural hypotension. C/I in pregnancy, B/L Renal Artery Stenosis. Losartan decreases serum uric acid levels.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a synthetic brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), acts as a natriuretic and vasodilator. Primarily used in acute decompensated heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omapatrilat inhibits both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme, thereby decreasing angiotensin II and increasing natriuretic peptides, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation.

choices.text: Genital Tuberculosis

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in the perineal area, difficulty in walking and sitting. She has a history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, a tender swelling is seen with redness on the labia, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bartholin abscess

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and image points to the diagnosis of Bartholin's abscess.

 

Bartholin Cyst and Abscess

 

Bartholin gland is a mucus-secreting gland, which plays a role in vaginal lubrication. They are a pair of 0.5 cm glands located in the lower right and left portions at the 4 o’clock and 8 o’clock positions of the vaginal introitus. They are generally nonpalpable when not obstructed.

 

Pathophysiology: Bartholin glands can form a cyst and an abscess in women of reproductive age and may cause dyspareunia, urinary irritation, and vague pelvic pain.

 

C/F:

 

  • The physical exam will often reveal asymmetry with a protrusion of one side (left or right) of the inferior aspect of the vulva.
  • Bartholin gland abscesses, unlike Bartholin cysts, are very painful.
  • While both are primarily unilateral, Bartholin abscesses are often tender to palpation, erythematous, indurated, and may have an area of fluctuance and/or purulent drainage.
  • Treatment
  • Asymptomatic Bartholin cysts do not require further treatment.
  • Bartholin abscesses may be treated with incision and drainage with Word catheter placement due to ease and effectiveness of treatment.
  • Marsupialization is the procedure of choice.
  • Women with recurrent cysts or those who are post-menopausal (risk of malignancy) should have the cyst completely excised.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Chlamydial infection: Chlamydial infection patient usually present with vaginal discharge, dysuria, or cervicitis.

 

Option C. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis involves the upper genital tract, leading to menstrual irregularities, infertility, and abdominal pain.

 

Option D. Genital herpes: Genital herpes usually presents as painful ulcers or vesicles in the genital area, rather than a tender, erythematous swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Bartholin abscess presents with significant pain, redness, and swelling in the labia, often making walking and sitting difficult.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with abdominal pain, jaundice and weight loss. He has hypoglycemia and elevated alpha fetoprotein levels (250IU) but has normal AST and ALT. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis of the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

A history of chronic alcohol intake with abdominal pain, jaundice and weight loss is suggestive of a liver dysfunction.  

 

 

Other Options:

 

Differential Diagnosis:

 

Option A. Liver cirrhosis: Often has elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT) and may present with similar symptoms but is not typically associated with high AFP levels.

 

Option B. Hepatitis: Would show elevated AST and ALT levels, ruling out this option.

 

Option D. Cholangiocarcinoma: May present with jaundice and weight loss but is not typically associated with elevated AFP levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma should be considered in a chronic alcoholic presenting with abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss, hypoglycemia, and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels, especially with normal AST and ALT levels.

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane represented below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Facilitated diffusion

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the process of facilitated diffusion. This type of transport involves the use of carrier proteins embedded in the cell membrane to help molecules that cannot readily diffuse through the lipid bilayer move across the membrane, down their concentration gradient, without the expenditure of cellular energy (ATP).

 

  • Facilitated Diffusion: This process helps molecules move from an area of higher concentration to one of lower concentration via specific carrier proteins. It is a passive transport method since it does not require energy from ATP but relies on the concentration gradient.
  • Carrier Proteins: These proteins undergo a change in shape to transport molecules across the membrane. They are specific to the substances they transport, ensuring selective and regulated transport into and out of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple Diffusion: Involves the movement of molecules directly through the phospholipid bilayer without the assistance of membrane proteins, driven solely by their concentration gradient.

 

Option C. Primary Active Transport: Requires ATP to move substances against their concentration gradient via pumps.

 

Option D. Secondary Active Transport: Also known as co-transport, uses the gradient of one molecule to move another molecule against its gradient, indirectly using energy but not directly using ATP.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 x 10^5 IU/mL and ALT is found to be doubled. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tenofovir

 

The patient is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B, as indicated by the positive HBsAg and HBeAg, which are markers of infection and infectivity, respectively. The viral load of 2 x 105 IU/mL and elevated ALT levels suggest active viral replication and liver inflammation.

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This is a marker of infection. Its presence indicates that the person is infectious.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): This is a marker of infectivity. It indicates that the virus is replicating and the patient is highly infectious.

 

HBV DNA: This is a marker of viral replication. In chronic hepatitis B, a high level of HBV DNA correlates with an increased risk of complications such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

The decision to start treatment in chronic hepatitis B is primarily based on the levels of HBV DNA and ALT. According to guidelines, treatment is indicated if:

 

  1. HBV DNA is more than 2000 IU/mL.
  2. ALT is elevated (more than 2 to 3 times the upper limit of normal).

 

In this patient, both criteria are met.

 

Tenofovir is preferred for its efficacy and lower risk of resistance compared to other options like lamivudine. Tenofovir is also favored over interferon-based therapies due to better durability of response and lower side effect profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamivudine: This drug is no longer preferred due to a high risk of resistance.

 

Option C. Peg IFN for 52 weeks: Pegylated interferon is not preferred due to less favorable response rates and a higher side effect profile compared to tenofovir.

 

Option D. Combined peg IFN with lamivudine: Combination therapy with pegylated interferon and lamivudine is not recommended due to increased side effects and no significant improvement in efficacy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tenofovir is the preferred treatment for chronic hepatitis B with high viral load and elevated ALT levels due to its efficacy and lower risk of resistance.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of a migraine, which is often associated with unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound).

 

Sumatriptan: This medication is a serotonin receptor agonist (triptan) used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks. It works by stimulating serotonin (5-HT) receptors in the brain, leading to vasoconstriction of dilated blood vessels and relief from migraine symptoms.

 

The best drug for acute management of a migraine attack in this scenario is Sumatriptan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: This is a calcium channel blocker used for the prophylactic treatment of migraine, not for acute management.

 

Option C. Propranolol: This beta-blocker is also used for migraine prophylaxis, not for acute attacks.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Used for preventing migraine, not for treating an acute attack.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the best medication for the acute management of migraine, characterized by unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions as shown in the image. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis

 

In this case, the patient presents with persistent cough, weight loss, and skin lesions. The chest x-ray reveals multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates, and the patient has a low CD4 count. These findings are significant for several reasons:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis can mimic tuberculosis, especially in HIV-positive patients. It causes disseminated disease with pulmonary involvement (multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates) and skin lesions. The presence of these lesions and a negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis further supports histoplasmosis, as this fungal infection is common in immunocompromised individuals with low CD4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis: While cryptococcosis can cause lung disease, it more commonly presents with central nervous system involvement, such as meningitis or meningoencephalitis. This patient does not exhibit neurological symptoms, making cryptococcosis less likely.

 

Option C. HIV with molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum causes umbilicated papules but does not lead to bilateral nodular infiltrates in the lungs. Thus, this diagnosis is unlikely given the chest x-ray findings.

 

Option D. HIV with tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is a common infection in HIV-positive patients and can present with similar symptoms and radiographic findings. However, the negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis in HIV-positive patients can mimic tuberculosis, presenting with pulmonary nodular infiltrates and skin lesions, especially in those with low CD4 counts.

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the given condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

 

  • The image depicts necrotizing fasciitis of the abdominal wall, also known as Meleney's gangrene.
  • This condition is a severe soft tissue infection characterized by rapidly spreading inflammation and necrosis.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been shown to have some benefit in managing this condition.

 

Meleney's Gangrene (Necrotizing Fasciitis)

 

  • Clinical Features: Signs of local inflammation, skin gangrene, and features of septicemia such as hypotension and fever.
  • Investigation: Culture swab tests usually reveal aerobes (such as beta-hemolytic Streptococci) and anaerobes, making the condition often polymicrobial.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical: Radical wide debridement is necessary and may need to be repeated every 24-48 hours to manage the infection effectively.
    • Medical: Intravenous antibiotics are critical to treating the infection.
    • Adjunctive Therapy: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has some benefits and is used as an adjunct in the management of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition: True: Radical wide debridement is often needed repeatedly (every 24-48 hours) to control the spread of the infection and remove necrotic tissue.

 

Option B. This is a case of Meleney's gangrene: True: The condition shown in the image is Meleney's gangrene, a specific form of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Option C. The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial: True: The infection can be caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococci and is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meleney's gangrene, or necrotizing fasciitis, requires aggressive surgical debridement, intravenous antibiotics, and may benefit from adjunctive hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • The condition is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

H/O consumption of a fruit, high fever, confusion, photophobia, unable to urinate are anticholinergic symptoms. Photophobia occurs due to mydriasis in anticholinergic poisoning.

 

Datura poisoning:

 

Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.

 

Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.

 

Features of Datura poisoning:

 

 D's of Datura

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death

 

Datura Flowers: Flowers are large tubular (trumpet-shaped) which may be white (alba) or purple (Niger)

 

Datura Fruit capsule: It is spherical with soft spines and contains 50 to 100 dark brown reniform (kidney-shaped) seeds which bear a superficial resemblance to chilly seeds

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning: Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug, physostigmine [Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity]

 

Below image shows Datura Flower and Datura Fruit

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. While Datura is the correct causative agent, Pralidoxime is not the correct antidote. Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, not anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. Yellow oleander poisoning presents primarily with symptoms of cardiac toxicity, such as arrhythmias and heart failure, not the anticholinergic symptoms described in the question. Additionally, Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Incorrect. Again, Yellow oleander would cause symptoms related to cardiac toxicity rather than the anticholinergic symptoms presented. Physostigmine is not the antidote for Yellow oleander poisoning.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • Types:
  1. Nerium odorum (White Oleander): Bears white, dark red or pink flowers
  2. Cerbera thevetia (Yellow Oleander): Bears yellow bell-shaped flowers, globular fruits

 

 

  • Symptoms: In both oleanders there will symptoms of heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse) and muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning. They are similar to digitalis causing death from cardiac failure.
  • Treatment:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine is useful in the management of ventricular tachyarrhythmias, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and bigeminy.
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies (digoxin-specific Fab fragments) are the treatment of choice for severe bradyarrhythmia’s with hypotension unresponsive to atropine and life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias.

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text:
A 8-year-old child weighing 26 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)

 

RBS → 550

рН → 7.01

Na+ → 158

Urine glucose → 3+

Urine Ketone → +ve
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis

 

According to the ISPAD guidelines shown below, first the patient has to be classified for shock/Moderate dehydration/minimal dehydration. In this given scenario, child is in shock, so, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC) and fluid replacement along with an IV bolus of 20 mL/kg 0.9% Normal saline, followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.05 - 0.1 U/kg/hr, 1 hour after starting fluid replacement therapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr.: First we will give fluids and then after one hour we will give insulin

 

Option C. Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr: The fluid volume of 10 mL/kg is insufficient for severe dehydration and shock. The correct volume is 20 mL/kg.

 

Option D. Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour: This option provides an insufficient fluid volume and delays insulin administration, which is not recommended in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in children, the initial treatment includes managing ABC, administering 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline, and starting an insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr.

choices.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice
Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. Investigations showed the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

 

  • The given CT image shows a cyst in the liver is suggestive of hydatid disease with floating membrane sign.
  • Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly called the dog tapeworm.
  • MC site of hydatid cyst in human: liver (MC) followed by pulmonary hydatids (2nd MC)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgery is mandatory: Surgical treatment of hydatid cyst indicated when PAIR is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic: FNAC is contra-indicated as rupture of cyst may lead to spillage or anaphylaxis.

 

Option C. Angioembolization is the treatment of choice:  Angioembolization has no role in the management of hydatid cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT.
  •  The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible.
  •  FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling below the left earlobe and is experiencing pain. What is the most likely cause of this pain? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Greater auricular nerve

 

The greater auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that supplies the skin of the external ear, the area over the parotid gland, and the angle of the mandible. It is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically arising from the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3. Any acute inflammation of the gland such as acute sialadenitis results in pain in the preauricular region. The pain is mainly due to stretching of the capsule resulting in stimulation of the greater auricular nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) traverses through the parotid gland but does not innervate it. Instead, it provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression. Damage to the facial nerve may lead to facial paralysis or weakness, but it's not directly responsible for sensation or pain below the earlobe.

 

Option B. Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: This is a layer of connective tissue that envelops the neck and extends into the face. It surrounds several structures, including the parotid gland. While the fascia itself isn't directly responsible for sensation, inflammation or infections that cause stretching of this fascia might contribute to discomfort.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal nerve: This is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin above the parotid gland, the external ear, and the external auditory canal. Though it provides sensation to the aforementioned areas, the region described in the scenario (below the earlobe) is not primarily innervated by the auriculotemporal nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Greater auricular nerve originates from the cervical plexus, specifically from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves. It ascends to the parotid gland and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the earlobe, and the area behind the ear, so the greater auricular nerve is most directly responsible for transmitting pain sensations from these regions.

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the given spirometry graph?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

The marked area in the spirometry graph indicates the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC). FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation. This is not fully expelled during a standard tidal cycle and represents the air that remains in the lungs to keep them inflated.

 

  • FRC Components:
    • FRC includes the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) plus the Residual Volume (RV).
    • ERV is the additional air that can be forcibly exhaled after the end of a normal, calm exhalation.
    • RV is the volume of air still remaining in the lungs after the most forceful exhalation, which cannot be voluntarily expelled.

 

 

Significance in Spirometry:

 

In spirometry:

 

  • FRC is critical for maintaining the alveolar inflation and preventing the airways from collapsing.
  • It is not directly measurable by simple spirometry because it includes the residual volume. Techniques such as body plethysmography or using tracer gas dilution methods are usually employed to measure FRC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tidal Volume (TV or VT): This is the volume of air inhaled or exhaled during a normal breathing cycle, not indicated in this context.

 

Option C. Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): Part of FRC, this is the maximum volume of air that can be voluntarily expelled after the end of a normal, passive exhalation.

 

Option D. Expiratory Capacity: It is the total amount of air that can be expired from the lungs after a maximal inhalation, typically including the tidal volume plus the expiratory reserve volume, not specifically marked here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration and is essential for preventing lung collapse and maintaining pulmonary function, especially during physical activities or respiratory challenges. Understanding FRC's role helps in assessing lung health and diagnosing potential respiratory disorders.

questions.text: A patient with a malignancy is undergoing chemotherapy. The platelet counts were reduced after the previous cycle of chemotherapy. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oprelvekin (IL-11)

 

Oprelvekin (IL-11) is a recombinant form of interleukin-11, which is used to prevent severe thrombocytopenia and reduce the need for platelet transfusions following myelosuppressive chemotherapy in patients with non-myeloid malignancies. Oprelvekin works by stimulating the proliferation and maturation of megakaryocytes, the precursor cells to platelets, thereby increasing platelet counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Filgrastim: Filgrastim is a granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF), used in treatment of neutropenia post-chemotherapy.

 

Option C. Erythropoietin: Erythropoietin like Darbepoetin is indicated in Anemia due to chronic kidney disease and bone marrow suppression.

 

Option D. Amifostine: Amifostine is indicated in cisplatin induced nephrotoxicity

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oprelvekin (IL-11) is the drug of choice for managing chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia by increasing platelet counts, thereby reducing the need for platelet transfusions in patients undergoing myelosuppressive chemotherapy.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

 

  • This patient most likely has a bleeding peptic ulcer.
  •  Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) includes both gastric and duodenal ulcers.
  •  Aspirin, an NSAID, interferes with the protective role of prostaglandins on the gastric and duodenal mucosa, increasing the risk of peptic ulcer formation in the stomach and the duodenum.
  •  Common presentations of peptic ulcers include pain in the epigastrium, bleeding, and vomiting.
  • The history of aspirin use and alcohol consumption further supports the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.

 

Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)

 

  • Etiology: Helicobacter pylori infection and NSAID use.
  • Mechanism: NSAIDs like aspirin disrupt the protective mucosal layer, leading to ulcer formation.
  • Symptoms: Epigastric pain, hematemesis, melena.
  • Sequelae:
    • Bleeding (more common in duodenal ulcers)
    • Perforation leading to peritonitis
    • Stricture causing gastric outlet obstruction
    • Malignancy risk (only in gastric ulcers)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss:

 

  • Occurs following repeated vomiting or retching, often associated with an alcoholic binge.
  • Characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Presents with self-limiting hematemesis, not usually profuse.

 

Option B. Esophagitis:

 

  • Inflammation of the esophagus, often due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Results in chronic blood loss and commonly presents as anemia rather than sudden hematemesis.
  • Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia.

 

Option D. Esophageal varices:

 

  • Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus, often due to portal hypertension.
  • Common in patients with liver cirrhosis.
  • Presents with massive hematemesis, splenomegaly, and ascites, none of which are described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne’s negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-45 dB

 

The given clinical scenario of hearing loss with a negative Rinne at 256 Hz and 512 Hz and positive Rinne at 1024 Hz indicates air conduction and bone conduction gap of 30-45 dB.

 

  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz tuning fork (TF) but positive for 512Hz tuning fork → approximate hearing loss will be 20-30dB.
  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz & 512Hz TF but positive for 1024Hz TF → approximate hearing loss will be 30–45dB
  • Rinne’s negative for all 256Hz, 512Hz & 1024Hz → approximate hearing loss will be 45-60dB.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female presents to OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaints of bleeding per vagina and mild abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. On investigation, mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

 

The clinical scenario presented indicates an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. The patient is hemodynamically stable, and the hCG level is 2800 IU/L with an adnexal mass measuring 3 x 2 cm. These findings meet the criteria for medical management of an ectopic pregnancy with methotrexate. Single-dose methotrexate injection is an appropriate treatment choice for an unruptured ectopic pregnancy when the patient is stable, has no significant symptoms, and the gestational sac is less than 3.5 cm in size without visible cardiac activity. Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis and cell replication, effectively treating the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral methotrexate: Oral methotrexate is not a standard treatment protocol for ectopic pregnancy. Methotrexate for ectopic pregnancy is typically administered via injection to ensure proper dosage and effectiveness.

 

Option C. Serial methotrexate + leucovorin rescue: This multidose protocol is used for ectopic pregnancies with higher hCG levels or when the single-dose protocol is contraindicated or has failed. However, it is more complex and involves multiple injections and monitoring.

 

Option D. Salpingectomy: Surgical management, such as salpingectomy, is indicated for ectopic pregnancies with significant pain, adnexal masses larger than 35 mm, visible fetal heartbeat, or serum hCG levels of 5000 IU/L or more. In this case, the patient’s condition does not meet these criteria, making surgery unnecessary.

 

Management of Unruptured Ectopic

 

 

Surgical Management in Unruptured Ectopic –

 

Indicated in:

 

  1. an ectopic pregnancy and significant pain
  2. an ectopic pregnancy with an adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger
  3. an ectopic pregnancy with a fetal heartbeat visible on an ultrasound scan
  4. an ectopic pregnancy and a serum hCG level of 5,000 IU/L or more

 

 Laparoscopy is preferred

 

  1. SALPINGECTOMY: Preferred if:
    • Extensive tubal involvement/ damage
    • Recurrent ectopic pregnancy in the same tube
    • Completed family
    • Ectopic at the site of a previous tubal sterilization
  2. SALPINGOSTOMY: (Linear incision on the antimesenteric border with removal of products of conception) Done if a woman wants to conceive in the future.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy in a hemodynamically stable patient with an hCG level less than 5000 IU/L and an adnexal mass smaller than 3.5 cm is typically treated with a single-dose methotrexate injection.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. Mark the correct biochemical changes which will be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urate and lactate levels

 

This patient with chronic alcoholism and gouty arthritis will most likely have elevated levels of lactate and urate.

 

The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by alcohol dehydrogenase is accompanied by the reduction of NAD+ to NADH. This results in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio (Hence ruled out Option A).

 

 

Due to this, the following metabolic reactions which require NAD+ are inhibited:

  1. Glycolysis
  2. Citric acid cycle (ketogenesis favoured)
  3. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  4. Fatty acid oxidation

 

This decreased fatty acid oxidation leads to increased esterification and production of triacylglycerol, which causes fatty liver.

In addition to this, there is an increase in two reactions:

  • Pyruvate to lactate
  • Oxaloacetate to malate

 

Increased lactate leads to hyper-lactic-acidemia, which leads to increased renal reabsorption of urate and decreased excretion of uric acid. This results in aggravation of gout.

 

Alcoholics are deficient in thiamine which inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase and these all leads to lactic acidosis.

 

A decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis, leads to a decrease in blood glucose levels, causing symptoms of agitation, impaired judgement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio: This is incorrect as the NADH/NAD+ ratio is actually increased due to the metabolism of ethanol.

 

Option B: Increased urea and urate levels are not specifically associated with alcoholism and gouty arthritis. But urate levels may be increased due to gout, urea levels are not directly related to the condition.

 

Option D: Increased levels of alkaline phosphatase can be seen in alcohol-induced hepatitis due to intrahepatic cholestasis but is not directly related to gouty arthritis in a chronic alcoholic patient. Therefore, this option is less relevant compared to increased rate and lactate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diltiazem

 

In a patient with atrial fibrillation and bronchial asthma, the primary goal is to control the heart rate. For rate control in atrial fibrillation, beta-blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (NDCCBs) like diltiazem or verapamil are commonly used. However, in this case, the patient has bronchial asthma, which makes the use of beta-blockers (such as propranolol and esmolol) less suitable due to their potential to exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Diltiazem is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that effectively controls the heart rate without affecting bronchial muscle tone, making it a safer option for patients with asthma. Therefore, diltiazem is the drug of choice for immediate management in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker, which can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Thus, it is not a suitable choice for patients with asthma.

 

Option C. Esmolol: Similar to propranolol, esmolol is a beta-blocker and can worsen asthma symptoms due to its bronchoconstrictive effects, making it unsuitable for this patient.

 

Option D. Propylthiouracil: This medication is used in the management of thyroid storm, a condition associated with severe hyperthyroidism. It is not relevant for rate control in atrial fibrillation and does not address the immediate needs of this patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate rate control in atrial fibrillation in a patient with bronchial asthma, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like diltiazem are preferred over beta-blockers to avoid exacerbating asthma symptoms.

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.text: During resuscitation, when is the given position? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present

 

This is the recovery position, indicated in post-op patients who are awake or drowsy or unconscious with pulse and breathing present to prevent aspiration of any secretions or vomit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent: Means the patient is in cardiac arrest and requires immediate resuscitation measures.

 

Option B. Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent: This is respiratory arrest and rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to maintain breathing of patient.

 

Option D. Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present: This seems very theoretical because with a lack of circulation, breathing isn’t feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for an unconscious patient who has a pulse and is breathing to prevent aspiration and maintain airway patency.

questions.text: A patient has Bilateral right sided loss of vision. What is the most likely site of lesion. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

Given the description of "Bilateral right sided loss of vision," the most likely site of the lesion would be the  Left optic tract. This type of visual field loss is consistent with the right visual field information being interrupted after the optic chiasma, which would affect the right visual field in both eyes.The optic tracts carry visual information after it has crossed at the optic chiasma. A lesion in the left optic tract would lead to a loss of vision in the right visual field of both eyes (homonymous hemianopia). This is because the left optic tract carries information from the right half of the visual field of each eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Optic Tract: Similarly, a lesion in the right optic tract would cause a loss of vision in the left visual field of both eyes. This is also homonymous hemianopia, but on the opposite side of the visual field loss compared to a left optic tract lesion.

 

Option C. Optic Chiasma: A lesion at the optic chiasma can cause various types of visual field defects. The most common is bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes. This typically occurs with pituitary tumors that compress the chiasma from below.

 

Option D. Optic Radiation: The optic radiation carries visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex. A lesion in the optic radiation can also lead to homonymous hemianopia. The specific location within the optic radiation (e.g., Meyer's loop) can lead to more specific deficits like a superior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the visual pathway is critical for localizing lesions based on patterns of visual field loss. Lesions at different points along the visual pathway (e.g., optic nerves, chiasma, tracts, or radiations) will produce characteristic visual field defects. This knowledge is used to guide further diagnostic testing and management, which may include imaging studies like MRI or CT scans to visualize the lesion and determine its cause.

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute
Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination, especially during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to follow proper procedures to avoid contamination and ensure the sample's accuracy. The best practice is to collect water from a gentle stream to avoid splashing, which can introduce contaminants from the environment into the sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collect water from already leaking tape: Not recommended as it could contaminate the sample and may lead to false results.

 

Option B. Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute: Before collecting, let water flow for at least 2 minutes

 

Option C. Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage: It is a good practice but this practice alone does not ensure the proper collection of the sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing and potential contamination. This practice ensures the accuracy and reliability of the water sample.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

 

  • Pathology – Remnant of thyroglossal duct
  • Most common site – midline à Subhyoid
  • C/F – Presents in 2nd /3rd decade of life as midline neck swelling which moves up on tongue protrusion and on deglutition.
  • Treatment - Sistrunk’s operation
  • Long standing thyroglossal cyst has a risk of papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Failure of obliteration of branchial cleft. Cystic swelling (soft)- typically in a teenager. Swelling at upper 1/3rd + middle 1/3rd junction of sternocleidomastoid.

 

 

Option C. Plunging ranula: Presents as Swelling in floor of mouth, Fluctuation present, Brilliant transillumination.

 

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Caused when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst, which is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • The treatment is typically surgical removal via the Sistrunk procedure.

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?(NEET  PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

questions.text: A 3-year-old child brought to the OPD with fever and a rash spreading from the face, behind cheeks, and buccal mucosa to other body parts. On examination, Koplik's spot is present. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Measles/Rubeola

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: The rash of rubella is similar in distribution to that of measles (rubeola) but it is less intensely red and confluent. Forchheimer spots (Red spots over palate) may be present.

 

 

Option C. Varicella: Varicella presents with rash which appears 24-48 hrs after prodromal symptoms, then rapidly to face & trunk. There are papules, vesicles & crusted vesicles, Centripetal distribution with greatest on trunk.

 

 

Option D. Mumps: Mumps presents with Painful enlargement of salivary gland, ear ache, jaw tenderness while chewing, dryness of mouth.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koplik spots and a characteristic rash that begins on the forehead behind the ears and spreads to the torso and extremities are pathognomonic for measles.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

The clinical presentation of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction in a young child, along with the histopathological image from the cardiac biopsy, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

 

Lymphocytic Myocarditis:

 

  • Pathology: Characterized by interstitial inflammation with a predominance of lymphocytes. The image provided shows myocardial fibers with an interstitial infiltrate primarily composed of lymphocytes. Associated myocyte necrosis
  • Etiology: Commonly caused by viral infections such as coxsackievirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus B19.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with signs and symptoms of heart failure, arrhythmias, and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever: Typically shows Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells on biopsy, which are not present in the provided image.

 

Option C. Chagas disease: Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, characterized by amastigotes in myocardial cells, often with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, not just lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Pyogenic myocarditis: Characterized by the presence of neutrophils, indicating bacterial infection, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

 

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

 

Hypersensitivity myocarditis

 

 

Giant cell myocarditis

 

 

Myocarditis of Chagas disease (arrow showing trypanosomes)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

 

The given clinical scene and image shows a post-op tracheal stump created for breathing in patients of total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma.

 

In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more rings of trachea, are removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration.

 

Complications after total laryngectomy:

 

  • Permanent tracheostomy: upper end of trachea is directly sutured to skin for the patient to breathe.
  • Speech difficulties: To help patient speak after removal of larynx, there are various techniques.

 

1. Oesophageal speech:  patient is taught to swallow air and release which vibrates pharyngo-oesophageal segment and produces a very low sound.

 

2. Tracheo-oesophageal speech: most effective, artificial prostheses like Blom-singer valve / Provox / Groningen are inserted.

 

3. Electrolarynx: electrical device held on the skin of the neck vibrates and produce voice.

 

  • Loss of smell and decreased taste sensation
  • Swallowing difficulty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial laryngectomy: Is performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening.

 

Option B. Percutaneous tracheostomy: Is a minimally invasive surgical procedure done in ICU patients to create an opening in the trachea for breathing support. The image below shows the procedure of percutaneous tracheostomy.

 

 

Option C. Standard tracheostomy: Involves creating a larger incision in the neck to access the trachea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total laryngectomy is a radical yet life-saving procedure for patients with extensive laryngeal cancer, resulting in significant anatomical and functional changes.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

A microscopic agglutination test is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Leptospira interrogans is a spirochete with hook-shaped ends found in water contaminated with animal urine, causes Leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis - Flulike symptoms, myalgias (classically of calves), jaundice, photophobia with conjunctival suffusion (erythema without exudate)

 

 

Weil disease (icterohemorrhagic leptospirosis) - severe form with jaundice and azotemia from liver and kidney dysfunction, fever, hemorrhage, and anemia.

 

Laboratory tests - Leptospirae can be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence.

 

Serotype-specific tests - Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)

 

  • Rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospirae - specific IgM antibodies in human sera.

 

Treatment - Penicillin or IV ceftriaxone

 

  • Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi. Presents as stepwise increase in fever, abdominal pain, and constipation.

 

Option C. Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test used to diagnose rickettsial infections. Presents as fever, rash, and headache.

 

Option D. Paul-Bunnell test, aka the Monospot test, used to detect heterophile antibodies in case of infectious mononucleosis, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).Presents as fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The microscopic agglutination test is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in symptomatic individuals, especially those exposed to potentially contaminated water environments. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to preventing severe complications like Weil's disease.

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

 

 

HS-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis.

 

Other investigations that can help include:

 

  • CSF examination
  • CSF culture
  • Serological studies
  • MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

 

The image shows coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM antibodies in CSF: Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear of CSF: Rapid, fairly sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method, but prepared from the lesions, preferably from the base of vesicles and stained with 1% aqueous solution of toluidine blue ‘0’ for 15 seconds, not CSF.

 

Option D. CSF culture in chick embryos: HSV-1 doesn’t grow well on Chick embryo line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid and accurate diagnosis of HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the gold standard, essential for guiding appropriate antiviral therapy.

questions.text: A medical student presented with complaints of repeated episodes lasting approximately 30 minutes, characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and a fear of an impending heart attack. The patient has experienced these episodes 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, and investigations did not reveal any obvious abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic Disorder

 

The clinical presentation of a medical student with repeated episodes of breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and fear of an impending heart attack, each lasting approximately 30 minutes and occurring 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, with no abnormalities found in investigations, is highly suggestive of Panic Disorder. Panic Disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, which are abrupt surges of intense fear or discomfort reaching a peak within minutes. The symptoms described, including palpitations, sweating, and hyperventilation, are common during panic attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): GAD is characterized by persistent and excessive worry about various things, but it does not typically involve the acute, intense episodes of fear or the physical symptoms of a panic attack.

 

Option C. Depression: While depression can have anxiety symptoms and panic attacks, the primary feature is a persistent low mood and loss of interest or pleasure in activities, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Social Phobia: Also known as social anxiety disorder, this involves a significant fear of social or performance situations. The symptoms described do not specifically relate to social or performance situations, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient who is on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

 

The given clinical scenario of white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa in a patient using inhalational steroids points to diagnosis of oral candidiasis and drug that can be used for the treatment is clotrimazole.

 

Asthma patients use MDI which can result in deposition of steroids in the oropharyngeal space, which might lead to cough, dysphonia, and oral candidiasis.

 

Clotrimazole is classified under Azole group of Anti-Fungal drugs, acts by inhibiting fungal sterol (ergosterol) synthesis. Used topically in treatment for topical fungal infections like tinea and candida

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is mainly used against dermatophytes and is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. But it is not effective against Candida.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Terbinafine acts by inhibiting the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase. which reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. Used to treat nail onychomycosis and other dermatophytosis.

 

Option D. Flucytosine: Flucytosine acts by inhibiting nucleic acid synthesis. Used exclusively to combat systemic fungal infections (e.g., cryptococcal meningitis) in combination with amphotericin B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clotrimazole is the drug of choice for treating oral candidiasis, especially in patients who develop the condition as a side effect of inhalational steroid use. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis, compromising the fungal cell membrane integrity.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman came to the OPD with a diagnosis of advanced cervical cancer. She has a 14-year-old daughter. What advice would you give for her daughter? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Advise HPV vaccine

 

The patient's 14-year-old daughter should be advised to take the HPV vaccine.

 

Screening CA cervix begins at the age of 25 years.

 

HPV vaccine

 

  • Contains recombinant VLP (L1 synthetic capsid protein)
  • Types –
    • Cervarix: Bivalent (16,18)
    • Gardasil: Quadrivalent (6,11,16,18)
    • Gardasil 9: Nonavalent (6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58)
