    • Dosing as per IAP:
      • Girls 9 to 14 years: 2 doses
      • > 15 years: 3 doses

 

On June 1, 2023 there will be the launch of Indian indigenous vaccine called Cervavac , quadrivalent vaccine produce by Serum Institute of India (6, 11, 16, 18).

 

WHO’s Safe Advisory Group (SAGE) in 2021 advised regarding updating dose schedules for HPV as follows:

 

  • One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14
  • One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20
  • Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21

 

Immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, should receive three doses if feasible, and if not at least two doses. There is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of a single dose in this group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screen for BRCA mutation: BRCA mutation causes breast cancer, ovarian cancer, endometrial cancer

 

Option C. Screen for PTEN mutation: PTEN mutation (chromosome 10) causes Cowden syndrome, has 20-30% risk of developing endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. Perform cervical biopsy: Cervical biopsy is not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine is essential for preventing cervical cancer and should be administered to girls aged 9 to 14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

 

  • The white fingers suggest the diagnosis of Raynaud's syndrome, which is commonly seen in individuals exposed to vibrating tools like drills and machines.
  •  Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by decreased blood flow to the skin due to arteriolar vasospasm in response to cold or stress.
  • This condition leads to color changes in the skin, transitioning from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reperfusion).

 

Raynaud's Syndrome:

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arteriolar vasospasm causes decreased blood flow.
  • Triggers: Cold or stress.
  • Symptoms: Color changes in the fingers, pain, and numbness.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic use of vibrating tools (e.g., drills, jackhammers).
  • Types:
    • Primary (Idiopathic): No associated medical condition.
    • Secondary: Associated with connective tissue diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), CREST syndrome (a form of systemic sclerosis), or mixed connective tissue disease. Digital ulceration (critical ischemia) is seen in secondary Raynaud's syndrome.
  • Treatment: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) to reduce the frequency and severity of vasospastic episodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water: Candidal infections usually cause red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with pustules and a whitish coating. They do not present as white, ischemic fingers typical of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Option B. Exposure to thinners and paints: While exposure to thinners and paints can cause dermatitis and other skin conditions, they do not typically result in the vasospastic changes seen in Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Option C. Continuous exposure to cement and concrete: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete can cause contact dermatitis and other dermatological issues but is not associated with the vasospasm and color changes characteristic of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Raynaud's syndrome is characterized by episodic vasospastic attacks in response to cold or stress, leading to color changes in the fingers.
  •  Chronic exposure to vibrating tools, such as drills and machines, is a common occupational risk factor for developing this condition.
  • Treatment includes the use of calcium channel blockers to manage symptoms.

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension and is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spironolactone

 

The ECG shows tall, tented T waves, absent P waves (atrial standstill), and a severely widened QRS complex. These are classic signs of severe hyperkalemia.

 

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can cause hyperkalemia. It is known for increasing potassium levels in the blood by inhibiting the effects of aldosterone, leading to decreased excretion of potassium in the urine.

 

Therefore, the drug most likely responsible for the ECG findings is Spironolactone due to its potent potassium-sparing effects leading to severe hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: Causes hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Can cause mild hyperkalemia but not to the extent seen in the ECG.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Does not affect potassium levels significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic, can cause severe hyperkalemia, which is characterized by tall, tented T waves, absent P waves, and widened QRS complexes on an ECG.

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papaya, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they could be abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counselling and information to the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AWW

 

The described scenario involves a pregnant woman with a misconception about the consumption of certain fruits during pregnancy and a symptom of night blindness, which could indicate a deficiency in Vitamin A. The Anganwadi Worker (AWW) is primarily responsible for providing health and nutrition education and counselling to mothers, which includes information about proper dietary practices during pregnancy. AWWs are trained to address specific local challenges that prevent healthy behaviors, such as cultural practices, myths, local food availability, and dietary practices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife): ANMs primarily focus on providing basic medical care, immunizations, and assisting with childbirth and antenatal care. While they do offer some nutritional advice, the specific role of counselling about dietary misconceptions primarily falls under the AWW.

 

Option C. Trained birth attendant: Trained birth attendants are primarily involved in assisting with childbirth and ensuring safe delivery practices. Their role does not typically include extensive nutritional counselling.

 

Option D. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist): ASHAs work to promote community health and link the community with health services. They play a supportive role in health education, but detailed nutritional counselling is more specifically the responsibility of the AWW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is the duty of the Anganwadi Worker (AWW) to provide health and nutrition education and counselling to pregnant women, addressing misconceptions about diet and ensuring they receive proper nutritional guidance. Their training includes addressing local challenges and cultural practices to promote healthy behaviors.

choices.text: Ask for line probe assay
Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ask for CBNAAT

 

According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) guidelines, the next step in managing a patient with a high clinical suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), a suggestive chest x-ray, and negative sputum smears is to perform a CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is a molecular test that detects the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can also identify rifampicin resistance, providing rapid and accurate results.

 

DIAGNOSTIC TESTS UNDER NTEP:

 

1. Sputum smear Microscopy

  • ZN staining
  • LED – FM

 

2. Culture

 

  • LJ Medium
  • Automated Liquid culture (ALC)
    •  BACTEC MGIT 960
    • BACTALERT
    • VERSATREK

 

3. Drug sensitivity testing

 

  • Moderate Proportionate Sensitivity testing PST MGiT 960
  • Economic proportionate sensitivity testing 1% LJ Medium

 

4. Molecular Diagnosis test:

  • Line Probe Assay
    • LPA TB
    • PL LPA– INH & Rifampicin Resistance
    • SL LPA-FQ / SLI Resistance
    • NAAT
    • CBNAAT
    • True NAT True NAT
  • Developed by ICMR Real time PCR Technology
    • True NAT MTB- MTB
    • True NAT MTB plus- MTB
    • True NAT MTB Dx- Rifampicin Resistance TEP:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat sputum smears: Is not appropriate since the patient already had two negative sputum smears and a chest x-ray suggestive of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. CBNAAT: Should be performed first than Line probe assay.

 

Option D. TB: Culture takes time to yield results, the patient may deteriorate in the meantime.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with palpitations. Physical examination showed a diastolic murmur in the left 3rd intercostal space. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

The presence of a diastolic murmur heard best at the left 3rd intercostal space (Erb's point) is characteristic of aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation occurs when the aortic valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow back into the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: This condition produces a systolic ejection murmur, typically heard at the right second intercostal space.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart and radiates to the axilla.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic Regurgitation is associated with a diastolic murmur, best heard at Erb’s point (left 3rd intercostal space). The murmur is typically described as a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: A 56-year-old chronic smoker presented with complaints of weight loss and cough for more than 1 year. He also has hypercalcemia. His biopsy report revealed hyperchromatic atypical cells. Which of the following is the most likely cancer is this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous cell cancer

 

The presence of hyperchromatic atypical cells on biopsy with the given clinical history suggests a cancer. The history of chronic smoking with hypercalcemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome is a finding of squamous cell cancer (SCC) of the lung.  Hence, the answer is option “b”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small cell cancer: Often associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) and Cushing's syndrome, not typically hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Large cell neuroendocrine tumor: Less common, may have neuroendocrine features but not specifically associated with hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: More common in non-smokers and often presents with peripheral lung lesions. Not typically associated with hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is strongly associated with smoking and can present with hypercalcemia due to ectopic PTHrP production, alongside symptoms such as chronic cough and weight loss.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Whole Bowel Irrigation

 

The child has ingested a significant amount of ferrous sulfate, leading to iron intoxication, which has resulted in metabolic acidosis. Managing iron overdose requires specific interventions.

 

Key Points:

 

  1. Iron Intoxication: Iron overdose is a common pediatric poisoning that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Ingesting a large number of ferrous sulfate tablets can result in gastrointestinal irritation, systemic toxicity, and metabolic acidosis.
  2. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) Revealed Acidosis: Metabolic acidosis is a severe consequence of iron poisoning, indicating systemic toxicity.

 

Management of Iron Intoxication:

 

  • Whole Bowel Irrigation (WBI): This is a key intervention for decontaminating the gastrointestinal tract in cases of iron overdose. WBI is performed using a polyethylene glycol-electrolyte solution to flush out the gastrointestinal contents. It is particularly useful when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Antidote: The specific antidote for iron poisoning is deferoxamine, which binds free iron and promotes its excretion. While deferoxamine is essential in managing iron toxicity, it is not listed as an option in this question.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Activated Charcoal: As mentioned, it is not effective for iron, alcohols, acids, alkalis, or petroleum product intoxications. Activated charcoal does not adsorb iron, making it unsuitable for treating iron overdose.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Used for heavy metal poisoning like arsenic, gold, and mercury, but not effective for iron.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Used primarily for heavy metal poisoning like copper and lead, and ineffective for iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Whole Bowel Irrigation with polyethylene glycol is the preferred method for managing iron tablet ingestion, especially when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis

 


The life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis is given below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Cancer: Mainly associated with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18.

 

Option C. Gastric Carcinoma: Most commonly linked with Helicobacter pylori infection.

 

Option D. Bladder Carcinoma: Associated with Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is primarily associated with an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, emphasizing the importance of avoiding consumption of undercooked freshwater fish in endemic areas to prevent this parasitic infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant Melanoma

 

The given image showing a benign proliferation of Nevus (type of melanocytes) in a child points to diagnosis of congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Characteristics of Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

  • Seen since birth
  • Black-colored palpable lesion with well-defined borders
  • Surface is rough, hair
  • If > 20cm – giant congenital melanocytic nevus
  • Risk of melanoma is present

 

Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) can be associated with various complications, some of which include:

 

  1. Risk of Melanoma: Individuals with CMN have an increased risk of developing melanoma, a type of skin cancer. This risk is particularly higher in cases of giant congenital melanocytic nevi (GCMN)
  2. Neurocutaneous Melanosis: CMN can be linked to neurocutaneous melanosis, a condition where melanocytes are found in the central nervous system. This condition can lead to neurological issues and requires careful monitoring and management
  3. Proliferative Nodules: In some cases, CMN may develop proliferative nodules, which are areas of increased pigmentation and growth within the nevus. These nodules should be evaluated by a healthcare professional to rule out malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract: This is characterized by clouding of the lens within the eye, leading to a decrease in vision. It is not related to skin lesions such as a congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Option B: Sturge-Weber Syndrome (SWS) often leads to secondary glaucoma due to vascular malformations affecting eye drainage, with facial involvement increasing the risk.

 

SWS presents clinically as Port wine stain.

 

Port wine stain

 

  • Features: Also known as nevus flammeus, it is a capillary malformation that presents as a flat, pink, red, or purplish mark. It remains unchanged throughout life and can be anywhere on the body but is often seen on the face as shown below in the image.

 

 

Managing SWS-related glaucoma requires a multidisciplinary approach and regular eye exams for early detection and vision preservation.

 

Option D. Basal cell carcinoma: This is the most common form of skin cancer, often associated with long-term sun exposure. It typically appears as a raised, pearly bump and does not usually develop from congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital melanocytic nevi, especially larger ones, carry an increased risk for the development of malignant melanoma.
  • Monitoring and possibly biopsy of suspicious changes within these nevi are important for early detection of malignant transformation.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page number 75.9 to 75.14 73.2, 73.3

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Viper

 

Since, the patient is bleeding profusely from the wound site, the most likely cause is a bite of viper snake, a vasculotoxic snake.

 

  • Cobra is a neurotoxic snake, and will cause paralysis, instead of bleeding
  • Russell’s Viper is mainly vasculotoxic, but also neurotoxic to some extent
  • Krait and Sea Snake have minimal local symptoms
  • Russell’s viper is mainly vasculotoxic, but also has some neurotoxic features
  • Most common poisonous snake in India are (Big Four): 
    • Krait (Most Common)
    • Cobra,
    • Russell’s Viper
    • Saw Scaled Viper
  • Anti snake venom (ASV) in India is effective against all the above 4 snakes (polyvalent). It does not have antiserum against pit viper, but still partially effective due to cross antibodies
  • In Neurotoxic snakes, neostigmine should also be given in addition to ASV

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cobra:

 

  • Type: Neurotoxic snake.
  • Symptoms: Causes paralysis rather than bleeding.
  • Mechanism: Cobra venom affects the nervous system, leading to paralysis.

 

Option C. Wasp Bite:

 

Local: there is pain, itching, redness and slight Swelling at the site of the sting. 

 

Systemic: Systemic reactions occur due to multiple stinging with signs of GIT disturbance (nausea, vomiting and diarrhea), sweating, bronchospasm, hypotension, shock and unconsciousness.

 

Immediate anaphylactic reactions may be seen in some cases.

 

Option D. Scorpion Bite:

 

Action: The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator, resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It has also some direct effect on the myocardium.

 

Signs and Symptoms Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles develop within hours.

 

Local: Little swelling, but prominent radiating pain, reddening, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (tap test).

 

Systemic: Nausea, vomiting, restlessness, fever, headache, blurred vision, abnormal eye movement, profuse sweating and salivation, lacrimation, rhinorrhoea, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, jerking and shaking, slow pulse, cyanosis, convulsions, coma and respiratory depression, and death

 

Treatment of Scorpion bite: Anti scorpion venom, Prazosin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viper bites are characterized by profuse bleeding, pain, redness, and blister formation due to their vasculotoxic venom.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

 

  • Image given is of trophic ulcer, typically seen in diabetic patients because of lack of sensation.
  • They are seen on weight bearing parts of foot.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has malaise for 2 weeks. His investigations revealed an elevated creatinine of 4.5mg/dl. His blood tests also showed the presence of HBs antigen. A renal biopsy was performed which demonstrated spike and dome on special staining. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranous glomerulopathy

 

The elderly patient is having a renal dysfunction. The presence of a ‘spike and dome’ pattern on special staining (silver staining) is suggestive of immune complex deposition. This is characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy. The diagnosis isd also supported by the presence of HBs antigen as the hepatitis B infection is characteristically associated with development of membranous glomerulopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease: Typically presents with nephrotic syndrome in children and does not show the spike and dome pattern on biopsy. No change on light microscopy; Electron microscopy shows podocyte effacement

 

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli, not associated with the spike and dome pattern.

 

Option D. Renal amyloidosis: Demonstrates amyloid deposits that can be identified with Congo red staining and apple-green birefringence under polarized light, not a spike and dome pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous glomerulopathy, associated with hepatitis B infection, presents with nephrotic syndrome and demonstrates a characteristic spike and dome pattern on renal biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposits.

 

Histology: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)

questions.text: A patient presenting with bleeding gums and easy bruisability was diagnosed with scurvy. What is the biochemical basis of scurvy?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective collagen formation

 

Scurvy is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in the synthesis of collagen. Collagen is a crucial protein for the structural integrity of connective tissues, including blood vessels, skin, and gums. In the absence of sufficient vitamin C, collagen synthesis is impaired, leading to weakened blood vessels, bleeding gums, and easy bruising..

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low calcium levels do not cause scurvy; they may contribute to other clinical conditions like Muscle cramps and stiffness, Tingling and Numbness, Tetany.

 

Option C. Vitamin K deficiency leads to the inhibition of clotting factors and cause bleeding tendencies.

 

Option D. Vitamin A deficiency causes hyperkeratosis and epithelial changes, such as xerosis and Bitot's spots, and night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about cancer treatment according to the Colombo plan? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Setting up cobalt therapy units

 

The Colombo Plan, established in 1950, was drawn up for the cooperative economic development of South and South-East Asia. It included 20 countries with the main aim of improving the living standards of people. The plan focused on industrial and agricultural development and provided support for health promotion, mostly through fellowships.

 

Key Contributions of the Colombo Plan:

 

  • AIIMS, New Delhi: Established with financial assistance from New Zealand.
  • Cobalt Therapy Units: Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India as part of the Colombo Plan. These units significantly enhanced the capabilities for cancer treatment in India.

 

Cobalt Therapy Units:

 

  • Cobalt Therapy: Involves using gamma rays from cobalt-60 isotopes to treat cancer. It was a crucial development in radiotherapy in the mid-20th century and improved cancer treatment outcomes significantly.
  • Provision under Colombo Plan: The supply of cobalt therapy units by Canada helped Indian medical institutions upgrade their cancer treatment facilities, making advanced radiotherapy accessible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Colombo Plan, Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India, significantly enhancing the country's capacity to provide advanced cancer treatment through radiotherapy. This was a crucial step in improving healthcare infrastructure and cancer treatment capabilities in India.

Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

 

The amount of radiation exposure follows Inverse Square law which states that the radiation Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Small blood vessels are radiosensitive.

 

Option C: Cancer cells are rapidly proliferating cells are most radiosensitive.

 

Option D: Bone marrow, gonads, bowel mucosa possess high radiosensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inverse Square Law is critical to understanding radiation dosage and safety in radiotherapy, ensuring that radiation exposure is managed correctly to maximize the therapeutic effect while minimizing harm to healthy tissues. This principle helps in planning and delivering radiation treatments effectively.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E2V3M4

 

The GCS score of this patient is E2V3M4

 

  • Opening eves to a painful stimulus - E2
  • Speak inappropriately - V3
  • Withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus - M4

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is an essential tool for assessing the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury.
  • It involves evaluating the eye opening response, verbal response, and motor response, with scores ranging from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).
  •  Understanding how to correctly assess and calculate the GCS score is crucial for determining the severity of the injury and guiding appropriate medical intervention.

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

 

The patient presents with sensory loss, limb weakness, and specific neurological findings that are indicative of subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Key Findings:

 

  1. Sensory Loss and Weakness of Limbs: This suggests a neurological disorder affecting the peripheral and central nervous systems.
  2. Angular Stomatitis: This is often associated with vitamin deficiencies, particularly vitamin B12.
  3. Loss of Proprioception and Vibration Sensation: This is characteristic of posterior column involvement, which is seen in subacute combined degeneration.
  4. UMN Type of Lower Limb Weakness: Upper motor neuron signs (UMN) such as spasticity and exaggerated reflexes, except for the absent ankle reflex, are indicative of corticospinal tract involvement.
  5. Absent Ankle Reflex: This, along with UMN signs, is a classic feature of subacute combined degeneration of the cord.

 

Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord: This condition is due to vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to demyelination of the posterior columns and corticospinal tracts. This results in a combination of sensory ataxia, spasticity, and other upper motor neuron signs, except for the absent ankle reflex which indicates peripheral neuropathy.

 

Additional Findings:

 

  • Angular Stomatitis: Points towards a vitamin deficiency.
  • Babinski Positivity with Absent Ankle Jerk: This combination is specifically associated with subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to B12 deficiency. Other conditions like cauda equina syndrome or Friedreich ataxia could present similarly, but the presence of angular stomatitis and the described neurological findings strongly support subacute combined degeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Cord Compression: This would typically present with radicular pain and possibly more pronounced lower motor neuron signs below the level of compression, not the UMN signs described here.

 

Option B. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): ALS involves both UMN and LMN signs but does not typically present with sensory loss or specific vitamin deficiency signs like angular stomatitis.

 

Option C. Multiple Sclerosis (MS): MS can present with varied neurological signs, but it does not typically present with angular stomatitis or the classic combination of absent ankle reflex with UMN signs seen in subacute combined degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency presents with sensory loss, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflex, along with other signs of vitamin deficiency like angular stomatitis.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of staring into space with frequent visual hallucinations. Pathology reveals Lewy bodies in neurons. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Parkinson’s Disease

 

The presence of Lewy bodies, which are aggregates of alpha-synuclein protein, in neurons suggests either Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia. Given the patient's symptoms of progressive decline in daily activity, visual hallucinations, and pathology findings, Parkinson's disease is the most likely diagnosis.

 

  • Lewy Bodies: These are characteristic of Parkinson’s disease and Lewy body dementia. They are intraneuronal inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein.
  • Visual Hallucinations: These are more common in Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia compared to other neurodegenerative disorders.
  • Parkinson’s Disease: The diagnosis is supported by the clinical history of visual hallucinations and progressive decline, alongside the pathological finding of Lewy bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prion’s Disease: Typically presents with rapidly progressing dementia and myoclonus. EEG shows characteristic periodic sharp wave complexes, and CSF may show elevated 14.3.3 protein. This does not match the patient's clinical picture.

 

Option C. Huntington’s Disease: An inherited condition characterized by the classic triad of dementia, chorea, and psychiatric manifestations. This condition usually presents earlier in life and has a strong family history component.

 

Option D. Alzheimer’s Disease: Primarily presents with memory loss and later with visual-spatial problems and the "four A’s" (amnesia, agnosia, apraxia, aphasia). Pathologically, it is characterized by beta-amyloid plaques and tau protein tangles, not Lewy bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lewy bodies in neurons and clinical features such as visual hallucinations and progressive decline in activity are indicative of Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TT/Td vaccine

 

In the national immunization schedule, the TT/Td vaccine is given to children at 10 years & 16 years of age as part of the school immunization program.

 

Additional Information

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles Vaccine can be given till 5 years of age.

 

Option B. Rotavirus vaccines can be given till 12 years of age.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B vaccine can be given till 1 year of age.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

National Immunisation schedule (2023-24):

questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with the lesion shown below in the x-ray. Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GCT

 

GIANT CELL TUMOUR (GCT)

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.
  • Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group.
  • Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Difference between Aneurysmal bone cyst and GCT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst. A dermoid cyst is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. These benign tumors are lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mature skin appendages found on their wall and their lumens filled with keratin and hair. Dermoid cysts are considered to be congenital, but not all of them are diagnosed at birth. Only about 40% of dermoid cysts are diagnosed at birth, while about 60% are diagnosed by five years of age. The dermoid cysts usually present within the first year of life and grow slowly. Dermoid cysts occur most commonly on the head and neck. The etiology of dermoid cysts remains mostly unknown. These occur when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development. In the head and neck region, dermoid cysts can most commonly be seen in the frontal, occipital, and supraorbital areas, with the outer third of the eyebrow being the most frequently affected region.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumor of distal end radius is always GCT until proven otherwise.
  • Mc site of giant cell tumor is lower end femur.
  • Lower end femur is Mc site for:
    • Giant cell tumor
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Osteomyelitis

questions.text: A woman presents to you with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lupus nephritis

 

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems. The patient's symptoms of fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue, combined with new-onset hematuria and findings of RBC casts and proteinuria in the urine, are indicative of systemic involvement typical of lupus nephritis.

 

Lupus nephritis is characterized by inflammation of the kidneys, often leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and renal impairment.

 

Next Step -

 

Conducting an ANA (antinuclear antibody) test.

 

Performing an anti-dsDNA (anti-double stranded DNA) test, which is noted as being very specific and correlates with lupus nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: This condition typically presents with WBC casts rather than RBC casts in the urine and is not usually associated with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, or ulcers.

 

Option B. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): While PSGN can cause RBC casts and proteinuria, it is generally a renal-limited condition and does not present with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, and ulcers.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy is also a renal-limited condition and typically does not present with systemic symptoms. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually following upper respiratory infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus nephritis should be suspected in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus who present with renal symptoms such as hematuria and proteinuria, especially when accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue. Further testing, including ANA and anti-dsDNA antibodies, is warranted to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent attacks of gout was started on a therapy that inhibits the synthesis of uric acid. His symptoms were relieved after therapy. Identify the drug he was prescribed? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Allopurinol

 

Allopurinol is a competitive inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme. It decreases the production of uric acid, therefore useful in cases of hyperuricemia and chronic gout.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Probenecid: Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acids. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation.

 

Option B. Colchicine: Colchicine is Inhibit granulocyte migration and the release of glycoprotein from neutrophils. Used in Gout, Cirrhosis, Acute Mediterranean Fever, Sarcoidosis.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac is a Non-Selective COX inhibitor having analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory property. A/E – Peptic ulcer disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allopurinol is the drug of choice for reducing uric acid synthesis in patients with chronic gout by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme. It effectively lowers serum and urinary uric acid levels, thereby preventing gout attacks.

questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin C

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of neurolathyrism. Vitamin C is beneficial in cases of lathyrism.

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings

  • Osteolathyrism (Odoratism): In animals

     

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine’ (BOAA)

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, yellow needle-shaped crystals are seen under the microscope. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio’s Test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Option D. Acid phosphatase test: It’s a non-cellular Semen Markers i.e. markers are specific and unique to seminal plasma but independent of spermatozoa.

 

Finding a significantly elevated acid phosphatase level is consistent with the presence of semen. Undiluted semen has an acid phosphatase level of 340–360 Bodansky units/ml. A value of > 100 Bodansky units with/without motile sperms indicate that ejaculation occurred within 12 h of examination. Level decreases with time after intercourse, and there is little chance of identifying it after 48 h.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Non-cellular Semen Markers: Acid phosphatase test (quantitative), Prostate specific antigen or PSA (p30)

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

 

Laparoscopic hysterectomy is a minimally invasive procedure that offers numerous benefits compared to open surgery. However, one significant disadvantage is the difficulty in assessing the extent of thermal burns. Thermal burns can occur due to the use of electrosurgical instruments, and the limited visual field in laparoscopic surgery can make it challenging to identify and evaluate the full extent of these burns. This limitation is crucial because undetected thermal injury can lead to postoperative complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged recovery time: Laparoscopic surgery typically results in a shorter recovery time compared to open surgery. The minimally invasive nature of the procedure means less tissue damage and faster healing.

 

Option C. Increased bleeding: Laparoscopic surgery generally involves less blood loss than open surgery. The precision of the instruments and the smaller incisions contribute to reduced bleeding.

 

Option D. Increased pain: One of the advantages of laparoscopic surgery is less postoperative pain. The smaller incisions and less invasive approach result in decreased pain and discomfort for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

The chloride level of sweat is evaluated in cystic fibrosis.

 

CYSTIC FIBROSIS

 

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Mutation in chromosome no. 7
  • Primary defect: CFTR gene [Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene on chromosome 7q31.2]
  • Other defects: Chloride channels, Potassium channels, Epithelial sodium channels

 

 

  • Sweat ducts normally absorb sodium from lumen which decreases in CF causing salty sweat.
  • Excessive loss of salt in the sweat is there. Other ducts are obstructed.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

Hallmark of cystic fibrosis –

 

High sodium and chloride levels Sweat chloride level is >60mEq/L in 2 occasions Airways, pancreas & GIT - Normally sodium uptake is there from luminal fluid but in CF there is increase of sodium and water uptake from lumen causing thick, viscid secretions.

 

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Phenylketonuria occurs due to absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme, leading to phenylketonuria. Diagnosis is made by Ferric chloride test, Guthrie test.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of the tissue enzyme glucocerebrosidase that splits glucose from glucosylceramide, resulting in accumulation of the latter in cells of the reticuloendothelial system. Diagnosis is made by measuring glucocerebrosidase levels in leukocytes or skin fibroblasts. Serum chitotriosidase levels are elevated.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta causes defective type-1 collagen. Presents with a triad of blue sclera, Fragile bones, Early deafness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

choices.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factors II, VII, IX, and X

 

Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X are zymogens of serine proteases that contain glutamic acid residues. These residues undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation via gamma-glutamyl carboxylase to form gamma-carboxy glutamic acid residues. This enables them to bind calcium ions (Ca2+), which is necessary for their activation and subsequent blood clot formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factors II, VIII, IX, X: Factor VIII is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation but does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option C. Factors II, VII, IX, XI: Factor XI is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is activated by thrombin and does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option D. Factors II, VIII, X, XI: Neither Factor VIII nor Factor XI are zymogens that require gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. They do not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zymogens are the proprotein form of enzymes (proenzymes) that require proteolytic activation to carry out their function.

 

Inactive form of vitamin K acts as a cofactor in the post-synthetic modification of these zymogens and their activation. This inactive form of vitamin K is recycled back from its oxidized form by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which can be inhibited by warfarin or liver failure.

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman accompanied by her mother-in-law comes to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

 

Infertility is defined as the inability of a couple to conceive after 1 year of unprotected intercourse. For women under the age of 35, it is recommended to wait and try for one year before starting any investigations. Since the woman in this scenario is only 23 years old and has been trying to conceive for only 6 months, the best approach is to reassure her and advise her to continue trying. Investigations are not indicated at this stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semen analysis for husband: Although semen analysis is an essential part of infertility workup, it is typically not indicated until the couple has been trying to conceive for at least one year if the woman is under 35 years old.

 

Option C. Hysterolaparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure used to evaluate the female reproductive tract, typically reserved for cases where initial evaluations suggest abnormalities or for women who have been trying to conceive for a longer period.

 

Option D. Diagnostic hysteroscopy: This procedure is used to examine the inside of the uterus and is generally indicated for investigating suspected uterine abnormalities or after a longer period of unsuccessful conception attempts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women under 35 years old, it is recommended to try to conceive for one year before starting infertility investigations.

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

questions.text: A young female is brought to the emergency department. Attendants inform that she has consumed 100 tablets of aspirin. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

 

Aspirin poisoning (Salicylism)

 

Respiratory Center Stimulation

↓

Hyperventilation

↓

↓CO2

↓

Respiratory Alkalosis → Reversible

↓

Metabolic Acidosis → Irreversible

 

Treatment - DOC is sodium bicarbonate (NaHC03)

  •  Reverses metabolic acidosis
  •  Helps in aspirin excretion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores: N-acetyl cysteine is an antidote for paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option B. Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is useful in organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option C. Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia: Glucagon is antidote in beta-blocker toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium Bicarbonate is the treatment of choice in aspirin poisoning, as it helps to alkalize the urine and enhance the excretion of salicylates, while also correcting metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancoast tumor

 

Pancoast tumors, also known as superior sulcus tumors, are a type of lung cancer located at the apex (top) of the lung. These tumors are particularly associated with several key clinical features and findings, especially in chronic smokers:

 

  1. Upper chest discomfort: This is a common symptom of a Pancoast tumor due to the tumor's location at the apex of the lung.
  2. Drooping of an eyelid (ptosis): This is part of Horner's syndrome, which occurs due to compression of the sympathetic nerves by the tumor. Horner's syndrome typically includes ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face.
  3. Pain radiating to the upper arm and tingling sensation: These symptoms suggest involvement of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the arm and hand. Pancoast tumors often invade or compress these nerves, leading to referred pain and sensory disturbances in the arm and hand.
  4. Chest X-ray findings: The provided chest X-ray shows a mass at the apex of the lung, which is characteristic of a Pancoast tumor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper lobe pneumonia: While upper lobe pneumonia can cause chest discomfort and possibly pain, it is not associated with Horner's syndrome or brachial plexus involvement. The X-ray findings would also typically show consolidation rather than a mass.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava obstruction: This condition can cause swelling and discoloration of the face, neck, and upper extremities due to impaired blood flow. However, it does not explain the specific nerve-related symptoms like Horner's syndrome or tingling in the digits.

 

Option D. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls that develop in pre-existing lung cavities, usually in patients with a history of tuberculosis or other lung diseases. They do not typically present with the neurological symptoms seen in this case, nor do they commonly cause Horner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors, or superior sulcus tumors, are associated with upper chest discomfort, Horner's syndrome, and neurological symptoms in the arm due to their apical location and propensity to invade local structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: A patient with reduced hemoglobin and gum bleeding presented to you. He has thrombocytopenia (platelet count 25,000/µl) elevated PT, and aPTT. Which of the following can the probable cause of his finding? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AML t (15;17)

 

The clinical presentation of reduced hemoglobin, gum bleeding, thrombocytopenia, and elevated PT and aPTT is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is associated with the t(15;17) translocation, is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) that commonly presents with DIC.

 

Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL):

 

  • Genetics: APL is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation, which results in the PML-RARA fusion gene. This translocation disrupts the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) gene, leading to a block in myeloid differentiation at the promyelocyte stage.
  • Clinical Features: Patients often present with symptoms of bleeding (e.g., gum bleeding, bruising) due to DIC, which is a common complication of APL.
  • Laboratory Findings: Thrombocytopenia, elevated PT, and aPTT are consistent with DIC. The peripheral smear may show promyelocytes with Auer rods.
  • Management: APL is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), which induces differentiation of the malignant promyelocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AML t(8;21): Associated with AML with maturation, typically presenting with myeloblasts and not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option C. AML t(16;16): Associated with AML with abnormal eosinophils, also not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option D. AML with NPM1: NPM1 mutations are common in AML but do not specifically correlate with DIC or the presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) associated with t(15;17) translocation commonly presents with DIC, characterized by thrombocytopenia and elevated coagulation times (PT and aPTT). DIC is due to release of procoagulant substances from the abnormal promyelocytes. Immediate identification and treatment with ATRA are crucial to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text: A middle aged male presented with features of neck swelling, exophthalmos, sweating, tachycardia and tremors. Which of the following is the likely associated finding in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti thyroid receptor antibody

 

This patient presents with classic signs of hyperthyroidism, including:

 

  • Neck swelling → Goiter
  • Exophthalmos → Bulging eyes
  • Sweating, tachycardia, tremors → Signs of increased sympathetic activity

 

The given history and the picture of the patient suggest a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism the commonest cause of which is Graves’s disease.

 

The most common antibody subtype, known as thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI), is observed in approximately 90% of patients. TSI binds to the TSH receptor and mimics its actions, stimulating adenyl cyclase and increasing the release of thyroid hormones.

 

  • Anti thyroid stimulating antibody cannot be the answer as such an antibody
  • Since TSI stimulates the gland for the formation of thyroid hormones. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-TPO antibody: Associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option B. Anti-thyroglobulin antibody: Also associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option C. Anti-thyroid stimulating antibody: Incorrect terminology for TSI, which is already covered under anti-thyroid receptor antibody.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is associated with anti-thyroid receptor antibodies (TSI), which stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excess thyroid hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism. The presence of neck swelling, exophthalmos, and other hyperthyroid symptoms strongly suggests this diagnosis.

 

Graves Disease – Key Features:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1081

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of bronchial asthma in third stage of labor. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carboprost

 

The drug that should be avoided in this patient with a history of bronchial asthma is carboprost since it can cause bronchoconstriction.

 

Carboprost (PGF2α analogue)

 

Action - It increases uterine tone by contracting upper segment of uterus

 

Use - To control postpartum hemorrhage (DOC – Oxytocin).

 

A/E - Vomiting, diarrhea, and bronchoconstriction.

 

Contraindications -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is the first-line drug to prevent and treat PPH and also used in augmentation of labour according to WHO guidelines. Administered by intravenous route and may lead to hypotension and reflex tachycardia.

 

Option C. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a PGE2 analogue used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and in atony treatment. It should be avoided in patients with a history of asthma, glaucoma, or myocardial infarction. One major adverse effect is uterine hyperstimulation.

 

Option D. Methyl ergometrine: Ergot derivatives are used in the control of postpartum uterine bleeding. It is given intramuscularly and is effective within 1-5 minutes. It is given at the time of delivery of the placenta or immediately after if bleeding is significant. Side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in patients with a history of bronchial asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of a painless ulcer in the genital area. It is associated with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Syphilis

 

Given scenario points out to a diagnosis of syphilis

 

ACQUIRED SYPHILIS:

 

Mode of acquisition - Sexual transmission & Blood transfusion

 

Stages are as follows –

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: In this condition both genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy are painful. It is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, with an incubation period of 2-5 days.

 

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: It causes painful ulcers in the genital region and localized tender lymphadenopathy, caused by HSV 2 > 1.

 

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale (aka donovanosis): It is caused by the bacterium Calymmatobacter / Klebsiella granulomatis. There is NO pain in Ulcer & NO Lymphadenopathy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary syphilis (syphiLESS) is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a Painless genital ulcer and Painless inguinal lymphadenopathy, which are classic presentations of this sexually transmitted infection.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no: 28.8-29, 29.13-16

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 339, 341, 342

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 379-383

questions.text: A child presents with mental retardation, bone pain, and inability to walk. On fundoscopy examination, a cherry red spot is seen. There is no organomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

 

Tay-Sachs disease. The given clinical scenario, along with the fundoscopy image showing a macular cherry-red spot, indicates that the most likely diagnosis is Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease: Niemann-Pick disease is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it often presents with hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), which is not mentioned in the case. The cherry-red spot is not a typical feature of Niemann-Pick disease.

 

Option C. Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis I), autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs. Enzyme deficient is α-L-Iduronidase. Presents usually at 6-24 months with clouded cornea, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, and skeletal dysplasia. Glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge are the other features. The condition is generally fatal.

 

Option D. Gaucher’s Disease presents with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance. Mental Retardation is not seen.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. The patient gives a history of a road traffic accident 15 years back. The CT image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontal mucocele

 

The given clinical scenario and the image findings are suggestive of a frontal mucocele.

 

A frontal mucocele is a benign cystic lesion that develops in the frontal sinus, which is one of the air-filled spaces located in the forehead region of the skull. It typically occurs as a result of the blockage or obstruction of the frontal sinus drainage pathway, leading to the accumulation of mucus within the sinus cavity. Over time, the trapped mucus can cause the sinus walls to expand, forming a mucocele.

 

 

Patient presents with headache, diplopia, and proptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal meningiomas: originates from the meninges, benign brain tumors presenting with headaches, seizures, vomiting, personality changes, and cognitive impairment. Given below is a Coronal MRI section.

 

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: is the most common benign tumor of nasopharynx. Patients present with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Pseudotumor of the orbit: is an idiopathic inflammation of the orbit presenting with painful proptosis, diplopia, and orbital congestion. Imaging shows right medial rectus muscle which is diffusely enlarged with moderate homogeneous enhancement with relative involvement of its tendinous insertion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal mucoceles are a significant cause of proptosis and orbital symptoms, particularly following a history of facial trauma or sinus disease. Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention to decompress the sinus and restore drainage can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: A middle aged cement factory worker has developed mesothelioma. This is likely to be associated with: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestosis

 

Mesothelioma is a malignant tumor of the pleura (or less commonly, the peritoneum). The development of mesothelioma is closely linked with exposure to asbestos, which is commonly encountered in certain occupational settings, including cement factories.

 

Asbestosis:

 

  • Pathology: Asbestosis refers to chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers. The fibers can cause inflammation and scarring of lung tissue, leading to a restrictive lung disease.
  • Complications: Prolonged exposure to asbestos can lead to the development of mesothelioma, a malignant tumor of the pleura or peritoneum.
  • Occupational Exposure: Cement factory workers, construction workers, and shipbuilders are at higher risk of asbestos exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Caused by inhalation of silica dust, leading to nodular pulmonary fibrosis. Not directly associated with mesothelioma.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Associated with coal dust inhalation, leading to coal worker's pneumoconiosis, not mesothelioma.

 

Option D. Byssinosis: Associated with cotton dust inhalation, leading to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, not mesothelioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, commonly found in occupations such as cement factory work, construction, and shipbuilding. Asbestosis can lead to significant complications, including mesothelioma.

 

Asbestos is a fibrous silicate mineral used in insulation, construction, and cement manufacturing.

 

  • Inhaled asbestos fibers lodge in the lungs and pleura, causing:
  • Interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Pleural plaques
  • Mesothelioma
  • Increased risk of bronchogenic carcinoma
  • Even minimal exposure can be dangerous over time.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atropine toxicity

 

The most likely cause of fever in this patient is atropine toxicity.

 

The clinical scenario is of organophosphate poisoning and patient was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime.

 

Atropine is a non-specific muscarinic receptor blocker, but not the nicotinic effects.

 

A/E of Atropine include –

 

  • ↑body temperature (due to ↓sweating)
  • ↑ HR
  • Dry mouth, Dry & flushed skin
  • Cycloplegia
  • Constipation
  • Disorientation
  • Can cause acute angle-closure glaucoma in older adults (due to mydriasis)
  • Urinary retention in men with prostatic hyperplasia
  • Hyperthermia in infants

 

Pralidoxime is given as an adjuvant to atropine in cases of organophosphate poisoning. It does not increase body temperature.

 

Hence, the sudden rise in body temperature is most likely attributed to Atropine Toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Side effect of pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used as an adjuvant in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning to reactivate acetylcholinesterase. It does not typically cause hyperthermia or significantly affect body temperature.

 

Option C. Due to organophosphate poisoning: Organophosphate poisoning typically causes symptoms due to excessive acetylcholine, such as sweating, salivation, bronchorrhea, bradycardia, and muscle fasciculations. It does not typically cause a sudden rise in temperature as described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Idiopathic: An idiopathic cause is one that arises spontaneously or for which the cause is unknown. Given the context of the medication administration and known side effects, the fever is more likely due to atropine toxicity rather than an unexplained cause.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

RICKETS

 

  • In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones.
  • Pathology:
    • Irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis
    • Thin and weak new trabeculae
    • On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped

 

 

  • Causes:
    • Vitamin D disorders: nutritional, secondary, malabsorption, decreased liver (25) hydroxylase activity
    • Calcium deficiency
    • Phosphorus deficiency
    • Renal losses: Fanconi syndrome
    • Tumors associated with rickets: GCT, osteoblastoma, fibrous dysplasia, neurofibromatosis
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis).
    • Indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance)
    • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
    • Looser’s zone in 20% cases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C. Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding).

 

 

Option C. Vitamin A. Hypovitaminosis A results from inadequate intake of vitamin A, fat malabsorption, or liver disorders and produces a variety of epithelial alterations. Radiographic features includes slow bone development, widening of cranial sutures with bulging fontanelles, and skull hyperostosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin E. Hypovitaminosis E is rare. It is usually due to the malabsorption of vitamin E, e.g. cystic fibrosis or pancreatic failure. It manifests as dysfunction of the CNS, characteristically presenting with a tremor and ataxia. Tendon reflexes are often absent. Clinically and radiologically it may be indistinguishable from the neurological sequelae of hypovitaminosis B12, i.e. subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency presents as thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis with abnormally wide (splaying), cupping or flaring (Brush-like) appearance; and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Years lost due to premature death

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

 

Definition: YPLL is based on Years of life lost through premature death

 

Importance:

 

  • YPLL occurs before the age to which a dying person could have expected to survive
  • YPLL is a type of mortality indicator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Years lost to morbidity refers to the time spent living with a disease or disability, which is not directly related to the concept of years of potential life lost.

 

Option C. Years lost to disability is a component of disability-adjusted life years (DALY). DALY Is BEST measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

 

DALY = YLL (Years of lost life) + YLD (Years lost to disability)

 

Option D. life would account into QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure that quantifies the impact of premature death on a population by calculating the number of years not lived by individuals who die before reaching a specified age. It highlights the significance of early mortality and its impact on society.

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here’s an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother also complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. What enzyme is most likely deficient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycogen synthase

 

Glycogen synthase: This is the correct answer. Glycogen synthase is responsible for synthesizing glycogen from glucose. A deficiency in glycogen synthase would result in the inability to produce glycogen, which aligns with the liver examination findings of no glycogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle’s disease or glycogen storage disease type V) primarily affects skeletal muscle glycogen metabolism. Symptoms include muscle weakness, cramps, and exercise intolerance.

 

Option C. Debranching enzyme deficiency (Cori's disease or glycogen storage disease type III) presents with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and growth retardation. The liver would still contain glycogen, although with an abnormal structure.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke's disease or glycogen storage disease type I) is characterized by severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hepatomegaly, Renomegaly. In this case, glycogen is present in the liver but cannot be broken down efficiently into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen synthase is a key enzyme involved in glycogenesis, the process of synthesizing glycogen, which serves as a storage form of glucose in the liver and muscles. Glycogen synthase catalyzes the addition of glucose molecules to the growing glycogen chain by creating alpha-1,4-glycosidic linkages between glucose units. This enzyme is regulated by various factors, including insulin, which promotes glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase.

 

Mutations or dysregulation of glycogen synthase can lead to Glycogen Storage Disease 0 (GSD 0), a disorder resulting from mutations in the GYS2 gene encoding liver glycogen synthase. C/f include fasting hypoglycemia, hunger between meals, hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and other metabolic abnormalities due to impaired glycogen synthesis.
