questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the lesion shown in the image. He had a traumatic injury to the chest one year ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?   (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keloid

 

  • The image shows scar tissue is of a keloid.

 

Here is a comparison between Keloid and Hypertrophic scars:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: A hemangioma is a vascular tumor that arises from the vascular endothelium.

 

 

Option B.Hypertrophic scar: Hypertrophic scar is limited to margins.

 

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign tumors arising from Schwann cells. Skin manifestations appear in early life, with the development of more than five smooth surfaced café-au-lait spots, subcutaneous neurofibromata, armpit or groin freckling and Lisch nodules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keloids are raised scars that extend beyond the original wound margin, are progressive, and do not regress on their own.
  •  They are most commonly seen in individuals with darker skin and may have a genetic predisposition.
  •  Treatment involves silicon sheets, intralesional steroids, laser ablation, and sometimes surgical excision with radiotherapy.

questions.text: A child presents with thinning of hair and scaling of the scalp. On taking further history, it is found that she consumes raw eggs in her diet regularly. The given manifestations are due to the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Biotin

 

Biotin (Vitamin B7): The given clinical vignette of scaling of scalp and alopecia as well as the history of raw egg consumption suggests biotin deficiency.

 

Raw egg white contains avidin, which tightly binds to biotin and renders it unabsorbable from the intestine. Hence, there can be a biotin deficiency state. Biotin deficiency is known to cause hair thinning and scalp scaling, among other symptoms related to the skin and hair. Biotin is essential for healthy skin, hair, and nails.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition known as pellagra, which primarily presents with symptoms such as dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Thinning hair and scaling of the scalp are not typical features of niacin deficiency.

 

Option B. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency can result in various neurological symptoms and skin changes, but it doesn't typically manifest as thinning hair and scaling of the scalp.

 

Option D. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine deficiency can lead to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, but it does not typically present with hair and scalp issues like thinning and scaling.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine

 

STRYCHNINE NUX VOMICA

 

Active Principle: Strychnine, Brucine

 

Most Toxic part: Seeds (Fatal dose: 1 crushed seed; uncrushed seed not toxic)

 

MOA –

 

  • Competitive antagonist of glycine at post synaptic receptors
  • Strychnine inhibits the uptake of glycine, which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter at post-synaptic junction which gives excitatory effects
  • Spinal Cord: Anterior horn cells & brain stem also.

 

Clinical Presentation –

 

  • Very sudden onset
  • Dramatic presentation
  • “Conscious seizures”
    • Generalized
    • Simultaneous Convulsions (2-3 mins): All muscles affected at once
    • In b/w contractions muscles completely relaxed (5 mins)
      • Death occurs after 5-6 convulsions (1-2 hrs)

 

1. Opisthotonos: Hyper extension of spine

 

2. Emprosthotonus: Forward bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

3. Pleurosthotonus: Sideways bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

4. Risus Sardonicus: Contraction of facial muscles leading to smiling face

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ricinus communis (Castor) poisoning leads to burning pain in throat, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea and death.

 

Option C: Nerium odorum (cardiac poison) causes headache, dizziness, vomiting, low blood pressure, fibrillation, AV block, coma, and death can occur due to cardiac failure.

 

Option D: Datura poisoning show symptoms like

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strychnine poisoning presents with characteristic "conscious seizures" and back arching (opisthotonos) due to its antagonistic action on glycine receptors.

choices.text: Rosette cataract with control of blood sugar level
Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient complaints of blurring of vision and gives history of Diabetes for the past 10 years. On examination findings as shown in image were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis and treatment for the same. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

 

Immature cataract refers to a cataract that has not yet progressed to cause complete opacity and loss of vision. Phacoemulsification is a modern cataract surgery technique that uses ultrasonic vibrations to emulsify the lens, allowing for its removal and replacement with an IOL. This is a common treatment for cataracts that are significantly affecting vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sunflower Cataract with Lens Extraction: Sunflower cataract is characterized by the presence of a central, sunflower-like opacity on the lens. It is commonly associated with conditions such as Wilson's disease, where copper deposits on the lens. Treatment typically involves surgical removal of the cataractous lens (lens extraction), often followed by the implantation of an artificial intraocular lens (IOL).

 

Option B. Rosette Cataract with Control of Blood Sugar Level: A rosette cataract usually forms a star-shaped pattern and is often associated with trauma. While controlling blood sugar levels is essential for patients with diabetes to prevent the progression of diabetic retinopathy and other complications, it may not reverse the changes already present in the lens.

 

Option D. Zonular Cataract with Lensectomy: Zonular cataract refers to the opacities that affect the zone or region of the lens. A lensectomy involves the surgical removal of the lens, which can be applied to different types of cataracts, often followed by the placement of an IOL.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The diagnosis of cataracts involves a thorough examination of the lens using slit-lamp microscopy or similar diagnostic tools. Understanding the underlying causes, such as diabetes, and recognizing the specific patterns associated with different types of cataracts are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment, which often involves surgery to restore vision. Regular monitoring and management of blood sugar levels are essential in diabetic patients to prevent or slow the progression of diabetic cataracts.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in low insulin: glucagon ratio?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Activation of hormone-sensitive lipase

 

In a fasting state, insulin decreases and glucagon increases, hence there is Low insulin: glucagon ratio. Since insulin has an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase, low insulin: glucagon ratio results in the activation of hormone-sensitive lipase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activation of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is promoted by insulin, but here it is low. Lipoprotein lipase enzyme breaks triglycerides (TGs) of Lipoproteins (Chylomicrons and VLDL) to give 3 fatty acids and glycerol.

 

Option B. Activation of glycogen synthase is promoted by insulin (fed state). In low insulin: glucagon ratio, glycogen synthase activity will be reduced, leading to decreased glycogenesis.

 

Option C. Activation of phosphoructokinase-1 (PFK1) is promoted by insulin (fed state). PFK1 is a rate-regulating enzyme in glycolysis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hormone-sensitive lipase is present inside the cells of adipose tissues. Stored triglycerides in adipose tissues are broken by HSL into 3 fatty acids and glycerol. 3 fatty acids go in blood and then are taken by liver where β- Oxidation of fatty acids (catabolic) occurs to give energy in Liver.

 

In diabetic patients, low insulin level which causes an increase in HSL activity, promoting the breakdown of lipids and the release of FFAs from adipose tissue. HSL activity is accelerated by hormones like epinephrine, norepinephrine, glucagon, ACTH, TSH, GH, ADH, and melanocyte-stimulating hormones (MSH).

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kaposi sarcoma

 

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a common malignancy in patients with HIV/AIDS. It is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and typically presents as painless or painful, violaceous (purple) lesions on the skin and mucous membranes, including the oral cavity. The image shows such a lesion on the palate, which is characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma. These lesions are vascular in nature and can vary in color from red to purple, often with a raised or nodular appearance. In HIV patients, Kaposi sarcoma is an AIDS-defining condition and is often seen in those with significant immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer usually occurs in sun-exposed areas of the skin and rarely affects mucous membranes. It typically presents as a pearly or waxy bump, not as multiple purple lesions.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: While melanomas can appear as pigmented lesions, they are usually black or brown and rarely present as multiple violaceous lesions in the oral cavity.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer can occur in the oral cavity but usually presents as a non-healing ulcer or a raised, firm, scaly plaque. It does not have the characteristic color and appearance of Kaposi sarcoma lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi sarcoma should be suspected in HIV patients presenting with violaceous lesions on the skin or mucous membranes. It is an AIDS-defining condition associated with HHV-8 infection.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with cola colored urine and had a history of skin infection few days back. His creatinine value was initially 2.5 mg/dl but even after 3 weeks of treatment it increased to 4.5 mg/dl. Which of the following is a likely kidney biopsy finding on electron microscopy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subepithelial deposits

 

A child with skin infection followed by passage of cola colored urine is suggestive of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis. The worsening of creatinine from 2.5mg/dl to 4.5 mg/dl is suggestive of worsen of his condition in a short span of time. This prompts a diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

 

Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN):

 

  • Pathology: RPGN is characterized by the presence of crescents in the glomeruli, which are formed by the proliferation of parietal epithelial cells and infiltration of monocytes and macrophages.
  • Clinical Features: Rapid deterioration of renal function, often following an infection such as streptococcal throat or skin infection.
  • Crescents can be seen on light microscopy in RPGN (especially crescentic PSGN).
  • But electron microscopy (EM) will still show subepithelial deposits, which is diagnostic of PSGN.
  • So, even though the clinical course is RPGN, the question asked what you see on EM - hence the correct answer is Subepithelial deposits
  • Type I: Anti-GBM disease (Goodpasture syndrome)
  • Type II: Immune complex-mediated (e.g., PSGN, lupus nephritis)
  • Type III: Pauci-immune (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, also known as Wegener’s)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subendothelial deposits: Seen in conditions like lupus nephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, not typical for RPGN following PSGN.

 

Option C. Crescents in glomeruli: Suggest RPGN, but the specific hallmark of PSGN is subepithelial humps (crescents may appear if it evolves into RPGN, but not diagnostic)

 

Option D. Mesangial deposits: Commonly seen in IgA nephropathy and other mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis, not specific for RPGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of crescents in the glomeruli on kidney biopsy is characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), especially in a patient with worsening renal function following an episode of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. However, crescents can be seen on light microscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+

 

ER+ is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients as it is seen with luminal A and B subtypes of the breast cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High Ki67+: High Ki67+ indicates a high proliferative index, which is associated with more aggressive tumors and a poorer prognosis.

 

Option C. BRCA1+: BRCA1 mutation is associated with an increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers, and these cancers tend to be more aggressive.

 

Option D. P53+: P53 mutations are associated with a variety of cancers and typically indicate a poorer prognosis due to the loss of normal p53 tumor suppressor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER-positive status in breast cancer is a good prognostic factor because it indicates a slower-growing tumor that is likely to respond well to hormone therapy.

 

Why ER⁺ is a Good Prognostic Factor:

 

  1. Slower tumor growth:
    • ER⁺ tumors tend to grow more slowly than ER⁻ tumors.
  2. Better treatment response:
    • ER⁺ cancers respond well to hormonal therapies such as:
    • Tamoxifen
    • Aromatase inhibitors
  3. Lower recurrence risk:
    • Hormone receptor–positive cancers have a lower risk of early recurrence.
  4. Overall survival:
    • Patients with ER⁺ tumors generally have better overall survival.

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a history of fever and cough for 5 days. On auscultation, crepts were heard on right side. Chest X-ray is given below. Mark the correct finding in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right middle lobe consolidation

 

Patient presenting with a history of fever and cough for 5 days suggests diagnosis pneumonia. The chest X-ray showing opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation.

 

Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border. In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.

 

 

The left image is a normal chest radiograph with the red line indicating the silhouette of the right heart border and right middle lobe.

 

The right image shows the same red line delineating where the silhouette should be, but is lost due to consolidation in the right middle lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right middle lobe consolidation is suggested by the obscuration of the right heart border and the specific location of opacity on the chest X-ray, aligned with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory symptoms. This finding is crucial for diagnosing the specific location of pneumonia, guiding appropriate treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infant mortality rate

 

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is considered the most sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community. IMR reflects the overall health and well-being of infants and the quality of maternal and infant care services. It is a comprehensive measure that can indicate various aspects of public health, including nutritional status, access to medical care, public health practices, and the socio-economic conditions of the community.

 

IMR = (Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births) × 1000.

 

SRS 2022-23 Latest data

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is seen for primary amenorrhea. She has not development of breasts or hair in the pubic or axillary region. Her height is 155cm and her weight is 48 kg. She has bilateral inguinal masses. On USG examination, the uterus, fallopian tube, and ovary are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism

 

Explanation:

 

  • The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.
  • In this question, bilateral inguinal masses (undescended testis), absent ovary, also there is absent uterus and fallopian tubes, all pointing to a conclusion that patient can be of XY karyotype. Because if female reproductive tract is absent, there must be mullerian inhibiting substance present which comes from Y chromosome.
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism can occur in disorders such as FSH or LH receptor mutations.
  • Now, in a XY individual with a defect in LH/hCG receptor, testis’ Sertoli cells will produce Anti-mullerian hormone which will not let uterus, fallopian tube, cervix, upper vagina to develop. Leydi cells will not produce testosterone due to which wolffian duct development is impaired and the testes fail to descend. They appear female at birth and at puberty present with primary amenorrhea. They lack breast development and pubic hair development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome: Androgen insensitivity syndrome individuals have normal breast development.

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: Turner's syndrome karyotype is XO.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovary syndrome: In Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) ovary and uterus is present, so can’t be answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism can present as primary amenorrhea with absent uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries in an XY individual, with bilateral inguinal masses indicating undescended testes.

questions.text: A patient with history of alcoholism presented with right hypochondriac pain and fever. He had an episode of diarrhoea 1 week prior. USG abdomen reveals a liver abscess of around 25 cc in right lobe. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medical management

 

  • This patient with USG revealing abscess in the liver most likely has an amebic liver abscess. Since next best is asked, medical management should be started first.

 

Amoebic liver abscess:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PAIR: PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration) is more commonly used for hydatid cysts and not the first-line treatment for amoebic liver abscesses.

 

Option B. Surgery: Surgical intervention is generally reserved for cases where there is no response to medical treatment or complications arise.

 

Option D. Percutaneous drainage: This can be considered if the abscess is large, at risk of rupture, or if there is no response to medical management. However, initial treatment should be medical management with antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For amoebic liver abscess, initial management should always begin with medical therapy using metronidazole, chloroquine, and diloxanide furoate.
  •  Drainage or aspiration is considered based on the size and risk of rupture of the abscess.

questions.text: A patient was given digoxin. He started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4 mg/dL. The plasma therapeutic range is 1 mg/dL. If the half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, how long one should wait before resuming the treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 80 hours

 

To determine how long it will take for the patient's serum digoxin concentration to decrease to a therapeutic level (1 mg/dL) from 4 mg/dL, we need to consider the drug's half-life. The half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, which means that every 40 hours, the concentration of the drug in the plasma will be reduced by half.

 

  • Initial concentration: 4 mg/dL
  • Therapeutic concentration: 1 mg/dL
  • Half-life of digoxin: 40 hours

 

We can use the concept of half-lives to calculate the time needed:

 

  1. After the first half-life (40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 4 mg/dL to 2 mg/dL.
  2. After the second half-life (another 40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 2 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL.

 

Therefore, it will take 80 hours for the digoxin concentration to fall from 4 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL, which is within the therapeutic range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient experiencing side effects from digoxin with a serum concentration of 4 mg/dL, wait 80 hours (two half-lives) for the concentration to decrease to the therapeutic range before resuming treatment.

choices.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter
Fluorescein dye - visualised under green filter

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

 

he most likely correct combination for fluorescein dye visualization is Fluorescein dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter. Fluorescein is a yellow dye that, when applied to the eye, emits a bright green fluorescence when illuminated with blue light from a cobalt blue filter. It's commonly used in ophthalmology to detect corneal abrasions, ulcers, or foreign bodies and to assess contact lens fit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a green filter: Lissamine Green is a dye that stains devitalized cells and mucous filaments and is used to visualize damage to the conjunctiva and cornea, particularly in dry eye syndrome. It is typically observed under white light, not a green filter, so this combination is not standard.

 

Option C. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a cobalt blue filter: This is not the standard practice for visualizing Lissamine Green dye. This dye is usually observed under white light, as the cobalt blue filter is specifically used to excite fluorescence from fluorescein dye.

 

Option D. Fluorescein dye - visualized under a green filter: Fluorescein dye is usually visualized under a blue light, not a green filter. When fluorescein is viewed under a green filter, the fluorescence is typically not visible because the green filter would block the green fluorescence emitted by the fluorescein dye.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In ophthalmology, different dyes and filters are used to aid in the diagnosis of various conditions. Fluorescein dye is visualized using a cobalt blue filter, which causes it to fluoresce and highlights areas of corneal compromise. It is crucial to use the appropriate filter for each dye to accurately diagnose and assess ocular surface disorders.

choices.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure
Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.text: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isolate for 6 days

 

The given scenario points to the diagnosis of chickenpox.

 

In a boys' hostel, everyone is not in the high-risk groups for severe varicella infection. For the management of suspected cases in this situation, isolation for 6 days from the onset of the rash is the appropriate measure to prevent further spread of the infection. Acyclovir and ZIG are not necessary for healthy individuals.

 

Varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is indicated as prophylaxis for individuals at high risk like Immunocompromised individuals, Pregnant women and Newborns.

 

 

 

Note –

 

Acyclovir: Antiviral treatment with acyclovir is generally reserved for high-risk groups or severe cases.

 

VZIG (Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin): VZIG is indicated for individuals at high risk of severe varicella infection, such as immunocompromised individuals, pregnant women, and newborns. It is not routinely given to healthy individuals in a setting like a boys' hostel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For managing a chickenpox outbreak in a boys' hostel, the best step is to isolate affected individuals for 6 days from the onset of the rash. This helps prevent the spread of the virus. Antiviral treatments and immunoglobulins are reserved for high-risk individuals.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD as he is always fatigued and has muscle cramps after exercise and the blood sample collected soon after exercise showed low glucose and lactate level. He became normal after resting for a while. Which of the following diseases is he most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McArdle disease

 

McArdle disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type V): This condition is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme myophosphorylase, which is essential for breaking down glycogen into glucose for energy during exercise. In McArdle disease, individuals experience muscle cramps, fatigue, and myoglobinuria (the presence of myoglobin in the urine) after exercise due to the inability to access stored glycogen for energy. Low glucose levels and lactate buildup can occur during exercise in individuals with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hers disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI): Hers disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme liver glycogen phosphorylase. It primarily affects the liver and leads to difficulties in releasing glucose from glycogen stores in the liver. This condition typically does not manifest with muscle symptoms like cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Option C. Cori's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III): Cori's disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme debranching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and muscles and can lead to muscle weakness, liver enlargement, and hypoglycemia. However, it does not typically present with the specific exercise-induced symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Andersen disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV): Andersen disease is a rare condition caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glycogen branching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and can result in liver fibrosis. It does not typically cause muscle cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. An X-ray was ordered and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cephalhematoma

 

Cephalohematomas are traumatic subperiosteal hematoma of the skull that are usually caused by birth injury. They are bound between the periosteum and cranium, and therefore cannot cross sutures. Being bound by a suture line distinguishes them from subgaleal hematoma, which can cross sutures.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subgaleal hematoma: This hematoma is located beneath the scalp's aponeurotic layer and can spread widely over the skull, which is not confined by suture lines. Therefore, it is less likely to present as a localized swelling.

 

Option C. Encephalocele: This is a neural tube defect characterized by the herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull. It is usually more severe and associated with neurological deficits.

 

Option D. Caput Succedaneum: This refers to swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp, which develops as the baby travels through the birth canal. This swelling can cross suture lines and typically resolves without intervention within the first few days of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cephalhematoma is a localized hematoma under the periosteum of the skull bone in newborns, confined by suture lines and typically associated with birth trauma.

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back and feels relieved if she lies on her side or when walks. What is the most likely reason behind this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVC compression

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness that the pregnant woman experiences when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. In the supine position during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the IVC, which can decrease venous return to the heart. This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, leads to reduced cardiac output and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness, and a decreased supply of oxygen and nutrients to vital organs.

 

  • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness.
  • Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: This would present with symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and altered mental status, not positional dizziness relieved by lying on the side.

 

Option C. Heavy meals: While heavy meals can cause discomfort, they are unlikely to cause the specific positional symptoms described.

 

Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: This might cause symptoms such as swelling and discomfort in the legs but not the specific positional dizziness described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior vena cava compression by the gravid uterus in late pregnancy can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, leading to light-headedness and dizziness when lying on the back, which is relieved by lying on the side or walking.

questions.text: Mark the option which develops from the structure marked A? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median umbilical ligament

 

Marked structure A is the allantois, which forms the urachus, which in turn gives rise to the median umbilical ligament.

 

The median umbilical ligament represents the remnant of the urachus (also known as the median umbilical fold). The urachus is a tubular structure that connects the fetal bladder to the umbilical cord and allows for the drainage of urine produced by the fetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid.

 

After birth, the urachus becomes non-functional and fibroses to form the median umbilical ligament. It extends from the apex of the bladder to the umbilicus within the median umbilical fold.

 

The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial umbilical ligament: These are the remnants of the occluded parts of the umbilical arteries. In fetal life, the umbilical arteries arise from the internal iliac arteries and pass to the umbilical cord, carrying deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

 

  • In the adult, they persist as the medial umbilical ligaments, which are paired fibrous bands on the inner surface of the anterior abdominal wall, running from the bladder to the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum arises from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct (or omphalomesenteric duct), which connects the yolk sac to the midgut lumen during embryonic development. It usually disappears by the 7th week of embryonic life.

 

  • If a portion of the vitelline duct remains, it can manifest as a Meckel's diverticulum. It's found in approximately 2% of the population and is often described by the "rule of 2s" - 2 inches long, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2% of the population, and can present with two types of epithelia (gastric and pancreatic).

 

Option D. Ligamentum teres (Round ligament of the liver):

 

  • The ligamentum teres represents the obliterated remnant of the left umbilical vein. During fetal development, the left umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta directly to the fetal heart, bypassing the liver through the ductus venosus.
  • After birth, the need for this shunt ceases, and the ductus venosus along with the left umbilical vein close up. The ligamentum teres runs in the free margin of the falciform ligament, connecting the umbilicus to the anterior aspect of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tracking of blood pressure

 

The phenomenon described in the question is known as tracking of blood pressure. This term refers to the tendency for individuals to maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values over time. Essentially, individuals with lower blood pressure in childhood tend to have lower blood pressure in adulthood, and those with higher blood pressure in childhood tend to have higher blood pressure in adulthood.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rule of halves: This concept refers to the observation that about half of those with hypertension are aware of their condition, half of those aware are treated, and half of those treated are adequately controlled. It is not directly related to the tracking phenomenon described.

 

 

Option C. The WHO STEPwise approach: approach to surveillance (STEPS) is an internationally comparable, standardized and integrated surveillance tool through which countries can collect, analyse and disseminate core information on noncommunicable diseases (NCDs).

 

Option D. Primordial approach: Primordial prevention refers to measures taken to prevent the development of risk factors in a population, thereby reducing the overall incidence of disease. This concept is related to preventing the onset of risk factors and diseases, rather than tracking existing conditions over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracking of blood pressure describes the observation that individuals maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values from childhood to adulthood. This means that blood pressure levels tend to remain consistent relative to peers over time.

questions.text: A woman came to OPD with a newborn who has complaints of chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The paediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lecithin

 

Newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome which is due to surfactant deficiency, i.e., lecithin.

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Hyaline Membrane Disease)

 

 

The newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, which is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and maintaining proper lung function. Lecithin, also known as dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC), is the most important component of surfactant. A deficiency in lecithin leads to insufficient surfactant production, resulting in alveolar collapse, reduced functional residual capacity (FRC), and the clinical features observed in RDS.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Dipalmitoyl inositol: This is not a component of surfactant. The main components of surfactant are phospholipids like lecithin and other proteins.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While present in amniotic fluid and used in the lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio to assess fetal lung maturity, it is not the primary component of surfactant.

 

Option D. Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylethanolamine: This is a phospholipid but not a primary component of surfactant involved in preventing alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant, particularly lecithin (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

 

  • Patient with sudden-onset severe chest pain, with a difference in blood pressure between the two limbs, and a widened mediastinum on x-ray suggests a diagnosis of acute aortic dissection.
  • AORTIC DISSECTION is tear in intima of aorta

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): ACS includes conditions such as myocardial infarction and unstable angina. These conditions typically present with chest pain but do not usually cause blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism presents with sudden onset dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and signs of right heart strain. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option D. Esophageal Rupture: Esophageal rupture can present with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and signs of sepsis. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs. It may cause mediastinal widening but would more likely present with other signs such as subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
  • Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.

questions.text: Shown in image is an orthopedic procedure being performed. Identity the procedure? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy

 

INTRAOSSEOUS THERAPY 

 

  • Intraosseous access is a rapid and effective method to deliver fluids, medications, and blood products directly into the bone marrow when intravenous access is difficult or impossible, especially in emergency situations.
  • Interosseous therapy is most commonly used in pediatric patients but can also be used in adults. 
  • The procedure involves inserting a needle or catheter through the skin and into the bone, typically in the tibia or humerus bones.
  • A needle is inserted at 90° to the medial surface of the tibia, and it is connected to a tube, suggesting fluid administration or aspiration.
  • Some common indications for IO therapy include:
    • Cardiac arrest or other life-threatening emergencies
    • Severe dehydration or shock
    • Patients with difficult venous access, such as obese or severely dehydrated patients or patients with vascular access issues due to scarring, burns, or other injuries.
    • Emergency situations such as during disasters or mass casualty incidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraosseous abscess drainage: A drainage procedure usually involves a larger incision or different type of instrument for effective drainage.


Option C. Diagnostic biopsy: A bone biopsy involves taking a tissue sample for pathological examination. While a needle is used, the setup with continuous tubing for fluid administration is not typical for a routine diagnostic biopsy.
 

Option D. Intraosseous cannulation for pain relief: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation is a rapid method to administer medications through the bone marrow cavity in a critically ill or an injured patient. The procedure is both safe and effective in children and adults. The preferred site for the creation of intraosseous (IO) access is usually the shin. A local anesthetic is injected into the shin. Next, a cannula is inserted into the shin until a popping sensation is felt. Once the attempt is successful, the cannula is connected to the intravenous (IV) infusion set, which is a collection of sterile devices designed to conduct fluids from the IV fluid container to a patient's venous system. Indications for IO access includes arrhythmias, severe haemorrhage, septic shock, respiratory failure, severe dehydration, diabetic ketoacidosis, and burns. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.text: A young male came to the hospital with a clean-cut wound without any bleeding. The patient received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the best management for this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Single-dose tetanus toxoid

 

The patient presents with a clean-cut wound and has a history of receiving a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. Based on the guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis, the appropriate management for this patient falls under the category where the patient has received a complete course of tetanus vaccination more than 5 years ago but less than 10 years ago.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Management of Tetanus-Prone Wounds:

 

 

CC = Complete course; TIG = Tetanus Immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaptonuria

 

OPTION B: Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic feature of alkaptonuria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has come with history of lower back pain and stiffness since 3 months. His ESR and CRP levels are raised. He has mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion is 3 cms. History of red eye is also there. The most likely diagnosis from amongst the following would be:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton (sacroiliac joint and spine) with variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Males are affected more frequently than females.
    • Age of onset is between 15-25 years.
    • The initial symptom is usually dull pain, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, accompanied by low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • The most common extra-articular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis) occurring in 30%.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
  • Etiology:
    • HLA B27 positive in more than 90 % cases
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • Bamboo spine (bony ankyloses)
    • Squaring of vertebrae
    • Inter-spinous ligament calcification: dagger sign
    • Facet calcification of joints + inter spinous ligament Trolley Track Sign
    • Sclerosed vertebral edges: romanus sign

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity.

 

 

The diagnostic histological feature is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. It either occurs in one bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic).

 

 

Etiology is genetic infection by paramyxovirus (measles and respiratory syncytial virus). There is increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Affects men > 50 years more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal. Increased marker of bone formation (e.g. S. alkaline phosphatase and S. osteocalcin). Increased markers of bone resorption. X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening, coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen.

 

 

Option B. Healed TB. The remineralization of the vertebral body, sharpening of disc margins, reduction of pre-/paravertebral shadows, and osseous/fibro-osseous fusion are signs of healing on X-rays but are unreliable. The remineralization can be appreciated after 2-3 months of ATT. Complete resolution of pre-/paravertebral collections, marrow edema of vertebra, and its replacement by fat/calcification on contrast MRI are observed with healing of spine TB. 

 

 

Serial radiographs showing progression of bony healing and complete resolution of cold abscess

 

Option C. DISH. Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spondyloarthropathy, also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis. It is a non-inflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses. The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankyloses occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected. In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax. The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine. The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine. Morning stiffness is also noticed in around 2/3rd of patients. Increased incidence of dysphagia is also reported in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Presence of lower back pain and stiffness since months, raised levels of ESR and CRP, mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion, with history of red eye are suggestive of presence of ankylosing spondylitis.

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents in OPD with complaints of cyclical pain in abdomen.  On examination, a suprapubic bulge can be seen in the pelvic area. PR examination reveals a swelling in the anterior aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

The given case scenario points to a diagnosis of cryptomenorrhea, due to an imperforate hymen.

 

Cryptomenorrhea is a condition in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract resulting in either hematometra (blood collection within the uterus) or hematocolpos (blood collection within vagina). In the long term, it may result in endometriosis, urinary retention and infertility.

 

IMPERFORATE HYMEN

 

  • Presents as cryptomenorrhea
  • H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea
  • Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen
  • On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision.

 

 

In Imperforate hymen, swelling is seen all along the length of the vagina on PR examination as there is hematocolpos (blood in the vagina)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse vaginal septum: Transverse vaginal septum is a Müllerian anomaly. On examination, blind vagina is found. No tense blue hymen and cough impulse will be absent. Diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI

 

Option B. Vaginal atresia: If vaginal introitus is not seen, then it’s vaginal atresia

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: Cervical agenesis will show absence of a cervix is on examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imperforate hymen presents with cryptomenorrhea, characterized by cyclical abdominal pain and hematocolpos due to obstruction of menstrual flow, with a suprapubic bulge and anterior swelling palpable on PR examination.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the image given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dermoid

 

Ocular dermoids are choristomas, containing tissue not normally found in the area. They often appear as round, firm, and sometimes hair-bearing lesions on the surface of the eye or near the eyelids as given in the image. Dermoids can vary in size and may cause astigmatism if they press against the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pterygium: This is a benign growth of conjunctival tissue that extends onto the cornea. It often presents as a wedge-shaped, fleshy growth and is usually found on the side closest to the nose. Pterygium is often associated with exposure to sunlight or wind, and its symptoms can include redness, irritation, or a feeling of something in the eye.

 

Option B. Pinguecula: Similar to a pterygium, a pinguecula is a benign, yellowish growth that occurs on the conjunctiva. It typically appears on the side of the eye nearest to the nose but does not grow onto the cornea. Pingueculae are also associated with long-term sun exposure and can cause irritation or dryness.

 

Option D. Dermolipoma: This is a type of choristoma, like dermoids, but it primarily consists of fatty tissue. Dermolipomas are usually located on the outer corner of the eye and appear as soft, yellowish masses. They are generally benign and asymptomatic, but their size and location can occasionally cause cosmetic or functional concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and differentiating between various ocular surface lesions is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management. This involves understanding their typical presentations, etiologies, and potential complications. Regular eye examinations and proper eye protection, especially from UV light, are important for eye health.

questions.text: Which of the following refractory condition is depicted in the figure.  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Astigmatism

 

Astigmatism occurs when the cornea or lens has an irregular shape, preventing light from focusing properly on the retina. This leads to blurred or distorted vision at all distances. Common symptoms include eyestrain, headaches, and difficulty seeing at night.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbyopia: This is a common condition associated with aging, where the eye's lens loses its ability to change shape to focus on close objects. Symptoms include difficulty reading small print or having to hold reading material farther away. Presbyopia typically starts to become noticeable in the early to mid-40s.

 

Option B. Myopia (Nearsightedness): This condition occurs when the eye is longer than normal or has a cornea that is too curved. As a result, light rays focus in front of the retina instead of on it. This leads to distant objects appearing blurry while close objects are seen clearly. Myopia is often identified in childhood or adolescence and can worsen during periods of rapid growth.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia (Farsightedness): In this condition, the eye is shorter than normal, or the cornea is not curved enough, causing light to focus behind the retina. This makes close objects appear blurry, while distant objects are usually seen clearly. Children often have some degree of hypermetropia, which can decrease as the eye grows and lengthens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and understanding these refractive conditions is essential for early detection and management. Regular eye examinations are crucial, as they allow for the timely prescription of corrective lenses or other treatments. Each condition affects vision in a unique way, and understanding these differences is key in providing effective patient care and guidance.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with varicose veins comes to OPD with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C4a

 

  • The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C2:

 

  • Description: Varicose veins without any additional skin changes or complications.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which indicates a more advanced stage than C2.

 

Option B. C3:

 

  • Description: Presence of oedema without skin changes.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, not just oedema.

 

Option D. C4b:

 

  • Description: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which is classified under C4a, not the more severe skin changes seen in C4b.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders, the presence of eczema or pigmentation in a patient with varicose veins is classified as stage C4a.

questions.text: Among the given options, murmur given in the image is associated with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mitral Regurgitation

 

The image provided indicates a murmur occurring between S1 and S2, which is described as a pan-systolic murmur. This type of murmur spans the entirety of systole.

 

Mitral Regurgitation produces a pan-systolic murmur due to the backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium throughout systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic Regurgitation: Characterized by an early diastolic murmur due to backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.

 

Option C. Mitral Stenosis: Characterized by a mid-diastolic murmur due to obstructed blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Option D. Aortic Stenosis: Characterized by an ejection systolic murmur due to turbulent blood flow across a narrowed aortic valve during systole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral regurgitation is associated with a pan-systolic murmur, which is present throughout the systole and heard between the S1 and S2 heart sounds.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the following histological image: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glomerulus

 

The above histology image shows the glomerulus of a nephron.

 

Glomerulus is a tuft of capillaries located within Bowman's capsule in the renal cortex of the kidney. Here are the key histological features of the glomerulus:

 

  • Capillary Endothelium: The innermost layer of the glomerulus consists of fenestrated endothelial cells. These fenestrations or pores allow plasma (minus the larger proteins) to move from the blood into Bowman's space.
  • Basement Membrane: Surrounding the endothelial cells is the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). It is a specialized extracellular matrix made up of type IV collagen, laminin, proteoglycans, and other glycoproteins. The GBM serves as a filter, preventing the passage of large proteins and cells but allowing smaller molecules to pass through.
  • Podocytes: These specialized epithelial cells cover the outer surface of the glomerular capillaries. They have foot processes called "pedicels" which interdigitate with one another, leaving filtration slits between them. The slit diaphragm, formed by intercellular junctions between adjacent pedicels, provides an additional barrier to the filtration of plasma proteins.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillaries of the glomerulus, mesangial cells have phagocytic activity and help in the structural support of the capillaries. They can also contract, thus regulating the blood flow through the glomerulus. Additionally, mesangial cells produce extracellular matrix components.
  • Juxtaglomerular Cells: These specialized smooth muscle cells are found in the afferent arteriole at the point of entry into the glomerulus. They secrete renin, a crucial enzyme in the renin-angiotensin system which regulates blood pressure.
  • Macula Densa: Although not a part of the glomerulus, the macula densa is closely related. It is a group of tall, closely packed cells in the distal convoluted tubule that detect changes in the sodium chloride levels in the filtrate and communicate with the juxtaglomerular cells to regulate renin secretion.
  • Bowman's Capsule: This is a double-layered capsule that surrounds the glomerulus. The inner layer, or visceral layer, is composed of podocytes. The outer layer, or parietal layer, is made up of a simple squamous epithelium. Between these two layers is the Bowman's space, into which the filtrate from the blood accumulates before moving into the renal tubules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leydig Cells, also known as interstitial cells of Leydig, are present in the interstitial connective between seminiferous tubules.

 

The testis contains numerous seminiferous tubules separated by connective tissue in between.

 

Seminiferous tubules are lined by several spermatogonia cells, which produce spermatozoa, and Sertoli (sustentacular) cells, which have a supportive function.The connective tissue in between the tubules is made up of Leydig cells, collagen fibers, fibroblasts, macrophages, mast cells, blood vessels, and lymphatics. Leydig cells are large, round, or polyhedral cells with eccentric nuclei. They are lightly stained and often have a foamy appearance. They secrete testosterone upon stimulation by luteinizing hormone from the anterior pituitary.

 

The image below shows seminiferous tubules and Leydig cells

 

 

Option B: Islets of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

 

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and contain numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. The islet cells are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

 

﻿﻿ The islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells:

 

  • α or A cells - located peripherally and secrete glucagon
  • β or B cells - located centrally and produce insulin
  • δ or D cells - scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin

 

The image given below shows the islets of Langerhans

 

 

Option C: The thymic medulla contains fewer lymphocytes than the cortex, and the epithelial cells (E) located here have different morphology and function. The most characteristic feature of the medulla in humans is the presence of thymic (Hassall) corpuscles (H). These are of variable size and contain aggregates of thymic epithelial cells releasing many cytokines important within the medullary microenvironment, especially for dendritic cell activity and for the differentiation of regulatory T cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glomerulus consists of a network of capillaries encased within Bowman's capsule, playing a key role in blood filtration.

questions.text: A female presented in dermatology OPD with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best step among the following options? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Evaluate for hyperandrogenism

 

  • Since the patient is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy, syndromes associated with acne should be evaluated and ruled out to reach a diagnosis. One of the important syndrome is HAIR-AN syndrome.
  • Hence, the next best step would be to evaluate for hyperandrogenism.

 

Important Syndromes Associated with Acne:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Looking for dietary triggers: It could be considered, but this should already be taken care of before prescribing isotretinoin and antibiotics.

 

Option C. Checking for antibiotic resistance: This seems an appropriate step but can’t prioritize over ruling out HAIR-AN syndrome in this patient.

 

Option D. Drug triggers are unlikely to be the primary cause of acne patient who is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. Moreover, lesions in Drug-induced acne are monomorphic and comedones are absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When faced with a female patient whose acne has not improved with oral isotretinoin and antibiotics, the next best step is to evaluate for hyperandrogenism, which can point to an underlying hormonal cause such as PCOS, necessitating a different treatment approach.

 

References: Williams Gynaecology 4th edition: page no 392-394

questions.text: A family consumes only polished rice. Which of the following combination of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect will be present in this family? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine – Transketolase

 

This is the correct combination. Consuming polished rice can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Transketolase is an enzyme involved in thiamine-dependent reactions, and its activity can be affected by thiamine deficiency, leading to various health issues, including beriberi, which is associated with thiamine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin - Glutathione Reductase: This combination is not relevant to the consumption of polished rice. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and glutathione reductase is not directly related to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine - Transaminase: While thiamine deficiency can affect various enzymes, transaminase is not specifically associated with thiamine deficiency related to polished rice consumption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin - Transketolase: This combination is not relevant to polished rice consumption. Riboflavin deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and transketolase is not directly related to riboflavin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The consumption of polished rice leads to thiamine deficiency which leads to defective transketolase activity.

 

Polished rice undergoes milling, which removes the outer bran layer rich in B vitamins and other nutrients

questions.text: A child presents with erythematous scaly patches in the perioral region, mucosal ulcers, and impaired epithelial wound healing. What is the likely mineral deficiency associated with this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc deficiency

 

The clinical features of periorificial dermatitis and stomatitis in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, seen in zinc deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency - Most common micronutrient deficiency globally. It presents with iron-deficiency anemia. It presents clinically with pallor, fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, light-headedness.

 

Option C. Calcium deficiency - Leads to rickets in children. Apart from clinical vignette of rickets there can be Muscle cramps and stiffness, Tingling and Numbness, Tetany.

 

Option D. Copper deficiency - Leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia, and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency disorder- Acrodermatitis enteropathica

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other group consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. Then Bladder cancer cases were identified from both the groups in the current time. What type of study is being performed? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retrospective cohort study

 

The study given here is a retrospective cohort study.

 

A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before commencing the investigations and study.

 

The given question tells that the workers in the industry were divided into two groups, first are those who are directly exposed and second are clerical staff who are not directly exposed to the suspected carcinogen.

 

The incidence of bladder cancer among these two groups is studied going backward tracking their records. Therefore, it’s a retrospective cohort study.

 

A simple comparison between these studies and an example is shown below:
 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prospective cohort study: Involves following a group over a time span till the development of outcome.

 

Option C. Case-control study: A case-control study involves comparing groups with a specific outcome (cases) with a rather healthy group (controls) and assessing their exposure history. In this case, workers are divided into groups based on their exposure status and the development of bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Intervention and response: Is not a type of epidemiological study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A retrospective cohort study involves examining historical data to investigate the relationship between exposure and outcomes. In this scenario, it is used to study the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer among workers over a 20-year period.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

 

  • Tilt the patient’s head back by pushing down on the forehead.
  • Place the tips of your index and middle fingers under the chin and pull up on the mandible (not on the soft tissues). This lifts the tongue away from the posterior pharynx and improves airway patency.

 

There is no absolute contraindication to it but Suspected cervical injury is a relative contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: Lift the mandible upward with your fingers, at least until the lower incisors are higher than the upper incisors. This maneuver lifts the tongue along with the mandible, thus relieving upper airway obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Manual inline stabilization: is a neck immobilisation technique in a natural position achieved by using the fingers and palms of both hands to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to gently counteract the forces of airway intervention

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to the clinic. She already has twins by normal delivery. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G2P1

 

In obstetric history, gravida (G) refers to the number of pregnancies a woman has had, including the current pregnancy, regardless of the outcome or duration. Parity (P) refers to the number of pregnancies that have reached the period of viability (28 weeks in India). Each pregnancy is counted once, regardless of the number of fetuses (e.g., twins count as one pregnancy).

 

  • Gravida (G): Number of pregnancies, including the current one.
  • Parity (P): Number of pregnancies that have reached viability (28 weeks or more), not including the current pregnancy.

 

In this case:

 

  • The woman has had one previous pregnancy that resulted in the birth of twins.
  • She is currently pregnant with her second pregnancy.

 

Therefore, her obstetric score is:

 

  • G2 (Gravida 2): This is her second pregnancy.
  • P1 (Para 1): She has had one previous pregnancy that reached viability and resulted in the birth of twins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G3P2: This would imply she has had three pregnancies and two that reached viability, which is incorrect.

 

Option B. G3P1: This would imply she is in her third pregnancy, which is incorrect.

 

Option D. G2P2: This would imply she has had two previous pregnancies that reached viability, which is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obstetric scoring, twin pregnancies count as a single gravida, and the obstetric score for a woman with twins by normal delivery and currently pregnant should be G2P1.

choices.text: Bone marrow aspirate
Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)
Polymerase chain reaction

questions.text: A 62-year-old elderly male presented with persistent fatigue and lymph total leucocyte count of 50,000/µl. His peripheral smear was done and had the findings as shown. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

The given history of elderly male with leucocytosis and the peripheral smear showing “smudge cells” is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The diagnosis of CLL can be confirmed using flow cytometry demonstrating cells with CD5/CD23 expression.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow aspirate: While useful in some cases, it is not necessary for the initial diagnosis of CLL if flow cytometry can provide definitive results.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH is useful for detecting specific genetic abnormalities but is not the first step in confirming CLL.

 

Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR can detect specific genetic mutations but is not typically used for the initial diagnosis of CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a suspected case of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), especially with the presence of smudge cells on a peripheral smear, flow cytometry is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia, who did not respond to haloperidol and thioridazine, was started on drug A. After beginning treatment with drug A, the patient's psychotic symptoms improved; however, he developed sialorrhea, dyslipidemia, weight gain, and hyperglycemia. Which drug is most likely to be 'drug A'? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clozapine

 

The description of the patient's response and side effects suggests that 'drug A' is most likely Clozapine. Clozapine is known for its effectiveness in treatment-resistant schizophrenia, where other antipsychotics like haloperidol and thioridazine have failed. It is distinguished by its side effect profile, which includes sialorrhea (excessive salivation), significant weight gain, dyslipidemia (abnormal lipid levels), and hyperglycemia (high blood sugar). These side effects are more pronounced with Clozapine compared to other antipsychotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ziprasidone: While it is an atypical antipsychotic, Ziprasidone is less likely to cause significant weight gain and metabolic side effects compared to Clozapine.

 

Option C. Risperidone: Risperidone can cause weight gain and metabolic side effects, but it is less likely to cause sialorrhea and is not as commonly used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia as Clozapine.

 

Option D. Aripiprazole: Aripiprazole is known for having a more favorable metabolic side effect profile and is less likely to cause significant weight gain, dyslipidemia, and hyperglycemia compared to Clozapine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the treatment of treatment-resistant schizophrenia, Clozapine is often effective where other antipsychotics have failed. However, its use is associated with notable side effects including sialorrhea, significant weight gain, dyslipidemia, and hyperglycemia.

 

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 222-224.

choices.text: Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar Nerve Palsy
Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy
Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture
Knuckle bender splint; Median Nerve Palsy

questions.text: Correctly match the statement regarding the splint shown in image:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy

 

  • Cock-up splint is used for radial nerve palsy.

 

 

RADIAL NERVE INJURIES

 

  • Most common nerve damaged in human body.
  • Most common cause: Fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Shaft of Humerus divided into 3 parts:
    • Upper 1/3rd
    • Middle 1/3rd
    • Lower 1/3rd: Radial nerve injured (50%)
       
  • Holstein Lewis sign: Radial nerve injury in lower 1/3rd fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Paralysis of ECRL & ECRB will cause loss of wrist, thumb and finger extension, leading to Wrist drop.
  • Wrist drop occurs in low radial nerve palsy, which spares the elbow and wrist extension.
  • There is also loss of sensation over the dorsum of 1st web space.

 

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment is usually conservative, which includes analgesic medications like NSAIDs; corticosteroid injections; physiotherapy; and immobilization with cock-up splints for 2-4 weeks.
    • The patient recovers within 4 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Option C. Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s ischemic contracture. Turn buckle splint is used to produce gradual stretching over the contracted joint. It is used to treat stiff elbow and Volkmann’s ischemic contracture.

 

 

Option D. Knuckle bender splint; Median nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question is a dynamic cock-up splint, which is used in cases of radial nerve injuries (wrist drop).

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania tropica

 

 

Difference between Leishmania tropica and donovani is that tropica do not invade organs. It causes cutaneous leishmaniasis otherwise called as Delhi boil, Aleppo boil.

 

Following image shows an ulcer surrounded by erythema

 

 

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

 

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

 

 

LIFE CYCLE IS GIVEN OF FILARIA:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia causes babesiosis, a tick-borne disease, presents as a malaria-like illness with fever, chills, and hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cause diseases like African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) and American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease), presents with different clinical features, such as fever, swollen lymph nodes, and neurological symptoms in African trypanosomiasis while in Chagas disease, fever and swelling at the infection site, and cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Histoplasma (dimorphic fungus) causes histoplasmosis. Mostly affects the lungs and then can disseminate to other organs in immunocompromised individuals. Presents variably, but it does not typically cause an ulcer with erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of intermenstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria gonorrhoea

 

The history of multiple sexual partners and lower abdominal pain with discharge and intermenstrual bleed suggests a diagnosis of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, of which cause can be N. Gonorrhoea among the given options.

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

 

 

Treatment –

 

KIT 6 (Yellow) – Tab Cefixime 400mg 1 Tab

 

  • Tab Metronidazole 400 mg (1 tab BD x 1 days)
  •  Tab Doxycycline 100 mg (1 tab BD x 21 days)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex causes painful genital ulcers.

 

Option B. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis is seen in sexually inactive females

 

Option C. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents as intense pruritus and white discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections, with Neisseria gonorrhoeae being a major pathogen, especially in women with multiple sexual partners presenting with lower abdominal pain and intermenstrual bleeding.

choices.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH
