questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D – PAH

 

The correctly matched pair of substances and their renal clearance is option B.

 

 

The concentration of the substance changes as it passes through the tubules. Removing the substance from the filtrate is k/a tubular reabsorption and adding more of the substance to the filtrate is k/a tubular secretion.

 

Amount of the substance finally excreted = Amount Filtered + Secreted - Reabsorbed

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the renal handling of different substances such as PAH, inulin, bicarbonate, and glucose is crucial for assessing kidney function and diagnosing various renal disorders. Each substance's behavior in the nephron informs clinicians about different aspects of renal physiology, such as filtration rate and tubular function.

choices.text: Acute tubular necrosis

questions.text: A patient was undergoing a hysteroscopic removal of a submucosal fibroid, in which a fluid deficit of 2000 mL is estimated in a patient. What is the immediate complication of this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario depicts case of fluid overload, due to which pulmonary edema can develop.

 

  • During hysteroscopy, systemic absorption of uterine distension fluid occurs through open sinuses or vessels.
  • Fluid deficit can be estimated by manual calculation or by use of an automated fluid management system.
  • When using hypotonic solutions (like glycine), the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 1000mL for healthy patients and 750mL for elderly patients or those with medical comorbidities.
  • For normal saline, the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 2,500mL for healthy patients and 750mL for those with cardiovascular disease.
  • If excessive absorption of fluid occurs with a hypotonic fluid; obtain serum electrolytes and the patient should be evaluated for volume overload.
  • Asymptomatic hyponatremia can be treated with fluid restriction and careful monitoring of urine output.
  • Treatment of symptomatic hyponatremia requires infusion of 3% sodium chloride and managed in intensive care.
  • Fluid overload from normal saline can be managed by fluid restriction; IV furosemide (20-40mg) is indicated if there is clinical or radiological evidence of pulmonary edema

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Acute tubular necrosis: While fluid overload can contribute to kidney injury, acute tubular necrosis is not the immediate complication in this scenario.

 

Option B. DIC: Disseminated intravascular coagulation is a serious condition involving abnormal blood clotting but is not directly related to fluid overload from hysteroscopy.

 

Option D. Thromboembolism: Thromboembolism involves blood clots traveling to various parts of the body but is not the immediate consequence of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluid overload during hysteroscopic surgery can lead to pulmonary edema as an immediate complication due to excessive absorption of uterine distension fluid.

choices.text: Esophageal veins and left gastric veins
Left colic vein and middle colic veins

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension. With the above symptoms identify the anastomosis seen in between veins: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

 

In the given scenario of a patient with portal hypertension, anastomosis between esophageal veins and left gastric veins can be seen.

 

In portal hypertension, increased pressure within the portal venous system may result in the dilation of portal venous tributaries and reversed flow at sites of portosystemic anastomoses.

 

The patient's presentation of abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension suggests an obstruction of the portal venous system, leading to the formation of portosystemic anastomoses. These are communications between the portal venous system and systemic venous system, which allow blood from the abdominal organs to bypass the liver and flow directly into the systemic circulation.

 

The lower esophageal veins, which drain into the systemic circulation via the azygos system, can anastomose with the left gastric veins (which are part of the portal system). In the context of portal hypertension, such as from cirrhosis, the blood flow through this anastomosis increases, leading to the formation of esophageal varices. These are dilated veins in the esophagus and are at risk of rupture, which can result in significant and potentially fatal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left colic vein and middle colic veins:  Both these veins are tributaries of the inferior mesenteric vein and subsequently drain into the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: These veins aren't directly associated with the complications of portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Superior rectal and phrenic veins:  The superior rectal veins are branches of the inferior mesenteric vein and drain into the portal system, while the phrenic veins are systemic veins. However, these two veins do not directly anastomose.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not play a significant role in the portosystemic shunting seen in portal hypertension.

 

Option D. Sigmoid and superior rectal veins: The sigmoid veins and superior rectal veins both drain into the inferior mesenteric vein, which is a part of the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not contribute significantly to the clinical features of portal hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of Porto-systemic anastomoses and their clinical presentations are as follows:

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with throat pain, fever, and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve

 

The Jacobson nerve / tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Jacobson nerve = tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal (IX cranial nerve) – supplies middle ear mucosa. Referred otalgia from tonsillitis / pharyngitis / Cancers of base of tongue is due to this nerve common innervation (ear & pharynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Greater Auricular Nerve: Arises from the cervical plexus (C2, C3) and primarily innervates the skin over the parotid gland and mastoid region, not typically involved in referred ear pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal Nerve: A branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), which innervates the anterior auricle and external acoustic meatus, contributing to sensations in these areas but not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option D. Auricular Branch of Vagus Nerve: Also known as Arnold’s nerve, supplies the concha and part of the external auditory canal and could potentially contribute to referred otalgia, but not primarily responsible in cases of tonsillitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of proximal femur in a patient with pain hip. The deformity shown is:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

 

FIBROUS DYSPLASIA

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental anomaly of bone formation.
  • The hallmark is replacement of normal bone and marrow by fibrous tissue and small woven spicules of bone.
  • Fibrous dysplasia can occur in the epiphysis, metaphysis, or diaphysis.
  • It may affect one bone (monostotic form) or several bones (polyostotic form).
  • The monostotic form is the most common and is usually diagnosed in patients between 20 and 30 years of age. It most commonly affects the femur.
  • The polyostotic form typically manifests in children <10 years of age and may progress with age. It most commonly affects the maxilla and other craniofacial bones.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome refers to polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, cutaneous pigmentation (café au lait spots), and endocrine abnormalities (Precoceous puberty).
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” borders).
  • Fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur has shepherd crook deformity.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • In long bones, the fibrous dysplastic lesions have ground-glass appearance.

 

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity (looks like shepherds stick which is crooked in shape) bone is replaced by fibrous tissue in fibrous dysplasia.

  • The multiloculated translucent lesion may be surrounded by a sclerotic rim, called ‘Rind sign’.

     

 

A. Shepherd Crook deformity; B. Rind sign 

 

  • Involvement of facial bones may create a leonine appearance (leontiasis ossea).
    • On biopsy, Chinese Letter Pattern is recognised.
    • Surgical treatment (Curettage + bone grafting) is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blade of grass deformity. The blade of grass sign, also called the candle flame sign, refers to the lucent leading edge in a long bone seen during the lytic phase of Paget disease of bone. The lytic, or incipient active, phase of the disease is characterized by intense osteoclastic activity that is exhibited on radiographs as osteolysis. In the long bones, osteolysis is manifested as a characteristic metaphyseal to diaphyseal wedge-shaped area of radiolucency that assumes the configuration of a flame or blade of grass. This advancing wedge of osteolysis, which begins in the subchondral bone of the epiphysis and extends peripherally into the metaphysis and diaphysis, spreads about 1 cm per year and shows no marginal sclerosis. A potential pitfall is misdiagnosing the track sign of the femur as the blade of grass sign.

 

 

Option C. Chicken wire appearance. Histopathologically, cellular areas in chondroblastoma are composed of “chondroblasts” with an oval to round nucleus and with well-defined eosinophilic cytoplasm. A fine network of pericellular calcification called “chicken wire calcification” are seen in the cytoplasm or stroma some cases.

 

 

Option D. Corduroy appearance. Hemangioma is a common benign bone lesion. It is estimated that 10% of the population has asymptomatic hemangioma of the vertebral bodies. Hemangiomas also are common in the skull. They usually are discovered as incidental findings. The radiographic appearance in the spine usually is characteristic, with thickened, vertically oriented trabeculae giving the classic “jailhouse” (Corduroy) appearance. In cross-section, these thickened trabeculae have a “polka dot” pattern on CT scan.

 

Treatment usually is not necessary.

 

 

Polka dot appearance on CT scan

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

 

The symptoms with the microscopic findings which shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci suggests infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment of choice for the infection is ceftriaxone.

 

Treatment of Gonorrhoea –

 

  • Third generation cephalosporins – DOC for uncomplicated gonococcal infection - both the sexual partners should be treated.
  • Ceftriaxone (250 mg given IM, single dose)
  • Cefixime (400 mg given orally, single dose)
  • If coexisting chlamydial infection – azithromycin or doxycycline added.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythromycin and Option B. Azithromycin are macrolides, generally used for chlamydial infections or as a co-treatment when chlamydia is suspected alongside gonorrhea.

 

Option D. Penicillin G is no longer recommended as the primary treatment for gonorrhea due to widespread resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially cases presenting with urethral discharge and identified intracellular gram-negative diplococci, Ceftriaxone remains the treatment of choice. This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

choices.text: 10 to 12 weeks
8 to 10 weeks

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you in her early pregnancy with anemia. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should the iron supplements be started for her? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 to 10 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Prophylaxis for anemia in pregnancy is generally started at 14 weeks and continued for 180 days. However, the given question indicates that the patient has moderate anemia and requires immediate treatment. Among the provided options, the earliest time to start iron supplements is 8 to 10 weeks, making this the correct answer.

 

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign, the severity of anemia is classified as follows:

 

  • Mild: 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate: 7-9 g%
  • Severe: <7 g%

 

Testing and Treating Mild and Moderate Anemia

 

  • Mild anemia or moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron.
  • Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron: Administer parenteral iron, such as iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe Anemia

 

  • Hemoglobin < 7 g%: Administer iron carboxymaltose.
  • Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%: Admit the patient for further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10 to 12 weeks: While this is an earlier time frame than the standard prophylactic start, it is not as early as 8 to 10 weeks, which is necessary for moderate anemia.

 

Option C. After 14 weeks: This is the standard time for starting prophylactic iron supplements but is too late for a patient with moderate anemia who requires immediate treatment.

 

Option D. After 20 weeks: This is much too late for initiating treatment for anemia, especially for a patient with moderate anemia needing earlier intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of moderate anemia (Hb 7-9 g/dL) in early pregnancy, iron supplements should be started as early as 8 to 10 weeks to ensure timely treatment.

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation and presents with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. On examination, fetal movements are normal, fetal parts not easily felt and muffled fetal heartbeat is heard. Symphysis fundal height came out to be 41 cm. Per abdomen examination reveals tense abdomen but not tender. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyhydramnios

 

The given scenario of 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

 

Polyhydramnios

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placenta: Abruption Placenta presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.

 

Option B. Hydrocephalus of fetus: Hydrocephalus of the fetus leads to increased head circumference in the fetus, which may cause an increased symphysis fundal height but unlikely to cause breathlessness and abdominal distension to this extent.

 

Option D. Fetal-maternal ascites: Patients of Fetal-maternal ascites commonly present with edema, proteinuria, hypertension, elevated liver enzymes and headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, it most likely points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with golden-brown ring over iris on examination. What next is done to diagnose the condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum ceruloplasmin

 

This is the most relevant test for the suspected condition. Wilson's disease is a rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other vital organs. Ceruloplasmin is a protein that binds copper in the bloodstream. In Wilson's disease, serum ceruloplasmin levels are typically low. Testing serum ceruloplasmin is a key diagnostic step for Wilson's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum Iron Level: While important in diagnosing conditions related to iron metabolism such as hemochromatosis or iron-deficiency anemia, serum iron levels are not directly relevant for diagnosing Wilson's disease. Hemochromatosis can also lead to liver damage but doesn't cause Kayser-Fleischer rings.

 

Option C. Alpha-1 Antitrypsin: This test is used to diagnose alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a genetic condition that can cause lung and liver disease. However, it is not related to the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings and would not be the appropriate next step in this scenario.

 

Option D. Alpha-Fetoprotein: This is a marker often used in the diagnosis of liver cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma. While liver dysfunction is a component of Wilson's disease, alpha-fetoprotein is not a diagnostic marker for Wilson's disease and would not be the best next step in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient presents with Kayser-Fleischer rings, it is crucial to evaluate for Wilson's disease, a condition of abnormal copper metabolism. Serum ceruloplasmin is a key diagnostic test in this situation. Understanding the appropriate diagnostic approach for specific clinical signs is essential in guiding effective and efficient patient care.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with distant visual acuity of 6/18, which improved on pin-hole testing. He gives history of not needing glasses for near vision now. On ocular examination findings as shown in image were seen. Patient has which of the following refractory error. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Index Myopia

 

Given the patient's age and the description of the symptoms, the most likely refractive error in this case is Index Myopia. This occurs when nuclear sclerosis starts in the crystalline lens, resulting in change in the density and hence the refractive index of the lens. This causes light rays to focus in front of the retina, leading to blurred distant vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axial Myopia: Axial myopia is a common form of myopia and is usually a stable condition that doesn't suddenly appear in old age.

 

Option B. Curvatural Myopia: This form of myopia is due to an increased curvature of the cornea or lens, which makes the eye's focusing power too strong. This also results in the focal point being in front of the retina, causing distant objects to be blurred. Like axial myopia, curvatural myopia is generally present from a younger age and does not develop suddenly in seniors.

 

Option C. Positional Myopia: This type of myopia can occur due to the displacement of the lens within the eye, which can sometimes happen with a subluxated lens. Positional myopia is not a common form of myopia and would not typically be associated with the symptom of improved near vision without the need for glasses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phenomenon of "second sight" in older adults is often associated with the development of nuclear sclerotic cataracts, which can cause a change in the refractive index of the lens, leading to index myopia. An important clinical sign is improvement in near vision in a previously hypermetropic (or presbyopic) individual, along with a decrease in distance vision that improves with pinhole testing. It's essential to recognize these signs and symptoms for the correct diagnosis and management of cataracts.

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: In a patient presented with a fever and a positive filarial antigen test, what is the next best step of management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

 

Given patient with fever and filarial antigen test positive points to diagnosis of filariasis. And the next best step for this patient is the detection of microfilariae in the blood smear.

 

The gold standard method to diagnose active infection is by demonstrating microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopy.

 

It is critical and should be based on the periodicity of the microfilariae. For nocturnal periodicity, blood should be collected between 9 pm and 2 am.

 

DEC provocation test is done to collect the blood in the day time. Patient takes a tablet of DEC orally (2mg/kg) so that the nocturnal microfilariae are stimulated and come to peripheral blood within 30 minutes.

 

Although there is an advantage of blood sample collection even during day time, the guidelines from CDC, NVBDCP, and IAPSM suggest blood sample collection at night, followed by identification of microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopic examination as the standard method for diagnosis.

 

Other methods to detect adult worms include:

 

  • Lymph node biopsy to detect adult worms.
  • X-ray (if worms are calcified)
  • High-frequency ultrasound and doppler of the scrotum (Option D).
  • Serology - Antigen detection by using monoclonal antibodies against Og4C3 and AD12 antigens.
  • ELISA and ICT

 

Treatment - Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) → DOC. Given orally in a dose of 6 mg per kg body weight daily for a period of 12 days. It kills microfilariae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone Marrow Biopsy: Not relevant for filariasis, as it does not involve the bone marrow.

 

Option B. DEC Provocation Test: While useful for driving microfilariae into the peripheral blood for easier detection during daytime, it is less direct than a nighttime blood smear.

 

Option D. Ultrasound of the Scrotum: Useful in chronic cases to detect adult worms in lymphatic vessels, particularly in cases of lymphatic filariasis affecting the scrotum, but not as immediate or definitive for acute diagnosis as a blood smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For direct confirmation of active filarial infection, detection of microfilariae in a blood smear is essential. This method provides clear evidence of the parasites in the bloodstream, crucial for diagnosing and managing filariasis effectively.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.(NEET PG  2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine

 

Given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of neurolathyrism, for which the toxin responsible is beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOAA).

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings
  • Osteolathyrism: In animals

 

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Lathyrism affects 15 - 45 years of age

 

  • Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)’Q
  • It manifests as following stages:
    • Latent stage
    • No-stick stage
    • One-stick stage
    • Two-stick stage
    • Crawler stage
  • Interventions for prevention and control of Lathyrism:
    • Vitamin C
    • Banning the crop
    • Removal of toxin: Steeping method and Parboiling
    • Education
    • Genetic approach
    • Socio-economic changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aflatoxin: Toxin produced by Aspergillus species. It causes aflatoxicosis and is commonly found in contaminated ground nuts.

 

Option C. Ergot alkaloids: Toxins produced by Claviceps species, leading to ergotism. Found in contaminated cereals.

 

Option D. Fusarium toxin: Toxins produced by Fusarium species, which can contaminate grains and other food products, causing fusarium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration Diseases

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (NEET PG 2023)

 

  • Anti-HBc (IgM): Positive
  • HBsAg: Positive
  • Anti-HBs: Negative
  • Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute hepatitis B

 

The serology results provide crucial information for diagnosing the type of hepatitis the patient has:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Positive
    • This indicates an active hepatitis B infection, as HBsAg is a marker of infection.
  2. Anti-HBc (IgM) (Hepatitis B core antibody, IgM): Positive
    • The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection or acute hepatitis B. IgM is produced early in the infection and suggests that the infection is recent.
  3. Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): Negative
    • The absence of anti-HBs indicates that the patient has not resolved the infection or been vaccinated. In the context of acute infection, this is expected as the patient has not yet developed immunity.
  4. Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
    • This indicates that the patient does not have hepatitis C.

 

Based on these results, the diagnosis is acute hepatitis B. The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc are key indicators of an acute infection.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Acute hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Option C. Chronic hepatitis B: Chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed when HBsAg persists for more than six months and is typically associated with IgG anti-HBc, not IgM.

 

Option D. Chronic hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc in a patient with fever, jaundice, and malaise strongly indicates acute hepatitis B.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, and the x-ray showed the following features. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Putty kidney

 

Given patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria along with the given x-ray points to a diagnosis of a putty kidney.

 

GENITOURINARY TB

 

C/F - Increased frequency of urine

Urine Analysis - Sterile pyuria

Most Sensitive Investigation - IVP

Sign - Moth eaten calyces (irregularity of calyces d/t inflammation caused by TB bacillus)

Bladder - Thimble bladder (low volume bladder because of persistent inflammation)

END STAGE: Putty kidney [lobar calcification of kidney]

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrocalcinosis:  Calcium deposits in the kidney tissue itself due to any disorder that leads to high levels of calcium in the blood or urine

 

 

Option C. Staghorn calculi: usually develop due to prolonged urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Pseudomonas species. Commonly composed of struvite.

 

 

Option D. Psoas calcification: This refers to calcification within the psoas muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Putty kidney is an advanced renal pathology often resulting from chronic infections such as tuberculosis, leading to extensive calcification and renal dysfunction. This condition is distinguishable on imaging by its irregular, extensive calcifications throughout the kidney, associated with clinical symptoms like abdominal pain and sterile pyuria.

questions.text: A husband and wife presented to the outpatient department with complaints of the husband's premature ejaculation, which is leading to frequent conflicts between them. Which of the following non-pharmacological techniques is most appropriate for treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squeeze Technique

 

For the management of premature ejaculation, the Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method that is often recommended. This technique involves sexual stimulation until the individual is close to ejaculation. At that point, the partner squeezes the shaft of the penis (coronal ridge of glans) for several seconds, which can delay ejaculation. This process is repeated several times before ejaculation is allowed to occur. The Squeeze Technique helps in increasing the time before ejaculation and is directly targeted at managing premature ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensate Focus Technique: While this technique, which involves non-genital pleasuring, can be helpful in reducing performance anxiety and improving sexual communication, it is not specifically designed for the treatment of premature ejaculation. It is useful for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Exposure and Response Prevention: This is a technique used primarily in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder and is not typically employed for premature ejaculation.

 

Option D. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): CBT can be useful for addressing underlying psychological issues contributing to sexual dysfunction, but it is a more general approach and not as specifically targeted for premature ejaculation as the Squeeze Technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method effective in the management of premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis before the point of ejaculation to delay it and can be repeated several times to increase the time before ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 531.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cefazolin

 

The drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery is Cefazolin, a first-generation cephalosporin. This class of antibiotics is preferred due to their efficacy against the most frequently encountered pathogenic organisms causing surgical site infections in cardiac surgeries.

 

  • Antimicrobial prophylaxis: Administered to cover the most frequently encountered pathogenic organisms causing surgical site infections.
  • Timing: The first dose should be given within 60 minutes before skin incision for an optimal duration of 24 hours but should not exceed 48 hours.
  • Special cases: In MRSA-positive cases, Vancomycin is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillin G: Not typically used for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery as it does not cover the range of organisms most commonly associated with surgical site infections in this context.

 

Option B. Erythromycin: Not the preferred choice for surgical prophylaxis in cardiac surgery due to its spectrum of activity and potential side effects.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: While it has a broad spectrum of activity, it is not the standard choice for preoperative prophylaxis in cardiac surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery is Cefazolin, administered within 60 minutes before incision to prevent surgical site infections.

questions.text: After using a hair dye a lady developed a skin reaction as shown in the image. Which of the following chemicals among given options is responsible for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Para-Phenylenediamine

 

The history of hair dye use and above image points to a diagnosis of contact dermatitis due to an allergen called Para phenylenediamine.

 

Contact Dermatitis is of 2 types:

 

 

Diagnosis of Allergic CD – PATCH TEST

 

Examples of Allergic CD:

 

  1. Hair dye: PPD (para phenylenediamine)
  2. Metal: Nickel (most common)
  3. Topical antibiotic: Neomycin
  4. Cement: Potassium dichromate
  5. Bindi: PTBP (para tertiary butyl phenol)

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pollen:

 

  • Pollen is a common allergen that can cause allergic reactions in some individuals.
  • However, the use of hair dye does not typically involve exposure to pollen, so it is unlikely to be the cause of the skin reaction in this context.

 

Option B. Chromates:

 

  • Chromates, particularly hexavalent chromium compounds, can be found in some industrial processes and certain products.
  • While exposure to chromates can cause skin reactions in some cases, they are not commonly found in hair dyes, so they are less likely to be the cause here.

 

Option C. Balsam of Peru:

 

  • Balsam of Peru is a known allergen found in various cosmetics and fragrance products.
  • It can cause allergic contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
  • If the hair dye contains Balsam of Peru, it could be a potential allergen, but it is not as commonly associated with hair dye allergies as PPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Para-Phenylenediamine (PPD) is a common cause of allergic contact dermatitis (delayed hypersensitivity reaction) associated with hair dye use.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition: 89.73 128.15, 128.42, 128.60

choices.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

 

Explanation:

 

Marked point on the myocardial action potential curve represents the plateau phase, which is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels.

 

Two types of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (T- and L-types) are present in myocardial cells. The opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels are mostly responsible for changes in the action potential. The action potential curve of cardiac muscles consists of 5 phases, as shown.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it mentions both the opening of sodium channels and the closure of fast potassium channels, which is characteristic of Phase 0, not the plateau phase.

 

Option C: Incorrect as it attributes the phase to the closure of sodium channels and the opening of slow potassium channels, which more accurately describes the repolarization phase (Phase 3) of the myocardial action potential.

 

Option D: Incorrect because the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which helps maintain the resting membrane potential, is not the primary driver of the changes observed in the plateau phase.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of a patient with history of a chronic knee pain. True statement concerning the X-ray shown would be: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bipartite patella; X-ray other knee

 

BIPARTITE PATELLA

 

  • It is the congenital fragmentation of patella.
  • In this condition, the patella is made up of two separate bones instead of one.
  • It occurs when the patella fails to fuse properly during development, leading to a bipartite appearance.
  • This condition is typically asymptomatic and may go unnoticed for many years.
  • In some cases, it can cause pain, swelling, or discomfort, especially during physical activity.
  • The X-ray of opposite knee must be taken as the condition is bilateral in 50% of cases and this condition is more common in males than females.

 

 

  • Management usually involves conservative measures to alleviate symptoms like rest, ice, and physical therapy to strengthen the Quadriceps muscles, and reduce stress on the patella.
  • In more severe cases, a brace may be recommended to provide additional support and reduce stress on the patella.
  • Pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs may also be prescribed to relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  • If conservative measures fail to provide relief, surgery may be considered. Surgery typically involves removing the smaller bone fragment and smoothing the joint surface to reduce friction and alleviate pain.
  • In rare cases, surgery may involve fusing the two patellar fragments together to create a single patella.
  • With appropriate treatment, most people can return to their normal activities without significant limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avulsion fracture; cylindrical cast. In avulsion fracture of PCL alone, the non-operative treatment relies on restoration of tibiofemoral relationship with immobilization, followed by physiotherapy. In the first 6 weeks, immobilization and limited weight bearing is achieved using a cylindrical cast in 15° flexion or with posterior support in the form of extension or dynamic anterior drawer brace to prevent subluxation of tibia.

 

 

Option C. Avulsion fracture; wire fixation. K-wire fixation is done for distal phalanx base avulsion fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows bipartite patella which is a congenital fragmentation of patella i.e., the patella is made of two separate bones instead of one.
  • In this condition, it is always recommended to get an x-ray of the other knee also as this condition is bilateral in most cases.
  • It is treated by surgical removal of the smaller bone fragment when the conservative methods fail to provide relief.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for the same since a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea, and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

The drug that is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects is amiodarone.

 

Amiodarone

 

→ Longest acting [t1/2 → > 3 weeks] anti-arrhythmic drug

 

→ MOA →

  1. Na+ channel Blocker
  2. β-Blocker (Non-competitive)
  3. K+ channel Blocker [Main action]
  4. Calcium channel blocker

 

→ Indicated in all arrhythmias except Torsades de pointes

 

→ Adverse effect of amiodarone:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol is a Selective Beta 1 Blocker. C/I in Bradycardia, AV Block and Acute CHF. It is used in HTN, Classical angina, MI, Chronic CHF, Arrythmia

 

Option C. Aspirin: Aspirin is only irreversible COX Inhibitor, anti-platelet drug. C/I in child with viral infection (Due to Reye’s syndrome). Can cause Hyperuricemia at therapeutic doses - avoid in gout

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is classified under potassium-sparing diuretic. Promotes sodium diuresis but maintains the body's potassium levels. C/I in patients with hyperkalemia. Can cause gynecomastia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is associated with a range of serious side effects, including pulmonary fibrosis, thyroid dysfunction, liver toxicity, and photosensitivity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tricuspid stenosis

 

The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur and a prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) are key indicators for diagnosing tricuspid stenosis.

 

Tricuspid Stenosis causes an obstruction to right ventricular inflow, which leads to an increase in right atrial pressure, reflected as a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP. The mid-diastolic murmur is due to the turbulent flow across the narrowed tricuspid valve during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Stenosis: While it can cause a diastolic murmur, it typically does not cause a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP unless there is secondary pulmonary hypertension affecting the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Mitral Regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur and, if severe enough to cause pulmonary hypertension, may indirectly cause changes in the JVP, but it does not directly cause a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Option D. Tricuspid Regurgitation: This condition causes a large 'v' wave in the JVP due to backflow of blood into the right atrium during systole, not a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A prominent 'a' wave in JVP and a mid-diastolic murmur are indicative of tricuspid stenosis, a condition causing right ventricular inflow obstruction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent a bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

 

  • Pain in the thigh (Meralgia Paraesthetica) is due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. This nerve entrapment often occurs during laparoscopic hernia repair, especially during the placement of mesh.
  •  The nerves commonly injured in laparoscopic repair are the genitofemoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves of the thigh.
  •  Patients with lateral cutaneous nerve injury present with acute neuropathic pain along the dermatomal distribution, resulting in meralgia paresthetica.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Treatment consists of rest, ice, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and possible local corticosteroid and anesthetic injection.
  • Drugs like gabapentin can be used to manage neuropathic pain.
  • In laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) repair, to reduce the chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve leads to sensory disturbances and pain over the skin of the genitalia and upper medial thigh. This nerve is most commonly injured in open repair of inguinal hernia, not laparoscopic repair.

 

Option B. Iliohypogastric nerve: The iliohypogastric nerve leads to pain in the inguinal and suprapubic regions. Injury to this nerve does not typically result in pain isolated to the thigh.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: Femoral nerve injury presents as lower limb numbness, weakness, tingling, paralysis, or pain along the nerve. However, femoral nerve injury is less likely to be caused by laparoscopic hernia repair and more often associated with other surgical procedures or traumatic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair.
  •  Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are included in qSOFA score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SBP, RR, GCS score

 

  • The Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score is used to identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit.
  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria:
    1. Respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min: A high respiratory rate indicates respiratory distress and a higher risk of organ failure.
    2. Systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg: Low blood pressure indicates hemodynamic instability and a higher risk of mortality.
    3. Change in mental status (GCS score): Altered mental status, measured by the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), indicates possible central nervous system dysfunction.
  • Each criterion is assigned one point, and a qSOFA score of ≥2 suggests a higher risk of adverse outcomes and increased mortality.

 

qSOFA (Quick SOFA) Criteria

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BP, RR, and CBC: This option includes blood pressure and respiratory rate, but the complete blood count (CBC) is not part of the qSOFA score.

 

Option B. Creatinine, PR, BP:  Creatinine and pulse rate (PR) are not part of the qSOFA score. Blood pressure is included, but the qSOFA score focuses on systolic blood pressure specifically.

 

Option C. RR, Body temperature, PR: Respiratory rate is part of the qSOFA score, but body temperature and pulse rate are not included.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria: respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg, and altered mental status (GCS score).
  • A qSOFA score of ≥2 indicates a higher risk of poor outcomes in patients with suspected infection.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upper airway examination

 

The image shows a tracheostomy tube, which is not used for upper airway examination.

 

Tracheostomy:

 

  • It is a procedure where alternative airway is established when normal airway is compromised.
  • An opening is made on the anterior wall of trachea and a tube is inserted, through which air exchange occurs between lungs and outside.
  • It bypasses upper airway structures from nose to larynx thereby reducing the dead space by 50%.
  • Usually done at the level of 2nd to 3rd tracheal rings.
  • High tracheostomy (1st ring) done along with surgeries related to cancer larynx.
  • In emergency tracheostomy, vertical incision is taken but in elective cases, horizontal incision is taken.
  • It is generally a temporary procedure till the pathology in the upper bypassed airway clears.
  • In some cases, like cancer larynx where laryngectomy was done, permanent tracheostomy is done.
  • Removal of tracheostomy tube is called decannulation.
  • Different types of tracheostomy tubes – PVC, Metallic (Chevalier-Jackson), etc.
  • Complications of tracheostomy → surgical emphysema, hemorrhage, Apnea due to CO2 washout, Pneumothorax, Tube displacement, Tube blockage, Tracheomalacia, Subglottic stenosis

 

Other Options:

 

Primary Uses of a Tracheostomy Tube Include:

 

Option A. Airway Toileting: Facilitates the removal of secretions from the airways.

 

Option C. Acute Nasopharyngeal Obstruction: Provides an airway bypass in cases of blockage in the upper airway.

 

Option D. Prolonged Mechanical Ventilation: Offers a secure, stable method for long-term ventilation support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy tubes are not used for examining the upper airway as they do not provide access or visibility to upper airway structures such as the nasal passages, pharynx, or larynx. Instead, tools like laryngoscopes or endoscopes are employed for this purpose.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

 

  • In the given scenario of dilated pancreatic duct with stones, a drainage procedure in the form of longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy (Peusthow) is preferred.
  • CHRONIC PANCREATITIS - Irreversible damage to architecture of pancreas.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple’s procedure): This procedure involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and bile duct. It is typically reserved for malignancies or specific inflammatory conditions localized to the head of the pancreas. It is not the primary choice for diffuse chronic pancreatitis with a dilated duct.

 

Option C. ERCP and sphincterotomy: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy can aid in the removal of pancreatic calculi but is not considered a long-term solution for chronic pancreatitis with a significantly dilated duct.

 

Option D. Coring of the pancreas head: Coring of the pancreatic head may be considered if inflammation is limited to the head of the pancreas alone, but it is not suitable for the diffuse dilation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with chronic pancreatitis and a significantly dilated pancreatic duct (greater than 6 mm), the preferred surgical treatment is longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (Peustow procedure).
  • This procedure helps to relieve ductal hypertension and improve drainage, alleviating pain and other symptoms associated with chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mannitol

 

The patient is experiencing Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), a complication that can occur during or after hemodialysis, especially in patients with initially very high urea levels undergoing dialysis for the first time. DDS is caused by a rapid decrease in urea levels in the blood, leading to a sudden change in osmolarity, which causes water to move into the cells, resulting in cerebral edema and neurological symptoms such as drowsiness and seizures.

 

  • Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS): This condition is characterized by neurological symptoms due to cerebral edema caused by rapid changes in blood urea levels during dialysis.
  • Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic is used to treat cerebral edema by reducing intracranial pressure and drawing fluid out of the brain cells, thus decreasing cerebral edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bumetanide: This loop diuretic is used for fluid overload but not specifically indicated for treating cerebral edema in DDS.

 

Option B. Ethacrynic acid: Another loop diuretic, similar to bumetanide, and not used for DDS.

 

Option C. Nesiritide: A recombinant form of B-type natriuretic peptide used in acute heart failure, not for treating DDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment for Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), which can occur during or after dialysis, involves reducing cerebral edema. The first-line treatment is mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.
